text: aroma is of lots of fruit ( reminds me of strawberry jelly & gummy fruit snacks ) . slight yeast aroma sneaks in there as well along with a tiny bit of alcohol-big but not complex . the fruit overpowers much of the aromas .  the beer pours a deep chocolate brown color and with little light passing through . first sip reveals an average body with very fine gentle rolling carbonation .  mouthfeel was super dry , yet still drinkable enough .

smell - chocolate malts , but otherwise a very quiet and balanced scent .  pours a completely opaque black color with a very large brown head , excellent lacing .  i never understand why beers like this always come so highly rated here on ba . plenty of caramel taste ( and flavour ) smooth and a little thick.i drank one cold and one warm to compare taste , niether was better than the other , pretty bland really overall .

i got hardly any aroma from this except a faint coffee malt note .  i feel like i 'm throwing gang size attempting to measure the size of the head with my fingers ; it 's huge . slowly it settles down into a bumpy and lumpy head that sticks around til the end . crazy lacing all over . a gorgeous beer .  a little too carbonated for my liking . a little smoothness would help .

smell - not all that potent , but some sweet notes of dried fruit . overall - a very good brew . a barleywine i would recommend over others i have had .  truly a fantastic and somewhat intimidating looking beer .  the first sip reveals and average body with very fine tingly carbonation . the body is a little lighter than i expected and not quite as sticky as hoped .

lots of grapefruit smelling hop -- fresh ; slight metalic aroma .  pours an extremely dark brown with exciting caronation cascades ( owing to the special draftflow you hear clinking in the can ) and super creamy brown head that leaves perfect lace rings until the entire pint is gone .  very dry . a definite sipper .

the aroma is nice , too , with some slight grainy spiciness , faint mustiness , and a little floral note , but its a little too subtle .  just a very inviting looking brew .  could easily pass for an ipa . mf- zesty carbonation livens up the body a bit but the weight is hard to perceive .

i smell the coffee already , and my nose is nowhere near the mug . got ta admit that worried me for a moment , but eh , i 'll try anything once . i 'm pleasantly surprised , would definitely get it again ...  a pitch black stout with a wonderful coffee colour head .  cocoa powder taste , not too sweet , has a bite to it . not too bad for an irish stout .

i tried and yeah ... drink this one fresh if you can . classic stout beer that is not a milk stout . not much on the smell but who cares ... .we are talking taste here and nothing else . silky smooth , creamy , easy to drink , an overall wonderful stout .  black pour with slight 1/2 inch dark mocha head .  m : smooth and creamy , but it does feel watery on the mid-palate , maybe i expected more with the thick motor oil-esque appearance , but i wish this was a little more beefed up . d : aside from the minor mouthfeel problems which really were n't a big deal to me , this is a very good black lager .

the smell was very minimal malt . this was a very nice , smooth and enjoyable porter .  pours amazingly dark , actually completely black body hosting a two finger thick beautiful milk chocolate head .  m : a little thin for my taste especially for a winter beer , but other positive aspects more than make up for it .

malted wheat and pale malt nose , otherwise clean .  pours an absurd black color with one of the darkest brown heads imaginable .  mouthfeel enters well with strong carbonation but it fizzes out as it moves back and is quite bloating after swallow .

smell was not very pronounced . the taste was not very pronounced either , some hops bitterness but primarily a very balanced and extremely smooth beer .  the beer poured magnificently . it raised a beautiful head , probably a half-inch thick . it was poured into a lead-crystal goblet , and it was the perfect choice for this beauty .  a mild estery maltiness comes through , very sweet , with minimal hops . the flavor is basically all butterscotch diacetyl . nothing else comes through besides a creamy cloying buttery sugary flavor . pretty terrible . i would have rather had a budweiser .

nose is a bit light , it 's a bit toasty and coffee .  pours a deep brown with an exceptional head .  i must say i was quite surprised by this one . i am a beer buyer for a grocery store in cambridge and one of my reps passed me this and after drinking this one it will certainly be a staple in my store . its pours just gorgeous into a pint glass and just tastes like a dream just a great beer overall .

all i pick up is lemon , some faint grain , fresh cooked corn ... digging a little deeper yields some sugared grapefruit , grassy hops and a honey touch . ok , not bad ... not great . multi dimensional without being heavy ... the perfect balance between hefe and ipa ... this is very refreshing .  extremely impressive lacing sticks peskily in narrow concentric bands . for what it 's worth , one of the best looking beers i 've ever seen .  m-this is just a little grainy , syrupy up front , light thin body , a little too thin .

the aroma was fairly non-descript , with minor floral notes .  a solid pour forms a dense rocky head that leaves a significant amount of lace behind with each gulp .  m-a little light on the body , for which a higher level of carbonation revs up and slightly compensates . it 's refreshing , complex , and light .

thick oily black with moderate tan head , this beer certainly looks like a black ale . nose was n't too great for me , as i was getting some off aromas ... mildew-y aromas even ... i did n't like those .  pours black with a thick creamy tan head .  mouthfeel is thin but appropriate for the style , i would like to see just a bit more of bite from the carbonation though .

nose is suprisingly muted . hoppy yes , piney and mildly resinous , with a toasty malt underbelly , but lacking in aromatics compared with many of stone 's other brews .  pours an oily pitch black , a whopping two inch head of tan color , sits there for several minutes before receding to a thick foam , and lacing spiderwebs before disintegrating into a multitude of spots .  mouthfeel - light on the bubbles .

the appearance looked very dark for what it is , so it sure did n't look that light.the smell of this beer is n't as fragrant as i would thought a fruit beer would have , however smelling aroma from the beers is n't my forte . the taste and mouthfeel of this beer is excellent . i certainly loved the taste of this beer because it is n't overly sweet like some of the other fruit beers i 've tasted over the years .  appearance : a beautiful dark red amber with an off white head , lacing is present on the glass .  m - definitely this beer 's weakpoint . when too cold its too watery . it 's a little over overcarbonated as well .

steel reserve has an appealing medium golden-amber color and a pleasant bready bouquet . i just wish it tasted like it smelled or looked .  a-clear amber color with a great amount of creamy white head that leaves very nice lacing .  a dark chocolate bitterness floating right above a very light body of roasted grains . at 3.3 abv this is a very light and highly drinkable session beer . almost too easy to drink . a unique beer in a special style .

the aroma has a lot going on but is very subtle . not like other imperial ipa 's that jump out and grab your nostrels .  a -- beautiful lacing . color appropriately pale .  mouthfeel : medium body , sticky , sweet , and carbonated .

the nose is fresh and light and almost seems to have some floral notes . thick and creamy mouthfeel .  the head which was tan in color retained quite well and lacing was thick , sheeted , and in rings as well . a visual delight .  t- smooth with just the right amount of hops with a slight bitterness/ dryness in the finish m- a bit thinner than i antisipated , but about on par with others in this style d- an easy drinker with a subtle complexity , will i be having this again ?

s- must , sweet malt , booze , a pet store t- booze , toffee , caramel , candi sugar , molasses .  translucent amber color with a big creamy light-tan head . tons of sticky lacing and great retention .  a little on the flat side .

a tried-and-true bottle-conditioned english best bitter . smell : a little grape-y ( not grapefruit ) , understated ( typical of the style ) . neither the maltiness , which tends towards fruity rather than bready , nor the hops dominate this beer : it 's simply a wonderful marriage of very good raw ingredients . this is the first time i had this beer , and sometimes my prejudice ( for and against ) english bitters compels me to usually rate their beers `` quaint '' and unremarkable .  33cl bottle pours a thick creamy head with descent retention , and sticky , patchy lace . imho this beer looks great , but otherwise , i do n't get it .  mouthfeel is dry and somewhat chalky .
aroma is faint , some dry roasted malts .  poured almost opaque black , with a nice off white 3 finger head .  a little too thin and carbonated .

i barely picked up any smell , but my sense of smell is n't that good and i do n't mind much . this porter is sweet , but you still pick up on the chocalate malt notes . incredibly drinkable .  pours a nearly impenetrable black hue with a one-inch layer of light tan foam that fades away to a lingering bubbly cap that clings easily to the walls of the glass , leaving behind gorgeous well-formed rings of lace as it empties .  the body is a tad thin compared to others i 've had but smooth as can be .

aroma - malty sweet with some caramel presence , too . kind of light smell-wise , but what is here is good . i will be getting more of these for the fall/winter .  produced a huge foamy tan head with superb retention behind it and tons of lace .  the malt character is very subdued in this ipa . if a beer could ever be considered juicy ... this is it . not much body to this , as someone else mentioned more like a really hoppy pale ale . that said , i still find this to be quite a successful ipa the citrus flavors are really great and fresh tasting .

very soft aromas , faint wheat bread . overall this is a tasty , smooth , and very drinkable beer .  scored this on a move today . cascading brown pour leaves an opaque black beer and creamy white head in it 's wake .  carbonation is average .

s - sour lemon and yeast aromas t - taste has some bready notes a hint of citrus and plenty of spice , more of a belgian pa for me .  can poured into a nonic , the caldera pale ale is a golden yellow with a moderate size , very tight white head that 's long lasting and leaves thick hunks of lace .  the beers appearance is average , lacks in color to be above average ( looked a little watery to be honest ) . the taste is great , smooth , hoppy , fruity all i expected and more . this is a very drinkable beer in fact i killed a 4 pack when trying it for the first time ... .great job dfh .

4 smell - a relatively weak aroma predominantly featuring pine and hops .  a 22-ounce , twist-off topped bomber bottle poured into a large tulip glass yields a bright , glowing , golden-orange body capped with an enormous layer of soft milk-white foam . the head refuses to depart the drinktop , subsiding to a fat , free-floating puck-style structure that leaves gobs of 3-d lacing spattered all over the glassware .  this was much like the carolina pale ale , but naturally hoppier . there was a good balance between the malt and hops ; it was quite bitter , but there seemed to be more flavoring hops than anything . unlike the carolina pale ale , i would drink this while out of the state as it is one of the more balancced ipas i have had .

smell : light malt sweetness , grass , and a hint of lemon rise from the glass .  *note : this is a 2007 vintage* a - poured into a goblet this has a nice mahogany , cloudy pour with one of the most impressive heads i 've ever seen . this 1 finger of big bubble head hung around for the duration of the ale leaving massive , clumpy side lacing . i'ver never seen bubbles of this size before in my brew , its insane !  m & # 8211 ; smooth , no complaints , but it doesn & # 8217 ; t enhance the flavor .

tasted 7/14 a - pours a pretty reddish honey s - i did n't detect too much besides yeast and malt t - begins with citrus notes , a tiny hop bite follows , ends nutty m - pretty light d - real high ! pretty light and tasty .  appearance- cloudyish yellow-golden pour with massive amounts of foam . very nice lacing .  m - slightly thin , decent carbonation .
has somewhat of a fizzy , carbonated nose that smells of sweet roasted malts and some alcohol .  appearance was black with a fantastic head and great lacing .  m - this is a bit thin .

still though , i wanted to give this a shot since i love stouts and love langunitas ... hoping the coffee does n't put me off too much . smells of roasted coffee and toasted malts .  appearance : deep black in color with a thick 2 '' milk chocolate colored head .  m : a little bit thin , and slightly alcoholic o : a solid belgian strong blonde , but ca n't touch duvel .

the nose is behind the rest of this brew . i pulled nothing but malt and some type of barley smell . the feel is decent but slightly better than mediocre , nothing to really to note .  pours a deep hell-fire red with an awesome off white head that would not go away . this beer looks and tastes like the definition of `` strong '' .  tastes like a pilsner on the back end m - stays mostly in the front part of the mouth , so somewhat limited overall in this respect d - at 3 % , this is something you could literally drink all day and not feel it .

low aroma of cocoa and marshmallow . i wish i had a maduro cigar .  pours a strong burgundy color with a thin off-white head . unlike many old ales which look dead in the glass , both clarity and lacing are strong with this beer .  the mouthfeel is just a touch too thin .

a-hazy and yellow with a brown glow , incredibly thick foamy long lasting head with great lacing s-hoppy and sweet with a slight hint of malt t-opens hoppy with strong roasted middle and finishes very subtly with banana m- very gentle on the tongue , i let it sit for a second to release flavors on to pallet d-excellent value . i would gladly pay the 3 bucks again for this bomber ... very nice  glorious cloudy flame colored body suffused with gamboge highlights and capped by a humongous tower of old lace merengue which recedes to a lasting multi-tiered souffle of creamy bubbles . lacing scatters all over the sides of the glass like a pollock painting .  m - has a light mouthfeel , with an average amount of carbonation .

smell , belgian beer smell , sweet , flowery , alcohol taste , interesting mix between belgian triple , and german lager , there is a sweet malt component and also a mild pepper flavor in the finish . very interesting , not quite like anything i 've previously tasted . overall , very drinkable and interesting brew .  appearance- deep golden in color , if not approaching a light amber color . head becomes quite large upon pour ... one inch plus very easily . large bubbled , frothy , lightly creamy looking . lacing is exceptional with chunks , streaks and spotting all over the glass .  watery coffee . some chocolate , a little dusty .

smell - malty , chocolate . i had to swirl the beer in the glass a few times to get a good smell . it seems to be lacking in the aroma department .  appearance : a creamy mocha crown acts as a barrier between the air and the absolute darkness of this beer .  i would like to add that some reviews have compared sweetgrass to a west coast ipa ... very misleading . the malt bill on this brew is fairly complex ( idaho 2-row , german vienna , caraamber , belgian caravvienne ) as is the hop bill ( ukg , willamette , galena , amarillo , czech saaz , cascade ) . however , the ibu 's , hop flavor and aroma are not really agressive enough to hit the west coast style expectations . but i think this is a nice `` session '' style beer at 5.5 % ( 1.062 og ) . maybe east coast style yeast ?

smell is interesting , almost a bitterness like citrus smell but none of that came through in the taste .  there are 2 fingers of off-white head that slowly dissolve into chunky bubbles . good lacing rings on the glass with each sip . probably the best head i have seen on any sierra nevada beer .  very interesting beer , first wiff is on a grassy pine hop , yet it is more a citrus hop taste to the tongue ? pours a orangish hazey color with a white head . enjoyed the flavors , a very unique brew ... would recomend to anyone who likes a differntly hopped beer .

smell : faint chocolate , spice and alcohol .  '' pours with a very substantial head , nearly out of control , enormous and sticky . dense yellow-white bubbles surge and froth , pillowing into a crowning mesa . rather auburn in color ; when held to light shimmers an electric bronze and metallic apricot , with streamers everywhere racing to the lip of the glass . stunning !  i can not begin to describe how completely vile and repulsive i found this beer . the aroma alone was enough to make me wretch ... i did n't vomit , but i could have , and the flavor just brought me closer . however , that said , i do understand that this is a big thing in the midwest ( they used to mix their own ! i ca n't even say it 's to style . well made , well yes , i guess . sorry a-b , i ca n't do any better .

pours a light amber/red color with little head nor lacing - very attractive when poured . this beer is one of the cheapest enjoyable beers i 've found in my beer drinkings . i would highly recommend this beer for an evening of beer drinking .  pours a deep , burnt orange , with a creamy khaki colored head . head is huge , foamy , slow to receded , and leaves lots of lacing in its wake . love the way this one looks .  a bit too light in mouthfeel .

s : moderate notes of roasted grains and sweet malt . i also get a touch of fruit although i 'm not sure which one . berries maybe . t : a great balance between sweet malts and a touch of bittering hops . carbonation starts off a bit too spritzy and distracting but mellows out over time .  anderson valley poleeko gold on-tap at world of beer coconut creek , fl a- best head i 've ever seen on a beer . golden hazy color gradient in pint glass , white head 1.25 '' . m- wow , so creamy a smooth with the great head medium-to-light body ale . d- very drinkable and only 5.5 % abv i really could have had a couple more that night .  pours well , very little head on it and carbonation . a very dark ale , i guess i was expecting something a little more malty but i ca n't really complain about this beer .

pretty mild all around in the aroma department .  comes out a khaki-orangish color with a small head , lots of lacings , and tons of visible carbonation . i have to say this is one of the best looking beers i 've ever seen . it was gorgeous in the glass .  the mouthfeel is okay , but not the highlight of this beer .

earthy malt nose , some spicy alcohol .  appearance is absolutely beautiful with a clear radiant amber .  m : thinner and not as heavy as i would have assumed from the appearance and smell , still leaning toward a medium feel however . very pleasant . d : the thinner than expected mouth feel and very smooth taste make this a very session-able porter .

s - the smell is pretty faint and i could only pick up hints of caramel and a sort of malty tone .  driftwood farmhand pours a clear deep gold with a nice fluffy head that lingers .  m : gently creamy carbonation , perhaps a little thin overall .

aroma is quite mild roasted grainy malt .  very refreshing sweet porter with a hint of vanilla a- dark garnet red , almost completely opaque . beautiful creamy 3 inch head that leaves great lacing s- not much smell but do get a vanilla and roasted caramel malts t- taste is great .  `` bobby bob beer , best beer in vietnam . '' there is a whole lot of something going on with the aromas in this beer , but i 'll be damned if i could tell you what in the hell they were . it reminded me of walking into high school biology class on the first day , and being greeted by the smell of old formaldehyde from the specimen jars ( yes , i too dissected a fetal pig ) . formaldhyde nose , formaldehyde finish , and very little going on in between .
the smell is all alcohol ... not all that inviting .  nice tan head with superb lacing all the way down the glass .  if it tastes like paint thinner , do not drink .

grass and hay lead the nose , but it is a subdued aroma .  a - a beautiful beer . retention is great with the head lasting upwards of a few minutes leaving spectacular , webby lacing behind .  it 's thinner than i like , particularly for an oatmeal stout .

enjoyed at cellar temp . poured a gold color with 1-finger white head . aroma was mild at first , as i could n't get much of anything right away . but as i drank it and made room in the glass , i was able to swirl more and it smelled better and better the closer to the end . vanilla and oak came to mind , along with some heat . it takes like a pilsner , but with the flavor amped up , some heat , and some nice earthy , wood notes .  poured out the bottle this beer displays an attractive head of foam that takes awhile to settle out .  mouthfeel is alright .

smell - somewhat thin on the nose , but i smell some brown sugar and raisins/figs prominently . taste - figs/apples jump out at you , with a slightly sour note , and brown sugar and cinnamon are there as well .  very dark , purplish red . some nice , light pink lacing , relatively consistent .  mouthfeel is light for the beer type .

i did n't really pick up much of an aroma from this beer . the aroma i did get was mildly malty and sweet . i thought the taste was rather one dimensional but extremely delicious . it showcased sweet malt and nutty flavors followed by a slight hop bitterness to round things out .  lovely true red colouring and a pure white nitro head that is amazingly tight , creamy and resilient .  this beer is n't setting any records or braking any molds but it has been around for a long time and it pretty much sums up the catagory it belongs in . it is a golden american lager , crisp , clean , refreshing , it has more flavor than most of the others in the style ( in that style ) , and goes very well with lunch or if your in the mood for something easy drinking .

s : a clean aroma with a strong toasty/toffee presence . no hop aroma .  poured into tulips . ar : mmm , tart , cherries , green apple , light acidity/sour , light apple cider vinegar , nutty malt , earthy with brett , fruit down in intensity with time , light floral , *delicate , *caramel ap : light tan very large coarse chunky head , lace , clear light amber , rocky head , best head retention i 've seen t : brett earthiness , light vegetative , brett bitterness , tart hints , herbal spicy hop , nutty/crackery malt , fruity hints ( peach , light tropical fruit , cherry ) , long dry complex brett and hop bitter end , green apples ( light ) assertive but not aggressive , clean ( crisp ) medium caramel , woody spices m : dry lasting brett bitterness , lightly astringent , medium/high fine carbonation , *resin o : good , brett rather bitter , complex and clean , would like more sour in taste , would like it less vegetative , *darker than expected , *a strange beer , not really a full brett character , not sour , aroma and appearence are the best parts , *appearance is flawless *= ideas of fellow taster  mouthfeel : full to medium body .

what the aroma lacks , the taste & mouthfeel make up for it .  375ml bottle with best by date of 05/08/11 poured into a chimay goblet a - deep , hazy golden color , two-inch white head with awesome retention and lacing , really great looking beer s - very yeasty and bready aroma , notes of lemon citrus and white pepper , light boozy heat t - mildly sweet and spicy lemon and white pepper up front , midpalate is pretty yeasty with a sourdough bread component , more lemon and pepper on the finish with a surprisingly strong bitterness that really dries out the finish , decent amount of alcohol heat m - medium-bodied , moderate to slightly higher carbonation , well-balanced finish that is on the dry side , good amount of alcohol warming d - decent in terms of drinkability , but the alcohol is definitely more noticeable than many examples of the style i 've had , and there is a bitterness that i 've not encountered in most other tripels , overall , however , it 's not too harsh on the palate and there is a decent amount of complexity in the flavors that keep it interesting this beer 's entry into the top 100 made me realize i 'd never actually tried it .  mouthfeel was medium but the taste was very spicy , almost like a belgian wit !

i smell some coffee and some oats , that 's about it .  a mostly clear burnt sienna brown color , with off-white head that left an excellent wall of lacing .  the mouthfeel was highly carbonated , but not in a good way .

smells sweet and floral ( bit strange/unique for a `` wee heavy '' ) .  a- served in a chimay glass . d- overall , chimay white is a solid tripel that is worth trying .  average finish length , moderate sweetness . full , sticky , alcoholic body , rather astringent as well .

mild , soft , tight hop aroma of mild citrus , fresh grass and sweet fruit . pale malt in there too . nothing exceptional here , but decent complexity and good flavors make an enjoyable beer .  a - beautiful orangy amber color . only a little head but it sticks around for awhile .  i would like to see more body on this one .

smell was lacking , but the taste was better , nicely dry with chocolate malt .  served in a snifter this ipa pours a grand head with staying power , wonderful laceing.appearance is of carbonated apple juice .  m : medium body , high carbonation too high , as it starts out painfully prickly before settling into a smoother frothiness .

smell : very light and subtle , with hints of toasted grain and a somewhat biscuity malt coming through .  a : clear gold body under a gorgeous inch of creamy white foam that rises well above the rim of the glass .  m- a bit on the light side for a stout but still fantastic .

smell - slight notes of barley and grains . slight hop features .  a : the beer is very dark brown ( close to near black ) in color and poured with a finger high creamy brownish gray head that has excellent retention properties and consistently left a quarter finger high head covering the surface .  mouthfeel is a little thin but overall a good beer .
s- i get some of your typical belgian yeast aroma , dark fruits .  beautiful looking beer .  d. very high , the light body and flavors would make this a great session beer .

the color was a honey gold ; the head was a solid inch to inch and a half ( depending on the pour ) ; the smell was mediocre ; but the taste was outstanding .  perfect appearance , very inviting huge tan , rocky , mountainous head leaves incredibly chunky lacing .  a faint taste is present ( maybe honey ? ) . it is for all intensive purposes an average beer with a pleasant cherry taste . mainly because i think it will fill a good void of giving me the drink i need when i am not in the mood for a stronger beer .

poured more of a deep brown than black , when held up to the light light it did show thru the whole glass , a thinner light mocha colored head atop.aromas were very light wich suprised me a little , a bit of iron and chocolate mainly.the moufeel was execellent though , full and creamy almost like a marshmellow in my mind.full on chocolate on the palate with a tinge of earth , the alcohol is well hidden , the creamy feel and well hidden alcohol makes for a very easy drinker.a very nice `` bigger '' stout , it lacks a little but is nice to drink .  appearance - generous pour into a pint glass produced half a glass of long lasting foam . beer is a beautiful copper color .  looks more like a macro lager than a pale . head fades down to a soapy layer . slightly hoppy , watery smell with a bit of sweet-fruityness in the background . tastes slightly hoppy with a sourness mixed in all the way through . bit of fruity sweetness cloyingly there . really does n't taste anything like a pale ale .

this beer is definitely overrated , but out of all the overhyped mass-market beers available , it is one of the few that deserves its popularity . the aroma was ... well there was no aroma , sorry . as it warmed up ( and my tongue adjusted i guess ) impressive bits of roastiness floated through and i really enjoyed it . an average stout is better than no stout at all right ?  phenomenal retention and a bunch sticky lace .  pretty thin feel .

not a very strong aroma which is surprising . a faint coffee with a little roasted grain .  wow , an amber ale that is precisely amber in color . add a rogue-esque , creamy , off-white head with legs and you have a very pretty beer .  mouthfeel is good if a bit thin and that may be one of the beers few shortcomings .

nice ring of lacing left at the peak of the pour . smell - a little bit of hops and espresso , but more of a sweet caramel malt in the nose . fair amount of chocolate as well .  pours pitch black like a stout . a solid pour yeilds a finger and a half darker khaki head . still a half a finger head hanging around after 2 minutes , and the glass is covered in foam where the reas of the head used to be .  recommended by shady at the waterhuis in ghent , thanks . appearance was chestnut brown with a medium tan head and slight lacing . smell was of freshly cut hay and light spice . taste was hoppier than most browns , a good balance of bitter and sweet . very good choice , quite enjoyable and unique .

it seemed like the perfect day for a deep , smoky rich beer , instead of a porter , as i had some great lamb meatloaf awaiting me . instead , a bright coppery pour to dark honey lager looking 0.5l stein came my way with a fluffy white 1 finger head on board . i thought that the aroma would be smoky as well , but only in a subtle `` if you were looking for it , you 'd notice it '' kind of way . likewise with the flavor ; only a subtle smokiness that rounded off the malt flavors in this exceptional near dunkel lager . fresh , crisp and a bit bubbly to the mouth , this is one you could drink & drink & drink ... and watch your smile grow .  if you like a big thick beer ... well it looks as good as it gets s this smells like a huge double ipa .  little carbination and just lightweight in the mouthfeel department .

s - some malts , raisin and dark chocolate .  a : a deep brown-red color . absolutely crystal clear with a nice light tan fluffy head .  m thin , light , somewhat watery with decent carbonation especially at the front and sides .

aromas are too obviously alcoholic , with sweet toffee-like malts and faintly floral hops ( not nearly hoppy enough ! ) failing to enter the foreground . overall , i love it .  cloudy yellow-gold with an awesome initial head . huge and rocky with excellent retention and patchy lacing .  m - goes down as easy as any ipa would .

aroma is dry wheat malt , very raw .  appearance beautiful dark brown and thick with a large , tan , foamy head that went down slowly and covered the inside of my glass .  carbonation seems high for an ipa but head and lacing are a bit below average . at first sip it is a refreshing / light to medium pilsner body that encourages you to gulp a little more confidently untill a few mouthfuls later you are in a caught up in the aroma all the while never minding it . this is a classy beer and makes one feel classy .

nose is of a non-descript yeasty / wheaty variety , i mean , it 's there unlike cheap beers , but it does n't exactly leap out of the glass at you either . the appearance and smells really offer no hint to the treat that is hidden in the flavour and mouth .  appearance has a dark golden amber head with a generous head .  smell : big cloying sweetness not appealing at all . taste : bit of smooth crispness , cloying sweetness gets to be a bit unbearable . hops are minimal and the sweetness tastes fake . lame maltiness sweetness all over the place .

smells metallic and slightly roasted with fig molasses . decent smells .  perhaps the thickest , darkest beer ive ever had the pleasure of sampling ; pours an oily , opaque black with a rich brown head that eventually reduces to a heavy , sprawling lace .  mouthfeel : lots of carbonation , feels light and airy .
s : a small hint of malty , sweet flavor . t : great taste .  pours a beautiful copper with very active carbonation in my sam adams sensory glass .  mouthfeel is mild with little carbonation .

a - reddish brown color with about a 1 finger head s - ca n't really detect anything in the smell , which was weird because of the taste t - absolute taste explosion . so many tastes going on at once . great combo of wheat , caramel , and malts .  pours a very cloudy yellow , huge white head that sticks around and sticks to the glass on the way down .  i saw that it was a kenyan lager and i almost did n't even want to try it . being the ticker that i am , i gave it a shot , and this is exactly why we do n't judge a beer by its location ... appearance nothing to note ... aroma is light and sweet , corn , but you 'd expect tons of skunk and none is present ... the aroma is light and sweet , not at all a typical lager . this is n't a great beer but it exceeds expectations for a lager and a kenyan beer .

aroma is fairly mild but some chalky cocoa comes through mixed with a bit of roasted malt and some brown sugar . flavor is similar to nose , with some chocolate and a bit of roasted malt .  enchanting ruby in color with a firm , well-densed head of light mocha that shows spotty lacing .  ~can easily pick out the port-i-ness , this is a wonderfully complex beer . ~feels a bit too tingly , and is distracting .

the stuff looked like it was dying to be consumed , so i did the only right thing ... the smell is pretty bland , not a whole lot to report here , other than maybe a little bit of soggy grains . nondescript , but certainly nothing offensive either , so this will just get the old so-so 3-rating . cask-like , even , in its silkiness . a must-try if you ever get to this place and want to try an ultra-fresh example of an authentic german pils .  super interesting . dark black with a huge thick , creamy head that last forever bevore fading to a creamy floating film . awesome foam walls of lace the aroma contains faint dark raisins and prunes with hints of vanilla .  m - the feel is dry but not too dry . i think the feel in this brew may have been an accident . there 's allot of carbonation making for a coarse texture , which seems to be contradictory compared to most other dry feeling beers i 've had .

smell : clean , not too powerful , not much else .  poured from a bomber into a duvel tulip a- pours a dark , clear shade of amber with a solid offwhite head that sticks around for awhile and leaves some excellent lacing . looks gorgeous .  mouthfeel : medium mouthfeel is okay .

a grossly underrated beer . genny cream ale is a former world beer cup gold medalist for good reason . a golden pour into a frosty pint glass , the taste is clean with a sweet finish . good carbonation , good mouth feel , great drinkability . i 'd recommend this beer to anyone on a cold winter evening or a hot summer afternoon .  pours a golden amber with lacing that really looks like lace , nice and thick , and the head retention is stellar . it 's very clean and clear looking .  m : aftertaste is rather short . body is light .

( s ) - subdued roasted malts with strong raisin and molasses . ( t ) - nice layering to it : sweet , roasted , and slightly bitter malts only at different moments .  nitro bottle which was `` extra cold '' as instructed on the label was poured into a pint glass and yielded a enormous dense tan head that persisted for several minutes .  a little thin .

1 uk pint , pulled from the tap apperance- pleasantly surprised at the deep amber color of this bitter . smell- nothing special enough to note off the top of the glass taste- quite a well rounded bitter , starts off light but builds in your mouth as you drink it . mouthfeel- full enough body on the brew to tell its in your throat , but not too much to make you think you 're drinking milk .  pours a rich amber color with an impressive white head .  taste starts out quite yeasty , the other flavors eventually develop where you can pick out a bit of orange and clove , carbonation is quite assertive and sharp at first , the alcohol might have something to do with that since it 's not overly well hidden .

head was about of an inch that dissipates quickly in an off white color with little lacing smell : dry malts over all thought very laid back . a lot more mute than i thought it would be . although this sounds weird towards the end i have the feeling of the smell of autumn personified into a taste in my mouth .  a perfect creamy head rides atop this amber brew .  mouthfeel is nice and oily , but too much lingering carbonation adds an almost acidic feeling on the tongue .

s - cough syrup & dark chocolate . t - chocolate flavors with a sweet coffee note .  eliot ness pours with a beautiful two finger thick head that dissipates quickly , but has delicate lacing that sticks to the glass all the way through . the body is dark golden amber and is cleanly filtered for a truly clear presentation .  m : it was thin with lots of natural carbonation . a bit weak .

smell is damp with rich but distant foam of raisin . droopy lacing follows but the parachuters keep coming long as i can manage to contain myself .  750 ml bottle with a bbd of march 07 pours straw colored with a slight chill haze & super fluffy 2 fingers+ white head .  mouthfeel is a bit dissapointing because of the flavor leaving the palate all at once .

an excellent version of a czech pils . why is this beer able to travel so well overseas but urquell is n't ? this beer is endlessly drinkable . slight herbal notes , faint citrus as well , and , more importantly , completely satisfying when you are just looking for a beer to quaff without having to think too hard .  very impressive pour ... dark brown with a huge tan foamy head that leaves a bunch of lacing around the glass .  flavor takes it 's initial shape with the same wonderful attributes , but seems lacking in malt richness , and comes off a little thin .

s : not much goin on here . oily hops and a bit sweet .  huge head that 's pale white and gets really good and lumpy looking thick and frothy . the color is a darker straw color .  feels well carbonated , possibly a bit too much to enjoy the complexity .

smell the aroma is very muffled , even after warming . i can pick up a solid malt base though with maybe a bit of yeast to it . theres also some sherry and dark fruits , most notably figs . this ale is a lot bigger at the tongue than it is at the nose . theres a warming alcohol flavor to go along with the huge sugars . otherwise , this felt good . drinkability this is definitely 9 ounces of sipping ale .  it at first appears dark walnut but gives to me what is an extreme red . the head is surprisingly a very faint light tan , about three fingers , with some good retention and some decent initial lacing . really impressed by the color of the body on this beer . the beer looks great though .  the light body is not intimidating , however makes up for flavor and aroma . the taste is smooth , dry , and nutty . this is a decent brew .

s : aromas were very subtle . citrusy hops with faint malts and fruitiness ( dark ? nothing challenging here , but a great session beer .  on-tap at beachwood ii , a : pours black with a creamy full yellow-tan head , thick lace .  m - medium in body , but on the somewhat lighter side . creamy and smooth though . little to no carbonation .

slightly metallic . t - buttery toffee . the rich malty nose was enticing except for the dreaded metallic notes .  so lets start with saying i am not a huge porter fan ... we got the sampler at the stockton bj 's and we were really excited for the brown ... turns out we ordered the pitcher of the porter after the sampler ... . pours thick and heavy with med to large head .  light bodied , a lot of carbonation , no real aftertaste .

s : the first thing that struck me from this beer was actually a skunk ( as in the animal ) smell . otherwise , wheat , lemongrass and a tad of hay . t : no skunk in taste , otherwise it 's very similar to the nose . there 's a really nice and interesting rotted-wood funk character to the taste that i find remarkably enjoyable . really awesome flavors running around this for a saison . does the beer just fine . o : pretty excellent saison . i 'll be seeking out more fantome after this .  a-pours a viscous opaque black liquid with a dense dark tan colored head and good retention with an extremely thick lace .  m : light carbonation foaming on your mouth , medium body .

leaves a nice amount of bubbly lacing s : smells very slightly of hops with a slight spice note and possible pine notes t : nice hop notes as well as a great depth of spices m : nice carbonation tingle and honestly warms the mouth and body in the most wonderful way straight from the first drink .  champagne-like in appearance , clear gold and effervescent , with a billowy , perfectly white head .  i had this beer 1st on draft and then found it in a bottle at ht . i ca n't understand anyone grading this beer below an a the smell and the taste is just threw the roof . i have already hooked 4 other people on this beer . one of the few beers that i have had on tap and then found in a bottle that was even close to its draft flavor . this has become my new favorite . the only issue so far is i ca n't drink less than 3 of these in a session and this is truley a session beer

s : a clean and crisp aroma of pilsner malts , lemon , grains , and grassy hops . simple and straight forward , but kind of reminds me of bmcs .  poures almost black with a nice creamy head .  fine pour , average beer carbonation , small head . tastes like a weak wheat beer with intense cherry flavor that exactly matches the aroma . smooth , even flavor through the finish with aftertaste of cherry .

acetone at back end , volatile . so much better in tastes .  a - big white foam that has great retention , splotchy lace , and eventually settles to a thick cap .  smell was average , mouthfeel a bit on the thin side .

very grainy aroma with sweet malts . overall the aroma is not by any means off-putting .  appearance : beautiful golden color with a nice head and somewhat translucent .  i was pleasantly surprised with the smooth taste and more important .. the aftertaste . also , i liked the size of the bottle and the appearance of the label . my hat is off to the polish on this one . this beer deserves american translation about the brewery and other bottle infomation .

nose is crisp , with definite british hops and somewhat soapy . i could drink a ton o this stuff ... fantastic beer .  i think this beer tastes great , but the thing that impresses me most is the head . it looks less like it belongs on a beer than on a gourmet cupcake . it is beautiful , sticky , and the color of coffee butter creme . as i drink it , it leaves loads of lacing the whole way down .  mouthfeel was watery like cola . a little thicker , and this beer could be top notch by critics standards .

clear amber with red highlights with thin tan fluffy head . sweet lager malt and floral hop with malt finishes . sharp feel up front but smooth with light fuzz . a good fairly subtle amber to drink a few of . hoppy finish increases but not considerably .  this beer pours a brown so dark , it looks black until held up to bright light . the brown head fades slowly , leaving a nice lacing .  mouthfeel was light to medium in body and watery in texture with a lively carbonation .

not much smell but a little malt . tastes of smooth malt . extremely drinkable . i would love to see this on cask .  beautiful deep amber color and nice foamy head .  the hops come through strong on the first taste with the caramel malt and spices lingering for a crisp almost bitter finish . a rather nice offering from rogue but not as outstanding as some of their other brews .

the nose is a little weak but detectable are belgian yeast , malt and candied sweetness .  serving glass : poured from bottle into tulip . appearance : extremely dark ruby with massive , billowing tan head that leaves bubbles sticking to everything it touches .  the palate is medium bodied with an earthy malt character that is subdued by the by the fairly strong but not overpowering hops .

subtle vanillas and chocolate malt in the nose .  a- holy head , i 'd say about three inches of the top of my tulip is an off white head . the actual beer is a beautiful clear red hue . head is frothy an sticks around quite awhile , excellent thick ( ! ) lacing as well . i enjoy the looks of this beer immensely .  i poured this beer into my tumbler at 50 degrees then poured it out of my tumbler and into the sink . the bber was a light mahoganny color with a light orangy looking head . the smell was of sour something with a bit of a caralally smell . the taste was sour gross sour yuk ... too me . the sourness was just overpowering of rotten fruit and bout gagged me . i will not buy again .

on cask at nerax nice amber with an off white head . fruity and grainy malts add sweetness est kemp hops flow to add the `` best '' bitter . a very nice brew on cask . certainly worth a sample .  nice chunky head leaving equally impressive lacing .  the palate is perhaps a little too light and carbonated , but perhaps anything heavier could have made this cloying , so i 'll give it a pass .

smell : i could hardly smell this beer . but what i could smell was some dark malts , belgium yeast and caramel . some other things i could n't put my fingers on . some spice and some alcohol . overall : i was really excited for this beer but when i opened and poured my first glass i was a little turned off by lack of its scent . it also took a few sips to get into ... the more i had the more i began noticing its complexity . i 'm definitely going to purchase more jolly pumpkin products .  leaves one finger of tan colored head that has excellent retention , but not much lacing . looks great .  m : crisp , sticky , not that dry , medium bodied . d : a good tasting beer , but too big of a body that does n't really fit the style .

smell is super hoppy and very astringent , almost ammonia-like . while i enjoy very hoppy beers , this was just too overpowering . while my initial reaction to appearance and smell was somewhat disturbing , this beer 's flavor more than makes up for these other shortfalls .  i still get a kick out of what oskar blues is doing - a big tasty ris in a silver can . a - rich dark black color with a dark brown head which lasts almost the full glass .  this was another beer that i tried at a trade show . a nice head formed on the beer and it lasted through my drinking of it . it had a bit of a strong taste but not overpowering . it did n't have a pronounced hops/wheat/barley flavor , just a nice combination of them all . i do prefer the brewery 's 90 minute ipa more so , but this pulled a close second .

nose ... very subdued , some maltiness and a hint of sweetness , the slightest hint of some euro hop as well .  i love the fact you can go to trader joe 's and do a mixed 6pk and get some beers that you would not normally try . i pick up this beer because i am a huge fan of stouts . this is yet another good beer at a really really good price .  body is a touch too thin .

incredible beer . s - i do average on every beer . t - pure bliss . wheat and citrus with a smooth feeling . m - pure , not bitter , very over powering .  pours beautifully from the nitro-can , dark with a large cascading foamy head .  body is also average for most ales , a little light for a scottish ale .

smell ; not too impressed here , just average , a little more floral hops than other pils but a little more bitter spice would be nice .  a - a nice cloudy orange/amber body with nice carbonation streaming up the sides of the glass forming a fluffy , thick , off-white head that clings to the glass nicely , leaving nice lacing as it goes . towards the end the lacing is gorgeous and there is a half finger of head left with an ice cream scoop in the middle .  feels average in the mouth . nice carbonation .

it smells of sulphur ( molases , maybe ) , with a bit of raisins in the background .  gorgeous looking beer , pale golden color with a massive white head , and lots of bubbles .  i had this beer at the alaskan bush company . i also had it on tap at a local pub . great pour creamy head , roasty nose , i could not compare to anything , miller lite was about the only othe beer they had to offer . overall very drinkable is it available in the mid west ? ?

little bit of spice and fruity sweetness as well as a mild yeast note . overall very subtle t-flavor in this is really complex and very good . nice subtle hop flavor that blends extremly well with the malt and alcohol .  gives a big head ; off white and tightly knit with some frothage up top . dark brown in color with deep ruby coming through when held to a bright light . a nice quarter inch layer of retention and thick trails of lace .  m - a little thin in body , but a decent sweet , and cloying flavor .

the aroma was quite muted . i could detect some malt and maybe some nondistict hops , but that might be my imagination .  spectacular appearance : light hazy golden color , plenty of streaming bubbles .  it has a plain mouthfeel , but it is smooth and delectable .

wow , is what i can say about this beer from long island ? good body , a nice color , drinkable , and a nice hoppy finish . its good with food , good with friends , and good to drink alone !  came to the table with a good two inch creamy tan head and some nice lacing , the color was a nice ruby brown .  reviewed 4/15/2006 ( 12oz bottle bottled on 02/03/06 ) : pours an amber golden color body , very fizzy . has a huge head , white , good lacing , slowly diminishing . a very hoppy aroma , pale , and dry . bitter taste , semi-sweet aftertaste , semi-pale , semi-bitter . good balanced taste .

smells of sweet malt , a little oxidation , nothing outstanding , but ok. tastes sweet , malty , barely noticeable bitterness .  the beer pours dark , really really dark . the head of the beer was a creamy brown and very frothy like a stout should be .  light to medium mouth feel . tastes great.full flavor , with a little bite . for a dark beer it 's refreshing .

sm- acrid burnt malt with a bit of heat .  appearance - pours a bubbly , active tangerine color , a creamy thick finger of soft white , orange tinted foam on top . thick walls of lace are glued to the sides .  mouthfeel : nice mouth-coating , but a much weaker carbonation than i was expecting ( the tap ? ) .

s : mild with no sulfur odor that so many lagers seem to have . not a great smell but yet not anything memorable or objectionable either . kudos for that and bring on the hops ! d : great .  12fl oz bottle poured into my tulip pours a vibrant ruby like color with a three inch off-white head . nice layers of lacing cling to the sides of my glass .  m : a medium/full body with a very light , almost absent carbonation .

brought back from munich in a 500ml glass and cellared about 4 months ( so not too long ) , then poured into a pilsner . the beer was a very fine dark reddish brown ... quite enticing . s : try as i might , i had a lot of trouble bringing out the aromas with this particular bottle . perhaps it was due to my having brought it back from munich and aged it , as the first one i had , back in germany , had more of an aroma to it . regardless , it was somewhat sweet and malty , with a bit of caramel and dried fruits , perhaps raisin ... t : so damn smooth . very balanced all around , although admittedly i 've aged this awhile , perhaps contributing to the smooth taste and nice balance . d : superbly drinkable , with the balance and smooth quality .  burgundy color , with a full and creamy foam that lasts .  a robust stout - on the bitter side but just right . mouthfeel : spicy carbonation on the tongue - slick , but otherwise a little watery . maybe a little too carbonated - it overwhelms everything else with a nice big drink , but it more manageable when the beer is sipped .

aroma contains raisin with some grape and warm dark breads . raisin and grape hit first . this gives way as some roastiness takes over .  pours a super cloudy gold , full of huge ass chunks . big rocky white head , looking multigrain by all the big brown chunks suspended in it , but the most amazing lace i 've ever seen , i have pictures to prove it .  coffee dominates the taste but its bitter and boring , just not feeling the flavor ... the mouthfeel is almost an afterthought because its so light and boring .

the aromas were not very exciting . some maltiness w/ caramel and toffee aromas . the flavor was great .  pours a two finger lacy head over a brilliant ambered golden liquid .  this was the best north american beer i 've ever had from a can . while it ca n't touch a holsten festbock , it was a very nice brown ale and offered something that others do n't . it was almost buttery once you tasted the sour/ grain notes . very complex , and very tasty . worth a try , any time .

s -- i smell corn , alcohol , a little hops , and not much else .  poured into a red wine glass . a perfect thick fluffy head and rich dark brown body .  the mouthfeel is light and carbonation is moderate .

smell : buttery malt with grapefruit and other citrus/fruit , but there 's also a strong soapy aroma that takes a lot away .  this ale pours a striking walnut brown with a light tan head . the head is full of carbonation and clings to the sides of the glass leaving a nice lace pattern .  pours clear , copper with medium-dense head of beige bubbles . little lacing . hoppy , full-bodied flavor , but not floral . some sweet maltiness . my only qualm is with a bit of a sharp bite and some cereal flavor . similar to their pale ale in taste , but much more robust and flavorful .

creamy looking concoction , low head , but rises a fair amount with agitation . smell was low , noticable , but low . rich and buttery taste , with pastry notes abound , and 'nougat ' flavors just like the discription suggests . a great american strong ale , especially for it 's availability .  a -- black as death . milk chocolate head of about 3/4 inch fades to an appealing pond scum .  mouf & gt ; seltzery . not fab .

s- the first thing i thought when i smelled this was that the smell reminds me of red wine . i 'm not sure where this came from , and after a few more smells that idea left my head . i get lots of roasted malts , coffee and chocolate , and a light hoppy bitterness . smells boozier than 7.2 % abv . t- tastes very much like it smells . roasted malts , coffee and chocolate .  pours a three finger cream head that fades slowly to a thin layer leaving a good lace . crystal clear , deep amber color .  mouth is lacking in carbination expected . also a little thinner in the mouth than expected .

brooklyn summer ale ... i love the light , refreshing taste of this beer ! golden color , light on hops , light on malt ... light body and bready taste . light crisp bitterness and a citrusy/floral aroama !  nitro-can , a : pours a very dark brown , black from a distance , with a thick , very creamy head , which leaves gobs of lacing and has great retention .  i love good double ipa 's . however this one was a huge dissapointment . beer was very cloudy , i thought they gave me a german style hefeweiss it was so bad . hops were present but were lacking for a double ipa . the beer was really out of balance , big bitterness but no flavor to back it up .

very muted aroma ... not sure if i got an off-bottle , because i remember liking the smell of cold trail quite a bit . { edit : just noticed i rated the on-tap version exactly the same for the `` big three '' of appearance , taste , and aroma . nice . }  12oz , bottled on april 04 2011 poured into a tulip , decanted . appears bright golden yellow , effervescent , great clarity . large white head with good retention and lacing .  mouthfeel is just average , the carbonation is much too low for a tripel .

it had a nice scent of malt and clover .  a : light orange color , slightly hazy , one finger off-white head with killer retention time , excellent lacing .  mouthfeel was a bit of a letdown- on the thin side and made the beer seem less substantial .

lightish orange color with a green tint , which hints to the density of hops that likely go into this brew . suprisingly mild aroma . it 's all quite inoffensive .  light bronze with a full , lasting foam .  great looking beer . looks like carbonated orange juice or maybe a mimosa . beers do n't look much better than this . fresh squeezed grapefruit , peach , flint , light lemon and apricot . nice hop forward dipa here . major flaw is in the finish where the hop bitterness gets a little astringent and out of whack leaving a chalky , filmy residue on the palate . again the bread driven malts show some toffee notes in the middle are balanced by high alpha hops leaving a resiny citrus burst throughout . grapefruit and lemon , with some hints of orange , peach , pineapple , and other fruity flavors . if not for the finish this would have been spectacular .

appearence : it pours a nice dark brown with a rich , creamy , well sustained beige head , smell : the smell is of pale malts mixed with a tiny bit of bitterness . nothing too complex or anything .  a : beautiful golden color . the head pours huge ( 3 fingers ) and fluffy . quickly falls to a ring around the edges .  mouthfeel - average weight , above average bubbles .

very dry nose with subtle coffee but not much else .  pours a beautiful honey-brown color , although as the cascade settles the body now appears a deep , seductive orange . lots of bubbles cling to the inside of the glass , too , giving it a hazy , stained-glass look . retention is , of course , out of this world . gorgeous .  it has some zesty lemon/lime , a bit of grain , and some mineral water . it has a lot of flavor , though it is a bit blunt . it is supremely drinkable .

s. smell is not very strong here , very surprising . alcohol and notes of barley .  a : pours a dark amber and crystal clear with a cream colored head that stays for a pretty good amount of time .  served from a 2 liter flip top bottle bought at the brewery , poured into a pint glass bought from the brewery . light amber color in glass , hazy finish . big head that dissipated quickly , little lacing on glass . light aroma of citrus on pour . went down quickly , i was surprised how fast i finished the first pint . a typical wheat , but a good pint none the less .

after 3 attempts to seize the aroma of this brew , i came up with a blank each time . hell , maybe i was a bit stuffed up that day , but usually the sniffer is pretty good . either way , i prefer to drink a beer through my mouth . wow ... hops !  12oz bottle poured into the sa glass a - light amber in color , extremely high level of carbonation . thin , tall bright white head with tremendous retention . opaque but not cloudy .  the alcohol starts to peep through on the finish but is in check m : the body on the finish is a little thin for my liking but the carbonation is pleasant and tingling d : this is very very drinkable for the abv

it smelled hoppy and shad a slight hint of citrus.taste was a nice'n ' hoppy .  it has that beautiful guinness cascade and the lovely thick nitro tan head that is a rock solid 1 thick . the beer itself appears black as night but is actually very , very , very dark brown . when i first started drinking guinness in the standard bottles many years ago , it had a yeasty sludge in the bottom of the bottle and appeared to be bottle fermented and carbonated a completely different drink .  there was some even carbonation in the mouthfeel , and a slight aftertaste , but the beer was fairly typical in this regard .

it has a slighty sweet/malty aroma , but nothing very strong . a very nice pils , indeed .  a good looking beer for sure .  poured this from a bottle into a standard pint glass . noticed citric tasting hops over the pale malt . i would say this leans slightly more to an ipa , just slightly . i really enjoyed this and would buy it again .

the aroma is dry and earthy with some light , fruity malt .  pours beautifully ... similar to a guiness with bubbles that raise to a creamy head . wow this beer was a huge disappointment from the pour .  m : relatively average mouthfeel , with nice carbonation .

the nose is mostly very dull although there are hints of sweet molasses and roasted malts .  batch 006x1 a- pours a deep ruby red color with about a 1 finger cream colored head that stays for a ridiculous amount of time after the initial pour , never going below about half a finger . fantastic lacing on this one as well .  mouthfeel was disappointingly a bit too thin and watery in the finish for such a big beer .

s : smells faintly of caramel and hops . not too strong . t : caramel , toffee , tinge of hops , malt , little bit of grain .  i think this is one of the most gorgeous looking beers .  mouthfeel : light-bodied , slightly oily and a little watery .

medium carbonation and medium-heavy bodied . slight malty nose .  a : deep brown out of the bottle , black in the glass ; huge light-brown head fills half the tulip - just perfect - then recedes rockily and leaves chunks of lace . gorgeous .  truly one of the worst craft brewed beers made out there . thick , meaty , hops way too bitter , boozy , sweet . this is like a grain alcohol , hops , and pork slurry . must be what pork soda is .

good tasting beer and at the right price . schaefer beer taste good and has a nice look does anything else matter . if your looking for a good value i paid $ 13.99 for a 30 can case .  this beer had to settle for a minute before it left a 1/4 white head . impressive ! ! !  m : average for a lager -- it 's about the only thing going for this `` king of beers . '' d : incredibly low as there 's nothing bringing me back here .

slightly sweet , malty aroma with a slight nuttiness .  the pour is equally as stunning , as a cloudy , orange-amber ale fills my pint glass and produces a generous pillow of cream-colored head . truly a beautiful presentation . it looks great and has a pleasant aroma , but besides that , it is n't really on par with what i hope to taste from an ipa .  m : somewhat fizzy and a tad overcarbonated .

really not too much to the smell . it could be that i have a cold , but i 'm only getting the fruit from the hops . the taste is a bit nicer , lots of hops still , but it 's nicely balanced with toasty malt . it feels light and clean in the mouth and finishes long and crisp with a lingering hoppy orange flavor that lasted longer than i had expected .  new holland dragon 's milk pours a beautiful black with just a bit of garnet showing when held to the light . a fluffy ivory head sits on top .  body is medium full , but the carbonation is quite low .

smell is so-so , not very strong . looks very nice in a pint glass , with not much head to speak of .  appearance : huge somewhat bubbly head that 's very persistent . i 've had a good number of these dubbels and this is probably the best looking one i 've seen so far .  mouthfell was abrasive yet thin .

scent is light and consists of hints of spice and yeast .  a : jet black , large mocha colored head , reduced quickly . average lacing . this is the darkest porter i have seen .  the carbonation is a little weaker than most weissbiers ; the bubbles are small . the liquid is very smooth and a little thick . a textbook example of a hefeweissen , maybe with a slight reservation for the weak carbonation

a= copper color with a huge head that lasts for an eternity leaving great lacing along the glass s= yeasty and some toasted malt .  looks amazing . - light cocoa ... crisp hops , pine , light citrus.. grain , oats ... crisp and delicious .  m : medium to thicker body , average carbonation .

fresh roasted coffee is definitely the primary smell , although there 's no mistaking this is a beer . still , pretty much everything else is subdued .  pours a bright , crystal clear dark golden/amber with some red highlights when held to the light . has a fluffy white head and lots 'o lacing . beautiful color !  very dry , exceptionally dry , is that cotton in my mouth ?

s : there was not much of an aroma . some fresh grapefruit & some malt , but it really needed to be bigger . the flavor more than made up for what the nose lacked .  bottle : poured a dirty amber color ale with a super huge off-white foamy head with great retention and some perfect lacing .  s- nutty , maple syrup . t- i an normally a stout or porter guy but this one was really pleasant . you can taste the dark roasted malts and the hint of maple syrup which stays with the palette . m- .. d- i could drink a six-pack in one sitting only thing i would be wary of is the sweetness of the drink .

very mild aroma ; far more malty than most ipa 's . the flavor offers a huge improvement to the smell . the hop is now very pronounced .  exceptional crystal clear view with a white rocky head .  m : medium bodied with moderate carb .

s- leaves a little to be desired . some bready malts , and a little sweet caramel , but it seems like the `` volume '' got turned down on the smell . t- remarkably well-balanced . a delicious , sweet caramel / brown sugar type of malt flavor going on here . m- smooth and balanced , this is a very drinkable beer , especially at 5.9 % overall , i think this is an awesome beer . love it .  this beer pours a dense black , with only the slightest of mahogany edges when exposed to the light , and three fingers of thick , chunky khaki head , which dissipates very slowly , leaving a consistent web of pockmark lace around the glass .  quite a good flavor - bitter , but not anything too strong , with an average duration . light and thin-bodied on the palate , , with average carbonation .

extremely light-colored yellow . an awesome fruity wheat ale flavor while still managing to keep it lightly done . no overpowering attributes , just an easy drinking wheat ale .  its body is pitch black topped by an extremely creamy tan head that absolutely clings to the sides of glass . it looks almost like a glass of guinness and i wonder if it is nitro-poured or from a real ale beer engine .  carbonation is a bit excessive for me but not prohibitively so .

this lager is quite an eye opener , in the most literal sense of the phrase . aroma is minimalistic , with just a whiff of toffeeish malts and a hint of fruity hop notes .  the tan head on this stout is huge and just keeps hangin around . the body is black as expected .  the body was medium or just a bit more and lighter than expected .

the smell is a bit subdued . you get a subtle sweetness and roasted smell that come to the nose .  this beer pours out a hazy straw color with an absolutely massive amount of head !  admittedly it could have a much bigger body on it but at least it is well attenuated . a hop might have passed by the brew kettle but if it did , it didnt stay long .

dark bread , wood shavings , & murky hop resins with hints of black peppercorns & mild tobacco . t ~ malted barley lends caramel , wheat-bread , rye whiskey & black pepper .  a : a beautiful dark red amber . magnificent head with surprisingly creaminess and retention . good lacing .  some vanilla and spicy noted develop , and the hops meld nicely with the malt flavours and create a balance across the tongue . it 's a bit too intensely carbonated for my tastes , but still a nice beer .

s : it has kind of a rotten orange and medicinal smell that i 'm not digging .  a=light orange/amber with good head , lasting several minutes , leaving a amount of good sticky lacing .  whatever , it 's tasty and pretty nice to drink . overall , its smooth , but almost slightly sour porter . definitely worth a try .

bottle a-lazy hazy off gold belgian white looking . s-malty doughy t-pleasent hoppy bitter after taste . something made me think of a hefe for a moment . d- very easy to drink , lacing still apparent after drinking half of glass .  leaves a tan two finger head that has excellent retention , and leaves excellent lacing .  mouthfeel/drinkability- lightly carbonated going in , it never gets interesting enough to best highlight the hop and malt features to its potential .

s : not much going on here . pretty malty , bread-like , a little bit of hops , and perhaps some alcohol .  a great shining orb yellow body , opaque , and just glowing literraly screaming neon with an almost green florecscent hue along the edges . it looks spectacular for the style it just does n't look any better than this .  medium to thick , perhaps syrupy , though it 's tough to concentrate on the beer 's mouthfeel when it tastes like this . seems a bit under-carbed though , truthfully .

the nose was not very apparent but did offer some slight citrus notes . not overwhelming by any stretch of the imagination , it offered very clean and crisp flavors that were light in a good way .  a : dark . dark , three finger , espresso bubble colored head .  m - medium bodied but very thin and watery overall , even for a cask pull .

the aroma is surprisingly faint , even after it warmed , but there are some nice , and complex , hoppy notes , fruity , piney , lovely .  a mostly clear dark brown with mahogany highlights , this beer is capped with a ridiculously long-lasting beige head with excellent retention . quite the stunner , this , it 's been a while since i 've seen a beer with such good head retention .  m/d : a medium body , but thin and watery .

s : light , slightly metallic smelling malt , with just a touch of spicy hops and doughy yeast . t : fresh , grainy malt taste with hints of biscuit dough and lemon juice .  gorgeous black color-huge tan/cocoa head on top that seems to last in some way shape or form forever .  just a tad too bit flat and oily for me but otherwise a great beer especially at $ 5 per bomber .

a good crisp red . the red color is nice and bright . the mouthfeel is terrific and gives it a terrific drinkablility at an irish pub that you ca n't always get in a guiness . the head is about one inch and has a sweet foamy flavor that belies that rest of the the flavor profile .  this beer pours a huge head with amazing retention and a nice golden color .  the smoked malt is a bit harsh on the palette , and the beer lacks enough body to temper the rough edges in this department .

cloudy straw yellow color . a very good pale ale .  draught - mcganns pub , doolin , co. clare a black , black stout , with a darker head than the standard draught .  mouthfeel is tingly , aftertaste is of chocolate and hops .

pours color mimicking the bottle itself heavy , fluffy , connect-fourish lacing malty , soothing scent . maybe they brew this next to the cherry wheat , because it definately gives off that constant aroma . good balance of sweet , sour , & hop spice .  a : deep garnet clear body with a beautiful creamy 1 finger tan head .  mouthfeel not exceptional , some prickling from coarse carbonation .

oregon trails ipa ( i wish it had a proper name ) is driven by a biting bitter dominance from start to finish especially the finish . it has no aroma until agitated when a grassy , malty scent pokes through . this is a smart english-style bitter ale .  a : pours a magnificent deep dark brown liquid with one of the most beautiful tan heads i 've seen ! looks delicious .  the taste follows the nose , with malt followed by piney hops . the hoppy aftertaste lingers , which i 'd normally like but i find it a little off-putting in this beer . one is usually enough for me . overall , this is a solid brew that can be had on a budget , can be found everywhere in the u.s. , and is often a lifesaver at bars and restaurants where the only other choices are bmc .

an attractive beer . s- malt . touch of hops . t- taste better than smell .  old rasputin poured black , with a good sized head .  pretty much everything great about a czech beer . high drinkable , very refreshing and very crisp . you can smell and taste the hops but they are balanced nicely by the maltiness of this beer . i prefer it to urquel , but you ca n't go wrong with either .

smell is fruity , with some hops .  chef collaboration series ; pours a golden orange amber with a rich , thick and full solid white head . great looking .  this one remindes me of rich black coffie and hops mixed . this one is an almost black amber/brown brew that is big and malty . the mouthfeeal is heavy , almost like liquid bread . this one is realy good thank hevans for good bock i wish that this one was avalable all year long but i will get more in spring

not much aroma to speak of and not overly carbonated , but really fills the mouth with flavor nonetheless . excellent taste and drinkability ... sweeter than expected with a nice balance of citrus and hops .  a- deep dark rich black and slight mohohgany with a full three fingers of head s- sweet chocolate and coffee , raisons molasses and red fruit .  only complaint with this beer is it wasnt as thick in the mouth as i would have liked , but otherwise , great

s-caramel followed quickly by some rich oak and then some sharp alcohol .  i love the bottle , nice swing top , classy looking , and pours perfectly into a nonic glass a deep dark brown color , with a nice sturdy white head .  mouthfeel : light to medium , but i swallowed as quick as possible to stop the overload .

pours a clear amber brown with a one finger head that leaves spotted lacing sown the glass smell is faint but i pick up carmel and bready malt and maybe some fruit taste is all carmel malt and i love it - but it also has the signiture sa i could tell this was sa if i didnt know it which iam sure the homebrew idnt have or maybe it did since it won mouthfeel is medium to heavy body - smooth and creamy with perfect carbonation drinkability is great and even better in colder weather overall i think sa stole this homebrewers recipe and up the abv to make the imperial ?  drank at the monk , fremantle a - pors a deep mahogany colour withe two fingered off white head that left rings all the way down the glass .  i was hoping for a belgian strong ale with some woody characteristics , but i got whiskey instead . whiskey aromas , vanilla , bubblegum and spicey alcohol mix together in the aroma and is off putting . pretty much the same going on in flavor with vanilla , whiskey , and coriander-like flavors dominating . odd , oily - almost like mescal - flavors made me want to puke . i tried hard to like this since it was a gift and wanted to tell the gifter that i enjoyed it , but i did n't . someone wake me up when this whiskey barrell aging fad runs its course .

a : soft and slighty yeasty . mild phenols and a bit of citrus . t : sweet banana , balanced grassy hop bitterness , slighty spicy/peppery .  the beer poured very nicely into a pint mug : an amber brown colour with a decent off white head that displayed excellent retention and showed good lacing all the way down the glass .  decent mouthfeel despite the taste and thinness of the beer .

served at cellar temp . pours a dark copper color with an off white head-no hop aroma to speak of-taste was light in malt -i thought at first it was the cask pale .  pours a hazy , muddy amber with a monster fluffy white head that sticks around and laces the glass .  m : light , smooth , some carbonation -unassuming to the point of being boring and , frankly , not very good . mouthfeel is disappointing .

chocolate malt aroma was faint , but that was followed by a surprisingly strong malt flavor with a firm bittersweet hoppy aftertaste .  it pours a deep black color with four heaping fingers of dark tan head . there is lots and lots of belgian lace on the sides of the glass .  1 m : alright , not overly thin but could use body and texture .

faint nose , due to the nitro as well as it being served a touch on the cold side . made with real frangelico , this is heavenly . nice oatmeal stout body , with tons of sweet hazelnut flavors . just killer taste , as well as drinkability that 's out of this world . along with the bourbon barrel imperial stout , this was the best beer of the party .  pours a dark black ... very murky , with a very nice finger size creamy off white head . very creamy and sticky lacing as well .  my friends and i decided to split this beer and everyone had a different take on how awful it was . one tasted horse manure , another vomit , and another just wild animals ... and not in a good way . this is the second beer i 've ever poured out . it was so horrible we could n't finish it between four people .

s - nothing special here , typical bready/grassy aromas with some light , sweet malts . great springtime beer . narragansett continues to pump out great seasonal beers .  pours a brilliant amber color , with a smallish ecru head .  mouthfeel is a bit thin but standard for pilsners .

smell is dominated by vinegar - perhaps a little too much so . hints of sour cherries , a faint sweetness . i can relate to the comment on it reminding one of ketchup - an all too acidic , tart ketchup . worth checking out .  poured from a bottle into a chalice/goblet poured a rich thick head that actually capped over the rim of the glass in an elegant dome that disappeared rather quickly except for the dome , which is receding slowly . left a lot of lacing .  mouthfeel is smooth , but lacking something .

i was very happy to find the belgian-owned delhaize grocery store here in cologne , which stocks a few belgian beers for a very reasonable price ( this 12 oz bottle literally rang up for less than an kiosk espresso ) . the smell is not bold at all . it smells of malts and yeast with a hint of sweetness .  pours with a clear orange amber body topped by a medium thick off-white head with lots of lace .  m - low carbonation left a somewhat flat beer .

a big thumbs up for the artwork - very cool . a mild , sugar/fruit sweet brew . low alcohol , but highly drinkable ( probably wouldnt want more booze - would taste too much like duvel ) . effervescent and whimsical . i liked this brew for what it was - a simple , highly drinkable session beer . no .  appearance : a beautifully clear , effervescent pale yellow with a thick , pillowy white head . excellent head retention and lacing . a beauty .  ) the only reason the mouthfeel was a little low was because i thought this beer was slightly overcarbonated .

the aroma is light to non-existant with only light notes of hoppy and flowers there . its not bad or good , just not there . the taste is also very light , totally reminds me of a summer sessional . the taste is very pleasant thought with some light hops and wheat throughout . i would recommend this to anyone just in the mood to crush and get drunk .  deep black and thick with a hearty chocolatey looking head that doesnt want to go away .  m : its body is kind of on the thin side and somewhat watery .
