yuengling : when your standard bmc 's are n't acceptable anymore . smell was average at best . malts stick out sometimes , but that 's about it . very drinkable , would have this particular beverage over and over throughout my night .  it is certainly an attractive beer - the head is dense and the lace sticky ; the colour dark amber .  i found the texture to be a little odd as it felt a little thin on the palate , reminding me more of a porter than a stout , but i could still go through a couple pints in a sitting .

you would n't be able to tell this was a cask beer by looking at it . it has a pretty tight nose . the wine influence in the beer is fairly hidden .  12 oz bottle with freshness date 7/15/10 served in a goblet l ) beautiful frothy head that sticks around for awhile .  mouthfeel : somewhat lackluster . a little too thin in the mouth . it could actually stand a little more carbonation ( just a litle ) too .

little smell at all .  it pours a nearly impenetrable black with a big brown head that is at first billowing and frumpy and then settles into a thumb-thick layer with outstanding retention .  mouthfeel was kind of thin for the serving style .

smells sweet but subdued .  this is a beauty with a full , sticky head .  m : fairly full , mouth-filling body , but only a low amount of prickly carbonation ; it gets a little overbearing , especially for a lager .

s= not incredibly heavy . hints of citrus and malt sweetness . t= initially very crisp , eventually becoming slightly bitter again with notes of citrus . very drinkable , could hit you faster than you would think because of the 8.5 % abv .  mild aroma in a black body with an energetic head of light brown fine bubbles . near the top of the head below the beer line a continuous flow of small bubbles can be observed .  i have been known to sit and smell the beer for five minutes before i drink it . the taste is carmel with a almost pine after taste . after four beers the tart pine after taste is really noticable . i really like this beer . though sometimes they do n't taste right . i do n't know if i just have an old one or maybe it is too new and needs time to mellow .

very faint aroma overall .  poured a gorgeous , clear copper with a rich , frothy light-tan head that lasted the duration leaving a thick lattice of lacing on the glass .  i 've had 2 alpine brews thus far , ph and nelson.. time for the trifecta here ... pours a pale golden with one of the more impressive heads i 've ever seen on an ipa ... this things foams like duvel ... . gentle pour produces a 4 inch head and a steady vibrant stream of bubbles from the sa perfect pint ... citrusy and spicy hops dominate here ... not overpowering or pungent or anything but very nice ... light toasted malts are present as well ... perhaps a little yeastiness as well ... definitely hoppy but i was hoping for a touch more here ... the hops are tasty but there 's not a strong enough presence for me . spicy and herbal ... the brew is overcarbonated for my tastes and i wish that would have been toned down and i might have enjoyed this one more ... it was distracting ... not bad overall but i was n't as big of a fan of this one as some others have been ... a nice beer i guess ...

s. pleasant but nothing stands out besides some citric and floral hops and a bit of malt .  perfect looking beer in a pint glass .  m : little or no trace of carbonation . this porter is unbelievably light , considering its heavy appearance .

poured chilled in ale glass a : cloudy copper ; two-finger head ; decent carb action s : thin , light lemon ; bit of soapy smell t : well hopped , but the hops have a mild profile , making this very smooth ; bread and biscuits under a pine tree might be a good description overall , a smooth , solid ipa .  a= pours a beautiful hazy orange color . i really like hazy ipas .  m : low carbonation , could have some more body .
lots of raspberry in the smell , felt it made the aroma over powering with sweetness . felt that it was a little one dimensional .  excellent looking beer .  mouthfeel : very light and watery .

s- i 'm a little let down with the aroma . the faint nose has some grain and a touch of noble hops as well .  the beer is fantastically dark in appearance , almost as black as the background on this hallowed website .  the taste was complex , while on the lighter side for an epa , there was a strong vanilla and toffee flavor , a bit of the oak from the ageing barrel can be tasted as well . the flavor could be a bit stronger , espically for an epa , no hops or bitterness was present . overall a very intresting beer , but very good .

does n't have the overwhelming sweetness or fumes of a barley wine .  pours a thick black ; syrupy and dense . great head , coffee and cream color about an inch high .  this beer was quite good for a wheat . it has a medium-body , and on the nose is yeast and clove , as expected . tastes malty , herbal , and spicy , with an overall taste of banana which was really nice . it is minimally hoppy , and makes a very nice summer beer . i would very much buy this again .

the aroma was a little bit of a let down . far from the best in the style . what this lacks in aroma is made up for with taste . dark fruit and yesty esters makes this beer .  a medium pour produces two inches of dense white head . dear god , a half inch of foamy head is lingering . i can tell just from the look of this beer that it will be very good .  mouthfeel : this beer kind of dries out my mouth .

smell was mild , but defined . in other words , there was a handful of nice smells that were both expected and identifiable , but they were n't obscene or assertive like `` background music '' played too loudly . this was pleasant and enjoyable with its mildly spicy hops and `` gently sweet '' malt .  appearance - hazy , orange/straw color . a fluffy white head has great resilience , great stick and leaves quite a bit of lace behind . honestly , for a style i do n't enjoy as much as some others ( yet ) , this looks super in a gold rimmed stella glass .  mouthfeel is medium bodied and slightly over carbonated for my tastes .

the aroma i got was a bit soapy but there were some esters tucked away that were quite faint .  great retention and spectacular lacing . hazu and enticing . awesome .  the body is light-to-medium , with a slick texture and prickly carbonation , followed by metallic astringency .

nice scent , very sweet and malty , though , not as deep as i like in my browns .  it 's a beautiful reddish brown in color with a fluffy tan head .  this was full bodied and smooth but i felt that there was a bit to much carbonation .

s : rye bread and malt , sweetness and yeast . t : rich coffee , toffee , malt , and brown sugar .  appearance- chestnut color to a `` t '' . full creamy and smooth 1 inch dirty white head . lovely 1/3 inch remains for the endurance of the beer . patches , streaks and spots of lace cover about the entire glass .  mouthfeel : i only had a couple mouthfuls ( did n't even make it through one bottle ) , but it felt more substantial and less watery than o'douls or warsteiner .

able to pick up a good amount of hops with a deep wiff , otherwise standard . actually masking the crispness i come to expect from a lager with how smooth it is . very easy to drink , would definitely recommend it as a very good strong lager .  appearance : pours a pure white head , small bubbles , and very creamy looking , decent lacing on the glass . nice yellow hugh to the beer .  mouthfeel : light weight ; medium-high carbonation .

paid $ 7.49 for an australian longneck from bevmo in willow glen , ca . has a decorative yet functional metal fastener holding the cork down . has the color of a cloudy yellow wheat beer . the nose is yeast first and foremost , but there is also hints of alcohol and sweeter malts with some spice . yeast and bread at first ; similarities to both a hefe or wheat beer but unique in its own manner . tripels usually are not my beverage of choice , so drinkability is affected , but it the best tripel i 've had to date . highly recommended for this style .  very good looking beer .  the mouthfeel is different from what i expected . they just got ta figure out if they want their beer super carbonated or near flat .

s : aroma is medium to low in intensity . notes of vienna malt and slight roast . good from start to finish , but lacks with the aroma , even when warmed .  a - pours an absolutely stunning hazy scarlet red-maroon with big creamy off-white head . this brew is a looker ! !  mouthfeel : kind of thin and watery and just a bit too much carbonation .

mostly earthy malty scents that are hidden inside . aroma needs to be searched for to be found . happy beering .  pours a deep copper body with a thick , frothy off-white head .  complaint with this one is the mouthfeel which feels a little thin for what i want a ris to be , i want a bit more chewy - though i suppose this lighter feel aids the drinkability which is high for such a monster , just a hint of booze .

smell sweet and malty nose with a mild , citrusy , hoppy smell .  a clear , medium golden brew topped by a frothy , off-white head . foam sits at 1 '' plus for some time , and laces up the stein superbly . 4.05 look : 5 | smell : 3.5 | taste : 4 | feel : 4 | drink : 3.5 1186  mouthfeel is firm and a bit spicy with the hops , but the drinkability is awful .

it seemed a bit thicker than most porters . they seemed to add spices to cover up the poor taste of the malt . not a fan , there are better porters out there .  a crystal clear straw-colored pils that pours with a voluminous rocky head with just a touch of hop spicy aroma on top of fresh malt . i pour some of this beer and the head rapidly rises , i let it settle and pour the last third of the bottle to form a huge rocky head .  mouthfeel is slightly a little too carbonated for my tastes .

s : not a whole lot here , definitely some yeast , some fruits , white grape or apple , and some mild hop bitterness is present . some grassiness , and caramel maltiness . t : bitter upfront , definitely well balanced , as it brings out the bready maltiness as it moves over my tongue .  looks like a decent blonde to me . fantastic head retention , simply fantastic .  i enjoyed this beer very much . one of the few breweries in us to try and succeed with a belgian doubel which are complex to brew . i liked the spicy overtones and the rich character . a great cold weather brew .

hazy burnt sienna in colour with a tan small head that disappears quickly due to being brew for cask production ( i got one of the few cans they did at the brewery ) . caramel and citrus on the nose , however quite light .  poured a bubbly cloudy peach with huge white pillowy head and lots of sticky lace .  a bit lighter in the mouth than i expected .

clear , pale gold with tenacious head and gorgeous lacing , aroma leaves something to be desired , a bit sweet , although a nice pepper note presents .  the higlights of this beer are hands down its appearance and drinkability ... especially for a big ipa ... pours a crystal clear burnt orange with a constant carbonation ... gorgeous white head which laces perfectly ... as nice looking of a beer as you 'll ever get ... surprisingly you get a strong malted backbone to the nose with expected citrus and piney hops ... very delicious ipa overall with the piney hops giving a wonderful aftertaste ... the malts kind of confuse the mouthfeel of this beer , but overall a great choice ... i gave this an exceptional rating for drinkability for several reasons ... for one , the price is great ... second , the beer is balanced , high abv but not too complex for the ipa lover ... you 'll really enjoy this beer ... bought at the local harris teeter at under $ 10/six pack and drinking while watching danica patrick wreck in a nationwide race ( she sucks ... .  i looked at the label `` unique hoppy altbier '' and thought the hops were gon na rip my tongue off or something , not so . to find the truth turn the bottle around simply `` water , malt , hops '' simple things are good though . now for the taste , nice and malty in the front with a hint of hops taking over . this is a very smooth and drinkable beer . skoal !

s : sweet malts and toasted grains , with some cinnamon spice . the chocolate and chili notes are there , but faint . t : very flavorful , with big chocolate taste in the malts .  a - fantastic cascading that never ceases to tantalize me . one finger , dense-as-cream , tan head with impeccable retention and thick lacing .  soft in hop bitterness , yet very well balanced . thinnish in overall body .

smells fruity and a little malty , but with lots of co2 .  large , bubbly and frothy white head that lasts .  i found it very highly carbonatedalmost too carbonated ( prickly , carbonic qualities are a bit distracting ) .

appearance : dark brown body with a light tan head that disappears quickly , the score would have been higher but the head did not linger smell : a sweet caramel scent that linger in the nose , nothing real spectacular taste : a heavy does of the malts , but yet still well balanced , wow this is one of the better beers that i have ever .  pretty easily the best looking ipa i 've ever seen . very clear amber color with an explosive , billowy offwhite head with infinite retention and thick lacing . so inviting .  the texture of this beer is a bit thicker than many hefeweizens and with a bit less carbonation than usual .

not much of an aroma that i can coax out of this beer . only a sweet maltiness , though very mild .  this abbel dubbel poured a large invigorating tan long lasting head with fine-small bubbles .  m - due to the not-so-well-hidden booze , the feel is not quite there .

the aroma on this beer surprised me ; it came off almost skunky , with strong notes of sour grapes and mild spice .  a : beautiful golden hue to the body and a soft white head on top .  this brew is a bit thin otherwise .

the aroma is faint , did not pick up much , perhaps a touch of scorched caramel & toffee .  a great beer to look at . nice lacing developed during the session .  opens with a big scent of chocolate raspberries and alcohol . pours a good sized brown stout head over an opaque , deep brown body . chocolate and raspberries are in the taste too , along with a dryness thats part stout and part red wine . midway through , some more roast coffee stout notes come through , then a rather rough english hop profile . a great with desert , or as desert in itself .

it has a mild aroma of saltine crackers and floral hops . it 's a very light but perfumey scent . tastes of doughy malt with a little bit of lemon peel .  clear ( semi-clear in later pours ) , vibrant amber straw color . lots of fluffy head that barely fades . lots of thick , pillowy lace all the way down the glass .  m - very light on the palette , foaming up nicely and bubbles lightly in the mouth . the finish is a bit dry for my liking though .

has a slightly sweet aroma , but nothing too strong . where the beer earns its points is in its taste with a perfect mix of sweet and bitter .  towering , pillowy tan head with great retention . a good amount of lace .  the mouth feel was pretty average , has a slight alcohol bite at the end of it .

unfortunately the head dissipated quickly after the first two sips . if i were to judge the style of beer by smell alone i would be convinced that this was a straight-up ipa . i did not detect any wheat in the nose . ( though i 'm no bloodhound ) the taste was good , but not what i expected , which made trying this beer fun . it has interesting depth with the hop/wheat combo . the emphasis is certainly on the hops , and they have a pine flavor to them which i really liked . the wheat played second fiddle in this brew to the hops . the more subtle flavor of the wheat may be a letdown if you are looking for a good wheat beer , but if you enjoy wheat beers and ipas then its a fun blend . mouthfeel is medium to light and its pretty crisp and refreshing . overall , this is a very drinkable beer . a good middle ground between two of my favorite summer styles .  i love sour , and this beer had sour in spades , but it also had a kind of cloying sweetness that i found unpleasant and difficult to drink . it poured black with a fine sticky head .  carbonation is right there and builds up , becoming harsh , slightly taking away from enjoyment and the mouthfeel is lighter that i would expect .

somewhat spicy , with some hoppy aroma , but overall muted smell t- perfect .  a : beautifully clear pale amber hue , with a nice , muffin-like fluffy as well as frothy bear head , lasting extremely well and leaving wool fibre-like thick and tight lacing~~ sheer brilliant for a cask-conditioned ale .  it feels a little watery but the taste and the super clean finish really help this . there is no real carbonation , and that is this beers downfall .

i like its apperance , aroma , and taste . i was not dissapointed nor impressed with its aroma , though not bad . overall very good english brown ale .  pours the deepest black i 've ever seen- not a tinge of amber to be seen around the edges of this glass at all . head lingers , minimal lacing .  the mouthfeel is a little watery for the carbonation , and it leaves a sticky residue after swallowing .
still worth looking for and tasting .  similar in appearance to guinness draught with less of a roasted coffee presence .  taste is alright , but the palate feel is quite weak .

the nose is very mild , nothing distinct at all .  the yeti imperial stout poured pitch black . an amazing dark creamy coffee looking head . loads of lacing is left on the glass .  mouthfeel is very fizzy , scrapes the tongue .

i chose bottle , but i 've had it every way possible , unless you can think of anything else ... tried shiner bock for the first time when i was 18 ... i was used to drinking 'anything ' light that i could get my hands on , but this turned my tastebuds around ... it 's not as dark as the more traditional bock , but a nice appearance i believe ... it 's aroma is n't bad or anything , just not as powerful as that of the more tradition bock ... taste ?  huge frothy light tan head , that is surprisingly lasting .  m : medium-bodied , fairly flabby carbonation , smooth .

s- no smell really to speak of , maybe a little nutty t-absolutely surprised , this tasted fantastic . nutty , not really bitter in my opinion so it was a bit of surprise from the style .  pours extremely dark to almost black with about an inch of puffy , light brown head and some foamy , brown lacing .  mf : the mouthfeel here on this brew tends to thin out after the initial sip , and there is absolutely no malt backbone to this baby . d : even though the mouthfeel is lacking , this beer is still refreshing .

okay . nose is soft and soapy , slightly citric , some lemon peeking through , but far too mild of a hop presence for any kind of an ipa , really . bitter , citric attack on the tongue from the start , doing a fine ride through the mouth ... sticks around with admirable aplomb . bright and brash . and really tasty . could use a touch more depth and complexity , but there you have it .  huge 3 finger white head bubbles up on the pour into my sa pint glass .  m : a lot of carbonation , i think it could have done with a lot less .

aroma was of faint chocolate . very good roasted coffee bean flavor that was somewhat sharp .  pours a dark brown with a hint of red and a nice finger of head that looks really creamy and sticks around a while . beautiful .  m-is sort of thin , much more than i would expect . d-is very nice .

the top is pure white and standing at two inches . s - light and airy mild malt . t - very tasty wheat with a hint of banana .  a really pretty beer .  this beer lacks some carbonation . i think if it had a little more it would n't have that chalky like feel to it .

notes of roasted malt on the nose .  the looks of this beer are unmatched in my opinion . it pours a hazy , yellowy orange brew that produces an incredibly attractive head wich produces some excellent lacing . from the bottom of the glass multiple streams of bubbles search their way up , causing the head to last for an eternity . truly marvelous .  the mouthfeel is too syrupy for my tastes , with an unfulfilling bite of carbonation .

my ratings are based on them calling this an ipa . to me this was closer to a bad tasting light ale . drinkability was average because it did n't offend me beyond claiming to be an ipa .  really nice lacing and retention .  m - sharp carbonation is a little oveer the top .

cinammon malty nose - very minor . toasty hearty deep malt taste backed by a medium bitter .  exceptional golden color and head .  mouthfeel : slick , but not as full as i would have expected . it pushes for full , but falls short . the carbonation is a touch high for the style , but it works with the flavor profile .

s : roasted earthy aroma .  poured from the bottle into my founders snifter a - black body with a big brown head resting on top . menacing looking beer.i ca n't imagine a stout looking much better than this .  mouthfeel : closing in on medium bodied , but not quite there .

s- light and slighty nutty/caramelly t- tastes sweet with a subtle caramel . delicious m- light and smooth . overall just a fantastic beer .  easily the best looking .  mouthfeel is fairly light with somewhat frothy carbonation .

aroma was a minimal with a little roasted malt , but not too much , although this is certainly due to the very low carbonation .  this beer pours a slightly cloudy brownish orange , with a light tan head . the thick , fluffy head fades very slowly , leaving many thick laces .  light-medium body is a bit lacking due to somewhat limp and loose feeling carbonation . i really enjoyed this offering a lot despite its lacking mouthfeel .

has an average smell that really gives off the bourbon flavor .  the beer is a brilliant , crystal-clear gold color , and it has a retentive frothy white head .  medium bodied and tingly from the carbonation .

smell : a very average smelling beer , nothing that really stands out .  dark brown to black with ruby highlights , a full creamy tan head that lasts , decent carbonation , and decent lace rings .  the feel was light bodied with light carbonation .

hmmm , i get an odd aroma here . earthy , almost mushroomy , slightly acrid coffee notes .  a - poured hard into a large pint glass , the surge was beautiful . the color is black with a ruby hue at the bottom when held up to the light , retention was outstanding a tan finger and half head that keeps its lacing all the way to the very bottom of the glass .  mouthfeel is ok and does not seem to stick to the palate .

the nose is faint , burnt sugar and malt , with some hoppiness , nothing exciting . taste is much better , nice hops up front , piney and fresh .  a : liquid black gold , great head , with good retention , amazing after all it was a cask , it looked soild black , and i barely let the light pass through the glass ! !  mouthfeel : prickly carbonation , oily texture , medium body .

appearance - deep reddish brown , lacing sticks to the side of the glass head does not hang around very long.. smell - buttery malty with a trace of earthy english hops taste - the correct carbonation , mild earthy hop and diacetyl .  great retention and a nice creamy looking texture to it . extremely thick and plentiful lacing all around the glass .  m : creamy , but kind of thin .

it looked , and smelled like a decent porter , but after one taste , i had to discard the entire six pack . it could have been that the six pack was skunky , i guess .  on to the beer : it 's amber brown in color with orange hues . did i mention the lacing and retention were awesome as well ? but one whiff brings this beer back down to earth , as the subtle nutty and toffee aromas could stand to be stronger . it looks and feels great , so you want it for that , but it does n't show you much affection .  the body is spot on , lush and full . the carbonation though is a bit lackluster . do n't get me wrong , in a beer like this i 'm looking for the carbonation to be a bit on the low side , but it 's almost nonexistent here and the beer is bordering a bit on being syrupy .

s : not a lot to smell here , the hops seems to be the only thing coming through . t : starts out really hoppy but ends with subtle citrus . d : this is just a really nice and drinkable pale ale . notes : this is one of the first pale ales i really enjoyed .  it pours out a black beer with ruby edges in the light . the head is light tan with a good froth staying afloat throughout and beautiful lace clinging to the glass .  m - medium bodied . carbonation is where it should be . they enter like a legit good beer and go down like water . this one is very good and could only really improve on the mouthfeel . the mouthfeel remains to be this brewery 's flaw , but given the progress that i 've seen from them , i 'm sure they will address that .

smell : wet grain and bready malt.. there 's a faint smokiness in the aroma .  large , proud head . like a beautifully dark orange ipa , lit from within . remarkable look .  like it 's little brother od12 , od16 is well under carbonated . it is only 8 % i would love to see this one at a higher abv and with a bunch more carbonation .

aroma is wheaty and yeasty , a bit bready as well .  two fingers of the creamiest head i 've ever seen , which is tan/cream in color and had great retention and tons of lacing . 3.5 d : picture perfect looks , awesome smell , and very tasty , but the drinkability suffers a hell of a lot from the mouthfeel .  the mouth feel is n't bad .

nice lacing s-very creamy with a hint of chocolate and some coffee . light smelling . t-comes in with a very tasty and high quality hit of chocolatey chocolate . i love this stout !  a- cherry wood color with a beautiful sand colored 1 inch head . lacing is very good .  not as light bodied as a budweiser , but still light bodied . it is far cheaper and tastes better than any of the other macro brews out there .

interestingly enough , did not have a huge aroma , really subdued .  a = dark , almost black , with a thick , creamy tan head . it was mesmerizing watching a dark tan cascade of fine bubbles run down the insides of the glass like a waterfall . simply beautiful , much like watching a guinness stout settle .  very bland and acidic . can taste the 9 % all the way through .

softly bread-y and only mildly roasty . instead , i 'm met with a huge diacetyl rush . definitely not an english porter but firmly an original american entry into the style .  pours a true amber color with a huge two finger head that leaves loads of lace on the glass .  i thought the body was a little thin .

wow , theres a lot of apple in this one , tart light caramel , too . pretty rich , yet disarmingly drinkable .  color is dark amber with a light tan head . head retention is outstanding , lasting to the final sip , and there 's lots of lacing down the glass .  m : fair carbonation , flattens out on the palate .

first taste is very smooth , with a slightly bitter aftertaste . it 's like a much smoother , much more flavorful guinness , which is a very good thing . it 's not blowing me out of the water with its flavors , but it is very complex and mellow and definitely worth a try .  poured into a tulip . appearance- pours a slightly hazy golden straw color with three fingers of fluffy white head , that isnt moving anywhere anytime soon . ( i hate describing appearance in so much depth , but this is an epic looking beer ) smell- lemon and a nice peppery spice to it . pretty good overall , and looks stunning , but with so many great saisons out there , i probably wont buy this again , unless its to try it on draft .  almost juice ? mouth was bitter , to be expected , but not a strong bitter , washed about like any other average beer . watery . i 'm impressed with the balance with this brew . one time only but sure would be good in place of lagunitas 's other ipa 's .

good lacing too . smell - firm malty scent with that often found soapy aroma associated with a hefe-weisse .  pours a two finger head with a huge cascading border . liquid is nearly clear golden copper .  from the water used ? nice flavors , but a bit light and bubbly on the feel . nice canned stout

huge and foamy , crackling like rice krispies treats . not a huge fan of the smell , a metallic wheaty smell , earthened by something almost like yeasty dark fruit , but not quite . the metallic wheat smell dominated though , i was n't a fan .  pours with an orange amber body topped by a thick white head with lots of lacing .  m : light on the tongue . super low carbonation but that is to be expected .

s/t/m- smell was uninteresting..yeast and malt . it was not much indicative of the flavor , which is wonderful . was hit with a sweet and bready malt followed by a mildly tart yeast..alcohol warms things up here .  this beer looks wonderful , pouring a slightly cloudy , grassy yellow with a healthy , rich snow white head that looks like whipped cream .  as this beer poured into my glass , the most noticable aspect was the big , creamy , moussy head , which lasted a good long time . good balance in the flavor ... german hops and malty sweetness . toasty , grainy . a mineral aspect to the flavor profile . overall a very enjoyable beer . not a very common style .

s - the smell of long roasted malt and a hint of alcohol .  pours black with 2 finger chocolate head .  m- creamy but thin and light . some good carbonation salvages it to an extent , but it needed more body to it .

smells overwhelmingly like raspberries , in an artificial sort of way . the artificial raspberry flavor overwhelms the senses , and prevents you from tasting any of the actual beer .  glad to find this at the local beer store ... a : perfect pitch black with a thick 2 inch mocha colored head that slowly fades . exceptional !  it 's lacking the velvety feel i like in a good stout brew . a bit too prickly for the style .

smell : i did n't really notice the smell . taste : very fruity , tart , and malty . clever packaging . very disappointing .  pours spectacularly with the widget . super creamy , with a pretty , bright white head .  but what a treat -- a seasonal beer with a long history and an intriguing taste profile . it is nearly flat and ( ironically ) headless from its low carbonated body .

smell is of tangy , sour wheat with a hints of apricot and orange . amazingly drinkable , would love to have this consistently , especially in the summer .  pours an absolutely gorgeous transparent amber-ruby color with a nice , soft tan/white head .  smells of candy and sugar . tastes of dried apricots and burnt caramel ... very buttery . this brew is rather dry to the pallet.. clean finish but not much residue on the ol ' taste buds . good beer.. ot great but worth a try .

the appearance was similar to an unfiltered ipa . the smell was of course hoppy , but there was a lot of sweetness lurking past the hops . it was initially hard to detect in the smell , but it was noticeable . the hops were obviously present , but my tongue got a workout with all the flavors .  pour it out and it looks like the black color in the sidebars you see on these pages .  this beer claims to be one of the hoppiest beers in belgium , but it is n't what i expected . far less hoppy than i had hoped . i was n't disappointed by any means , because it was an excellent tasting beer . at $ 5 a pop for a 12oz bottle , forget about me buying another one .

smells of sweetness , honey and very light toasted malts all around . tiny notes of noble hops also make an appearance .  the solid black beer was buried in a mountain of shaving cream . i got two inches of head for every one inch of beer , and it wasnt even thinking about going away .  m - medium to full bodied with no syrupyness . could use a bit more carbonation .

smell is somewhat weak with slight citrus and grapefruit shining through . very drinkable brew .  great appearance , beautiful orange/peach color .  it took me quite a while to try one because it did n't sound like it could be good . i am so happy i got dfh punkin ale to start with so i know that it is a style with potential to be awesome . this was down right gross . it tasted like i was drinking a bad pumpkin pie . sickeningly sweet . i could n't finish it .

wheat and pale malt nose lacking any hops .  a- niiiice , orange caramel color and a full finger head that shows lines to help you know where each sip was . d- very drinkable , a very clean finish that makes you always happy to have another sip .  m : light yet substantial body , but a little watery .

reissdorf kolsch is an excellent although not quite perfect ( fruh kolsch ) example of a kolsch . for those of you who like lighter but flavorful beers this is the style for you . very clear , and smooth . no distinguishable aftertaste and moderate alcohol content 4.8 % . overall , i would buy this beer over and over and of course drink it too !  a nice deep brown to black color , the head portly in size , spumous in texture , light chocolate brown in color the lace left behind a fine covering upon the glass .  m : plain , smooth , and almost instantly forgettable .

aroma is thin and distant..slight hint of green apples and dark spoiling fruits . there is a spritzy , grainy wet finish with suggestions of nuts . nice , although an extreme stretch to compare it to a traditional flemish brown ale .  this beer looks amazing . big chunky head like an ice cream float .  visiting toronto , pulled this of the local liquor control shelf as a local . i 've traveled all over , and this is about the worst beer i 've had since brewii in baltimore in 1979 . love thetaps logo , that was the only good feature of this beer . big daddy

the ravens-steelers game is making me , as a browns fan , extremely sad and jealous , so i 'm having this to console myself . nose is not too strong , with a slight coffee/chocolate and malt to go with a faint booze smell .  incredible pour , lacing like a glass of milk .  lightly carbonated d- very ... does n't fill you up and tastes great .

first smell it had the grassy hop scent with a slight smell of caramel .  bottle and served in my unibroue tulip : a - pours a deep ruddy brown topped by a long lasting frothy tan head and excellent lacing .  mouthfeel : foamy and somewhat thick , like a thin syrup with carbonation . puts a little bit of carbonation on the tongue , but not too much .

the nose presents some subtle citrus and grass notes with comparably very little in terms of malt .  the appearance is great . it 's a dark brown/black color with a bit of red showing on the edges . the creamy head looks great on the glass , and has a thick texture .  m-i thought it was a little on the thin side for what i was expecting .

you could smell the pale malts . light , grassy hop nose . nothing `` raw '' in the nose .  stange at hopleaf . appearance : darkness is what it says on the bottle , and darkness is what is inside . it pours a midnight blackcolor with just a hint of slightly off-black molasses in the very tip of the glass . darkness indeed . a creamy dark tan coffee head mellows in its creaminess , then recedes , reforming with every swirl and leaving some unexpected lace on the glass .  mouthfeel - a smooth mouthfeel , a bit on the watery side but crisp .
aroma is light and hoppy , barely existent .  nice lacing left behind , definitely an impressive looking beer .  m -- moderately chewy with the chocolate and malt , but finishes thin .

s - good , but nondescript . it smelled like a barleywine , that 's about it . worthy of your time and money .  a : beautiful pale straw yellow color . amazing head ! lots of lacing . a beauty .  this beer calls itself a dubbel , but at 6.5 % and with such light body , i would n't call it that .

s. the smell is the only drawback to this beer . it doesnt smell nearly as good as it looks or tastes .  appearence was beautiful clouded caramel brown along with yeast from the bottle . the head poured a large , three fingers , that lasted a good while before fading to a light froth above the surface . carbonation bubbles constantly rose from the bottom of the glass . wonderfully sweet on the nose , banana and green apple were the strongest scents up front , along with minor notes of orange and other citrus , a slight malt towards the end .  the mouthfeel is a tad thin as a result of the filtration , since residual proteins are quite important in mouthfeel .

( still i am happy ) on the pour : dark amber/copper , tan head medium lacing.malty nose , but somewhere in that fist inhale is a happiness .  the appearance was great . a really darkened amber . this beer poured great with a off white head that came to about two fingers .  mouthfeel : a little thin on the palate , but otherwise felt good .

kind of a faint aroma . wow . that tasted like marijuana .  production code 23cf a : pours a slightly hazy light golden color with a massive foamy head that takes up half the pint glass . great sustain with thick lacing all over the glass .  it seems light in the mouth .

s - a hint of a roasted smell ( i have a bad nose ) t - nice roasted taste kind of smoking taste , unlike a porter .  appearance - cloudy mahogany , thick cream colored head that laces incredibly .  m : kind of flat , not bad , growler is only 2 days old , so it may be a factor .

s : malt , some faint bourbon , chocolate , some wood ? t : chocolate and coffee up front , but taking another sip i am getting some roasted malt , some woody flavor and a hint of the bourbon aging . d : just an outstanding beer .  in great similarity to the ara bier , stille nacht has a ton of head that seemingly never reduces into a rich , thick , white head . lace is very nice all the way down to the bottom .  the flavor is n't bad at first , upfront it tastes like a flavorful macro lager .

s : somewhat subdued aroma , compared to what i was expecting , i guess . i get a bit of grapefruit and a bit of pine with some earthiness and body odor . as it warms , the hop profile improves just a bit , but is still a little underwhelming . t : the taste is better than the aroma . really nice hop profile with citrusy fruits up front ... grapefruit and tangerine prominent .  the head sticks around for the whole drink and leaves lots of sticky lacing on the sides of the glass . this is a perfect looking weizen .  m - not as thick as i expected but very drinkable d - outstanding , i could drink a couple of these pretty easily .

the aroma was nothing particularly startling : it was average and neutral smelling of slightly smokey malt .  `` cask '' ading action is short lived but impressive gold tones flurry then settling to a nice dark amber walnut color with a steady finger high head of ivory creamyness , continent shaped lacing sticks well .  ok carbonation .

in aroma , bitter backer 's cocoa with metallic undertones dominate .  2010 bottle drank into my darkness tulip ... a dark as midnight night with a huge dark tan head . the head is amazing as it literally arises from beneath the beer foaming up a full four fingers . the head is two colors , dark tan on the bottom with a lighter color on the top .  it 's extremely smooth , but i think the body could be a lot lot thicker - the smoothness comes from the thin character of the body . the flavor is n't over the top like some , but it could use a little more body and a little more flavor would n't hurt either .

s : for the stronger abv i was surprised that the smell was not more potent . i sensed a hint of nut , pine , citrus . t : tasted great !  cascade pour , very similar to taps , however , the head sets up fast compared to the best taps . tan head , black/ruby color . that said , its seems flat compared to the pubs , and a little thin . very nice .  just slight bit high on the carbonation , and a body that 's just about right .

the aromas are certainly delicious but disappointingly dull .  whoa ... the first sniff had me thinking something was off . it pours a gorgeous honey color ... very tiny bubbles ascending give it a nice carbonated look ... the 1/2 inch thick off-white head clings to the glass as the liquid descends .  mouthfeel - very beerlike .

the smell wasnt strong , but was a bit smokey and burnt . overall a very enjoyable beer .  a : very dark -- nearly black but with a hint of redness ; beautiful , dense head ; wonderful , even lacing s : lots of grapefruit with a little extra citrus going on ; on the second smell , i noticed more pine scent ; there 's also a bit of strong alcohol smell t : surprisingly the grapefruit and pine scents carry over more than expected into the taste .  m a little thin here d yah ...

not much for a head , i could n't really pick up much of a nose on it . drank great though .  the head stayed for the entie beer , and the lacing in the sides of the glass was absolutely fantastic .  m : full mouthfeel with a medium body to it .
a bit spicy in the nose but not very aromatic .  pours a glowing golden straw with a healthy white head . excellent lace and retention .  possibly a bit thin .

smell : the nose is disappointingly mild - it 's bready and toasty with a hint of caramel , but it 's very faint . where 's the hop aroma ? taste : tastes like boston lager 's big brother .  pours with a dense two inch off-white head ; holds throughout . one of , if not the , best looking beer i 've ever seen .  before expanding my palate yuengling used to be my favorite beer . i gre up in the dc area so we had plenty of it around . i still consider this a great beer for a night full of drinking , but not one that i would drink because i want to enjoy a beer . i still love you yuengling and i ca n't wait to have you again ... stupid yuengling does n't ship to ca .

s - had some faint hop smell with chocolate and smoke overtones . t - toasted malt with earthy coffee tone .  the beer 's appearance is ridiculously good , the best head i 've had in weeks .  and now i know why people say it tastes like chocolate syrup , because it kinda does . but this is really good if you like chocolate . probably 1200 calories in this bottle . but who 's drinking beer and watching calories ?

s : unfortunately the hop aroma has worn off quite a bit . i still get a little pine note , and some sharp cheese . t : the hop aroma may have worn off , but the taste is still there !  the tan head was a full , three-fingers of foam that became a rocky cap that displayed good retention and excellent , consistent lacing .  the only complaint about this beer is that its a bit thinner than guiness or beamish , and not quite as rich or full flavored .

it smells like 'beer ' , and by that i mean good-ol'-american-honest-to-goodness-beer . that is , slight adjunct smell mixed with the faintest wiff of hops and malt .  appearance : served in an eight-ounce glass , it comes with a superb tan head , almost overflowing from the glass . outrageous retention , stays on and on . fantastic lacing as well .  carbonation is a bit high and affects the mouthfeel a bit feels prickly with carbonation as well as a bit syrupy .

smell : smells of sweet caramel malts and light baking spices like cinammon and nutmeg , slight hitns of orange as well ; smell is not especially strong though and i feel as if i 've got ta pull pretty hard from my nostrils to pick up on it .  yellow in color with a huge , frothy , rocky white head that seems to last forever . all sorts of sticky lacing , a very attractive beer .  this is a very enjoyable , crisp lager but more of a classic , good american-style lager than a german pilsner since it really is not very hoppy and is lighter in body . it is lightly sweet and bitter . it becomes slightly more bland and mineral-water like near the end but still retains decent flavour and body .

not too much of an aroma , slight sweet grape smell . taste is very nice - alcohol is very present yet balanced with candy sugar , honey , and vanilla .  this beer poured a deep rich brown color .  mouthfeel & gt ; effervescent . thin .

guinness draught may not be the best stout in the world , hell it is n't even the best stout produced by guinness , but what the beer lacks in complexity made up for in style . pair this with a dark ruby colour and guinness may be the nicest beer to look at . it is certainly easy to drink and makes a good session beer . still , this beer is available just about everywhere and is allowing beer drinkers to get a consistently good , albiet not great product at most drinking holes .  poured into a snifter with the darkest black you will see in a beer .  this beer feels a little lighter than many ipa 's , but that is not to say it has less quality .

pours a hazy orange tan ( looks like 1/2 lemonade 1/2 tea ) with some thin bone-white head that leaves a little spotting . somewhat muted , but definitely east coast style with lots of caramel malt sticking out through the leafy dry hops . nice clean , somewhat sweet finish . notes : this beer is rather interesting because it seems to be backwards in mouthfeel for an ipa : it 's really bitter right up front but finishes sweeter .  a : looks magnificent in a glass , burnt yellow-orange , with a big puffy , white head with oustanding lacing as the beer is drunk .  mouth feel is exceptionally carbonated almost to the point of obstructing the flavor .

scents of corn , some wheat , and mild floral tones waft out .  opaque amber and peach . super fine long lasting head .  mouthfeel is syrupy and coating . i do n't really think i could have more than one of these per night , but i 'd be damned if i did n't try . if anything , it would be the sticky and cloying mouthfeel rather than the big booze presence preventing me from doing so , which is surprising to me .

s : smell is slightly skunky with a little bit of yeasty smells and faint sweet malts .  a= pours a pitch black color with a nice two finger thick brown head on it . the head and color is really suprising for a lager .  the hickory stick stout is a slightly stronger beer than i prefer . i ca n't really drink a lot of it at once but however ... the beer had a very thick and long lasting head on it . the taste is a bit bitter but at the same time fairly smoothe going down . the aftertaste is a little stronger than i prefer but all in all it is a very smoothe and good smelling beer .

i do n't pick up a lot of aroma but sweetish caramel malts come through . the flavor is interesting , this may be the most caramel forward beer i 've had .  colour is a rich brownish-red . big two-finger head fades with mild lacing . a moderate amount of carbonation is visible . appearance is beautiful but the taste was a little run of the mill .  mouthfeel is slick .

initially the smell was mild and it was hard to distinguish the scents . with a good swirl i reveal hints of pine and sweet malt and a rather floral aroma but still quite mild .  500ml- & gt ; sam smith pint a ~ pours black with a thick tan head that rises like a biscuit out of the glass . exceptional appearance .  suprised to see the alc at 10 % . really interesting . somewhat of an acidic mid and short finish . still the aroma is outstanding . almost tannic and closed . maybe time would help this brew come around ? still very interesting . would have been better served with friends and shared , not sure even an 12 oz bottle is for just 1 person .

s - leaves me kind of flat , i do n't smell much of ... anything , to be honest . it 's a relatively sweet-smelling brown , i do n't smell much trace of pumpkin or pumpkin pie spicing .  the head displays great retention and absolutely coats the glass in lacing .  the mouthfeel is rather disappointing .

smells clean alcohol , vegetal , chocolate , mild aromas overall . decent williamette hop aroma .  this was an excellent beer , and something that i would gladly get again for the price per 6er a- beautiful golden color , visibly carbonated , with a nice white head that leaves a lacing for the entire life of the beer s- this surprised me a bit .  i was lucky enough to catch the tail end of the batch that coopers was lucky enough to recieve ... poured unlike any cask ale ive seen to date ... fluffy , quickly receding head that didnt spiderweb at all , nice consistent lacing ... smell is more intense than the normal ipa , nice aromatic fruity hops present , touch of piney bitterness ... taste is nice and rounded , despite being somewhat complex.. oak tones meld nicely with the fruity hops , again the pine tree bitter hop oil presence is a great touch ... unfortunately the carbonation was all but gone , a little too flat even for cask ales , and it had only been tapped for two days ... oh well , the flavor is what counts and mac and jack deliver on that note ... looking forward to trying the blackjack cask-conditioned ... cheers !

aroma is lightly ( read lightly ) sweet malt and a touch of '' ... soap . enough is enough and i ca n't finish this pint .  pours a cloudy bright orange-yellow with a massive white head , stiff as whipped cream .  the mouthfeel is a bit on the light side , but maybe that contributes to its overwhelming drinkability .

smell was very underwhelming . it did n't really smell that strongly , but what there was included some spices and ginger . the taste was a huge surprise after the relatively unimpressive smell .  it is a deep deep brown/black and has a great thick tan colored head of good duration .  strangely light mouthfeel when it hits the tongue . under carbonated by a long shot .

aroma is almost non-existent , very faint hints of caramel malts and herbal/earthy hops .  it was a little too dark for me to get a real picture of the color , but it was dark and the head was nice .  m- high carbonation , very light .

an exceptionally clean easy to drink summer lager and first rate at that . this is a great traditional lager , leaving little to the nose but plenty to the taste and the feel .  bought in vienna a : pour a cloudy pale orange body with four fingers of beautiful white fluffy head . retention is great as is the lacing .  mouthfeel was somewhat watery not at all what i was expecting .

aroma is mostly of malts , some subtle chocolate notes too .  pours a dark brown almost black color , very huge light brown head that fades very slowly and leaves a good amount of lacing along the glass .  starts smooth and slightly bitter . settles with a medium-full body and deep caramel flavor . finishes strongly bitter ; drains dry . the distinct cough suppressant aftertaste is mercifully short-lived .

smell was very plain with a slight hint of spices .  a : pours a dark , almost opaque brown color . a large beige head of over two fingers forms with great retention .  aromas of chocolate and roasted maltiness . the flavors depict much of the same and it 's a bit more complex than many other brown ales . this is a great beer to hang around a late afternoon drinking with your buds . go for it .

smell : fairly middle-ground with a neutral kick of grassy , grainy , hoppy deliciousness . this is by far the most drinkable and delicious of helles lagers i have tasted . mouthfeel : carbonation livens the palate along with the smooth highly drinkable consistency that is this oh so special beer . alongside the plethora of beer that this monastery pumps out this is a good base for the magnificence that this place will bestow upon your taste buds .  pours into my snifter dark and viscous , black with no light being able to penetrate , a large amount of tan head that fades slowly with some decent lacing on the glass .  a little thinner , but a better or no aftertaste . tastes good , a bit thin , but not much .

pour is dark , chocolate bar . nose of roast malt and coffee .  a huge , fluffy white head sits on top ( i think this is what clouds look like ) , and it 's not going anywhere .  m : a bit on the thin side , well carbonated , dry .

the aroma was sweet and malty with fruity english ale yeast esters . dull at first , they moderately improved as the esb warmed .  very dark velvety black beer with a dark tan , barely red in it , head .  ) but remembering from past experiences on tap a very light pleasant taste light in the mouth very easy to drink and much enjoyment has been had with this beer in my hands

too much alcohol in the nose , but there is also hints of chocolate , coffee , and dark fruits . but this really is a finely crafted winter beer .  pours a nice reddish orange with a creamy off white head that has good retention and rings the glass .  mouth is heavy and bitter with a cloying finish .

there 's not a ton of aroma , but i 'm made well aware that this is not a typical american brown ale as it 's been catagorized here ( edit : i do see that it 's been correctly changed to flanders oud bruin ) . tastes wonderful . no noticeable alcohol or hops . highly drinkable .  appearance : dark and thick black with a 1 1/2 finger thick tan head . really great head retention , filled with bubbles , leaving behind tremendous lacing .  unlike the smell , there is no hint of milk to the beer . the only detraction is thinner body and high level of carbonation .

apearance is a dark brown almost black with a creamy tan head smell is smooth and a little nutty , but almost none existent .  appearance - warm amber , watchful carbination , excellent head retention .  m -- nothing out of the ordinary here .

makes a small 1 finger fluffy head that leaves good lacing , stouts and porters are always beautiful beers . nose is rather light not much here , obvious roasted malt but not much else under laying that maybe some zest from the hops . taste is big , and looms ever larger compared to the tiny profile of the nose . espresso beans , powerful coffee flavor with chocolate and it all is blended together so nicely .  appearance- i love lots of head ( lol ) on my beer . the best retention i 've seen so far on any ipa period .  m : you can feel the carbonation and it has a nice touch of hops spice .

not much aroma . beer looks great , nice medium head .  poured into a surly snifter . tons of head . took ten minutes to fade but provide some glorious cascading as it did .  the carbonation is present in the mouth and the beer does n't feel creamy enough for me .
aroma - light but stable malt , rather sweet and floral , almost candyish .  pours a beautiful black color with small tan head .  m : spritzy , thinner , but ok. d : very good .

smell : this was really lacking . for a beer with such a powerful taste , i found myself surprised at how hard i had to sniff . the smell is sweet and i ca n't say much else .  bottle date 11/01/07 - bright orange color , large head with staying power .  the mouthfeel is wet ( this being the weak-point of this brew ) .

smell is nice . not a ton of smell to it , but what i get is a lot of dark roasted malts .  looks perfect , for the style .  taste : a little roasty . pretty fizzy which is n't really common to the style and was as though designed to make up for a lack of flavor . the middle is sweet cocoa and the finish is pretty dry with a hint of roastiness and caramelized malt . note : catchy name but i wish they would have put their creative juices into brewing a better beer .

it did n't feature much of anything as far as aromas are concerned .  pours with a clear amber orange body topped by a thick white foamy lasting head and lots of lacing .  finishes crisp with a sort of biting feeling in the back of the throat .

bitter notes with a slight roasted coffee element .  22oz bottle this beer poured a dark brown , almost chocolate milk , colored creamy head with a pitch black body . easily one of the most beautiful heads i 've ever seen on a beer .  m - a little short on carbonation for a belgian , also the sweetness gives it a thick , syrupy feel .

faint whiff of malt and clove are all i get . slightly flowery . quite a bite to it , though , despite the weak nose .  mostly black with hints of mahogany..great huge light brown frothy head .  duchesse de bourgogne was my first toe dip in the water , and i found those waters foul . mouthfeel is wet . this shit is right .

pours a crystal clear dark golden color , almost exactly like pilsner urquell . aroma is rather faint ; slight musty fruit notes , banana and little bit of clovey smoke , reminiscent of a nice german hefeweizen . man , this beer is good !  pours black as death with a huge four finger head that refuses to recede past a finger .  yuengling lager is a good choice to stock the fridge with . its actually cheaper around here than bud and other macros , and has a much better flavor . it is a fairly watery beer , but the flavor that is there is mostly of malts , with a little hops thrown in .

the aroma was rather dull as some faint malt was the only detectable tone for the nose .  a -- black color with a thick finger of head that left rings around the pint glass with every sip s -- faint coffee and roasted malts , pretty standard t -- this was n't too heavy on any of the flavors that i want in my stouts , it was fairly basic with hints of coffee .  a little low on carbonation . clean and refreshing .

i am only getting faint burnt and caramel type of smells . t : a pretty good taste , but overall light and not overpowering . this tastes like a great beer for people who are only used to huge american macro lagers . o : a great session beer . i do n't think it is anything spectacular , but it is good .  with a white velvety head that just sticks to the glass in a way i can only describe as sexy .  almost aggressive carbonation , crisp mouthfeel .

s : some hops , and a smell reminiscent of wet earth . not unpleasant . overall a very nice if not spectacular beer .  a : tons of head atop a clearish pale orange body . gorgeous lacing .  mouthfeel is average . right amount of carbonation ; right amount of foaminess .

s - very mild . nothing really sticks out too much , maybe just your average citrus and malts . it 's decieving because ( maybe my nose is clogged ) i do n't smell much .  not just a perfect pour for the style -- a perfect pour . a tight , soapy two-finger head sticks atop a perfect hazy gold . i ca n't think of a really , really nice way to describe this color .  m : i got a lot of carbonation in this beer .

smell of roasted malts , some chocolate and a faint toasted wood scent .  pours super black .  let down a little by an overly thin mouthfeel . the soft , creamy carbonation helps out but it would have been better with some more body .

very attractive beer . bright flavor is citrusy , mildly estery and i occasionly picked up cheesey notes .  oak aged yeti pours a very thick and motor-oily liquid forming huge amounts of creamy head ( brown-reddish in color ) that goes down after about 5 minutes leaving a lot of lacing in the glass . another perfect pour just like its yeti siblings .  the only relative disappointment is the mf for me -- it 's too thin for a stout .

s : mild citrus hop aroma . t : lovely malt flavor , biscuity , with some subtle fruit notes and a nice hop tang at the end .  very pretty glowing amber beer , nice head , large bubbles at the bottom of the glass .  mouthfeel is ok , a little flat .

some citrus , some spice . t. : evident test of lemon flower .  i was left with a rocky island of head in the middle of my glass . super sticky . the lacing was so impressive that i actually felt bad rinsing out the intricate design left behind . it was remarkably consistent . the body was clear and sparkling , half way in between yellow & copper . d : becomes more drinkable as the temperature rises but definitely not an all day beer . a good night cap .  brewed just a month ago . the smell is nearly nonexistent besides a hint of malt . the flavor is paper , vegetable , malt , and a hint of herbal hops . glad it was only 99 cents because it is worth jsut a bit less .

not much aroma to speak of , i get mostly hard cider from this . overall a very good and interesting beer . i 've never had an oak-aged double ipa , and thought that the two would n't go well together .  a - a beautiful fiery reddish orange color with a two finger foamy white head . a great look overall in the snifter . i really can ; t get over the color , it 's awesome . a great looking beer with an inviting aroma .  t- the malts definatly lead the way creamy and the coffee aromas come through in the flavor adding a pleasent bitterness tying it all togather . m- lingering tase is please n't but nothing to special d- i can nurse about four a day no problem . very good but not something i 'd just pound .

the smell is lightly hoppy and rather citrus . just smelling the beer is refreshing . i enjoyed the taste of this lager quite a bit .  bottle : poured a pitch-black color stout with a super huger dark brown foamy head with good retention and some light lacing .  the smell was great with a lot of hops and citrus . i was expecting a little more hops but i have been on quite an ipa binge recently so maybe i was affected by this . that said the general taste was pleasant and the beer was very drinkable .

s - fairly muted but somewhat sweet .  appearance 5/5 bright and clear , dark amber red colored with a big , creamy , off white head that 's going to leave an excellent , excellent , lacing . have to wait for the foam to subside before noting anything on aroma .  the body is bit on the thin side , but that 's not necessarily out of the ordinary for an oatmeal stout .

i 'd heard a lot of good things about pranqster from several friends and was quite curious to try it , having loved northcoasts other beers . finally i went on a roadtrip recently and ended up in a beer outlet store in camirillo , and was about to pick up some arrogant bastard , but then i saw pranqster ! it is by far one of the sweetest matliest beers ever . pranqster to date is the only beer i have never been able to finish , and i shamedly poured the remainding half of the bottle down the sink ... damn you pranqster !  on tap served into a pint glass.enjoyed on sept11.pours bright orangish copper in color.foggy appearance.off-white , small bubbled , creamy froth creates a thick layer & lasting crown leaving lacing collars.yeast , pine & woody resin to the nose.the upfront is a dry bitter at first sip like many ipas ; surprisingly , slightly toasted malts come producing an smooth velvet palate , notes of grapefruit & citrics.all this makes the big difference from others !  the mouthfeel is much too bubbly and stiff for this style , but maybe that 's what it gives it its marvelous head ... this is the only thing holding the beer back .

sweet can . the aroma is of light malts and straw , adjusted with corn or rice .  light copper orange with a sticky cream colored lasting head . good clarity . big resiny `` c '' hop aroma with some malt character to back it up .  heavy alcohol , extreme spice , honey , grapes and pepper . oof - this is where my `` inexperiance '' as an advocate comes in . an immediate peppery sting inflames the mouth and the grapes , saffron and alcohol kill them off . wtf is saffron ? sorry dfh .

lively bubbles . smell : slight malty smell , no detectable hops . lagers , especially adjunct lagers , are n't close to the top of my favorite beer style list , but this one is very nice .  a - brilliantly clear golden body with a thick vicious white head .  smooth porter richness nicely balanced with light hops m : a bit thin for my taste but fits with the balance and delicacy of the flavor d : balanced flavors and delicate mouthfeel make this a very drinkable porter ; i definitely want another

aroma is surprisingly mildly malty and hoppy . flavor is where this sweet little dog knocks my socks off .  beautiful deep , dark color . with an impressive dark head that leaves lots of lace .  m - a bit of a disappointment here . it leaves a nice stickiness in the back of my throat , but it 's maybe a little too carbonated for me ; it just seems too light .

aroma is yeasty and phenolic with some earthiness and an herbal note . again , as in the nose , phenolic and earthy yeastiness .  looks like a really nice refreshing beer .  the taste was also dominated by honey . i think i would have liked this is it had been a beer with some honey highlights since i love honey but this is basically a glass of honey with a little beer thrown in to make it flow out of the glass better . by the end the honey is just too much to take and i had to choke down the last third just to avoid a drain pour . avoid this one . ( 1.5 , na , ml , n )

the smell is very faint . for me the beer just smell very malty . the flavor however is much better .  it 's opaque as can be ; the head is large , chunky , and tan colored .  mouthfeel : heavy carbonation and a light body . fizzy , with a bit of puckering bitter .

appearance : pour is an orange/coppery color and comes with a 1 and 1/2 finger head that is slightly off-white and creamy ; head fades relatively quickly to a full and un-even skim and leaves a pretty full curtain of lacing down the sides of the glass ; body is pretty clear and shows strong carbonation bubbling throughout . smell : not especially strong , but smells of lightly toasted grains and there 's definitely a sweeter malty backing .  poured into a wine glass from a corked and caged 750 ml bottle . a- tons of head . the first pour filled the glass with over 75 % froathy , dishwater head . left lacing behind that was sticky and tan . the beer is a deep burgandy color with small bubbles of carbonation shooting up throughout .  some harsh roast flavours show up in the finish and it is also sorta sorta chalky . mouthfeel is ok i guess , but who cares when it tastes this bad ? i 'm guessing this flavour comes from some sort of cheap grain/adjunct .

smells ... yeasty . it 's mellow and almost gives a sense of creaminess it 's so smooth .  after a long pour from the tap the head finishes with two and a half fingers with this fantasic crown on top . i would love this beer to have a little more i.b.us to give it a little more bite .  unlike dl , this puppy is thin in body & complexity and has a body nowhere like motor oil . lightly carbonated to the point that any less carbonation one could considered this aspect the beers only fault .

got some of this on a whim . great golden color . i figured there would have been a reddish hue but did n't really notice any . nice hint of cherrys with a hint of the malty nirvana to come . great taste not a strong cherry overtone like i expected good malt taste . good mouthfeel again this is a great session beer . great session beer its on the rotation in my beer fridge  now a cloudy orange-wheat color , still with an enormous head that lingers for a long time and leaves a massive amount of lacing in its wake . a truly beautifully hefeweizen .  actually kind of thin for me . carbonation is good , but the bitterness is too dry for my taste .

smell is a bit odd . i get a little bit of wet blanket , which is obviously unexpected . great grassy flavor ; really earthy .  the color is very light for a quad , a light tan with a hint of amber . the head is light tan and rises several fingers and has amazing retention and lacing .  mouthfeel : light , pretty carbonated , and a bit of bitterness . this one does n't get too wet on the tongue , still , a tad light for a lager but a well deserving mouthfeel .

a : dark opaque hue , passes no light at all , foamy brown head , decent lacing s : mild roasted dark malts , pecans t : dark roasted malts , nutty , hearty , black bread m : decent carbonation , medium to full bodied , hearty , mildly bitter overall , a really good black ale with a full hearty , nutty taste .  this beer pours a beautiful dark chestnut with a ruby hue . there 's a white fluffy head , and excellent lacing around the glass .  m : medium to high body with lower carbonation . slick finish .

s : citrus and pine , not as strong as i would like but good . my guess is this is n't past it 's prime fwiw . t : it has the perfect amount of bitterness for me , finishes dry , grapefruit is prodominant m : medium , carbonation is about right o : overall this is a good/very good ipa . if you like good ipa 's i would recommend this for sure , i just think its way overpriced .  pours a pitch black color with a thin brown head into my glass . very good for the style .  the taste was crisp , sensual , malty , and generally delicious , with a whisper of chocolate . the ale was an average feel , nothing noteworthy .

has notes of citrus and pine hops plus some apricot hints in there too . this beer is a very refreshing ipa with a not to much fruit back but just enough to make it refreshing .  pours out to a brilliantly clear sunshine golden , forming a rocky white head with superior retention and excellent thick sheets of lace . a great looking beer .  m - average mouthfeel .

there was not much of a scent to it , slight malt and chocolate . great flavor , medium to full body , hints of chocolate and deep flavoring .  bottle , it 's a beautiful golden red color with ample head and fair retention .  m : relatively light for what it looks , smells , and tastes like , though not to the detriment of the beer . lively carbonation matches body .

i like hoppy beers and this fits the bill . i was n't expecting much based on the smell of the beer ; just average . i highly recommend this to any ipa fan .  being a huge fan of dogfish head 90 minute ipa , i absolutely had to try this when i found it at my local beer and wine retailer . a - burton baton pours a deep , dark copper . this beer is very clear with faint traces of carbonation rising to the top of the glass .  this beer is good . i do n't understand why people freak out with a+ ratings . for me , ninkasi 's `` maiden the shade '' is a better choice for a similar beer . i do n't get why the `` bros '' give `` total domination '' a c rating and then give this an a+ ?

nose is a little less reliable , with some coffee and hop balance extant but not much else ; somewhat lacking and dull in the sniffer to be honest . taste is sweet with coffee and hops and plenty of malt sugar .  appearance - a huge foamy , cotton-like head that lasted most of the beer .  i find this to be a very clean tasting beer with good thin mouthfeel .

excellent carbonation , beautiful fluffy head that held for minutes on end , nice lacing etc ... deep brown but incredible clarity . dark fruits that are sweet but not overwhelmingly so . supple on the tongue . delicious brew .  nice white head . looks great .  the mouthfeel is a bit sticky and the body is a little heavier than i would imagine , however , this really drinks nicely and is one of my favorite portsmouth offerings .

it smells of bittersweet toffee and/or caramel ( i could n't really pin it down ) . were i ever in new england again , i 'd definately look for another bottle of long trail ale .  with half of a 33cl pour into an oversized wine glass , the beer produces a two finger thick head . the head is pure white , lasts forever , and lacing sticks greatly to the glass .  wow , this beer looks friggin great . dark as night , huge tan head . looks like a two-layer cake . aroma is somewhat gross , like old leather and mold . someone said 'beef jerky , ' and i can see a note of meatiness . interesting , but odd . wow this tastes foul . it tastes like a suitcase that was left in the basement for years . then the basement was flooded , and the leather buckled and grew mildew in the cracks . i hate to say it , but this is going right down ye olde tadcaster draine .

beautiful lacing is left on my pint glass with each sip i take . aroma : some vegetal hoppiness and notes of sherry ( oxidation ? ) . i also get a little raisin/dried fruit . the aroma of this beer lets me down a bit ... .i just dont like this sherry/port wine smell im getting out of this beer .  there was a big , creamy , tan-colored head and excellent lacing . a great looking stout .  the mouthfeel was thinner than average for the style with a crisp , bubbly carbonation that mellowed as the beer sat .

nose is kind of small and muted , very tiny all i get off or this is a light malt . i just wish this beer had some degree of bouquet on it .  retention is amazing . perfect looking beer .  mouthfeel is average - nothing special ... tingly carbonation , and not overly smooth/silky .

s- some faint roasted malt and grains . not as much going on in the nose as i had hoped . t- that 's better , the taste brought it back . i just wish the nose was a bit stronger .  huge head showing great persistence and lacing .  the mouthfeel is medium bodied , and perhaps a bit too carbonated .
s : subtle pumpkin aroma with a faint notes of spices and toasted malts .  this is a beautiful beer . the body has a very pretty ruby tinge to it .  m - a bit acidic to the tongue .

nice looking head . aroma is caramel malts with a hop hit .  this my friends is a brown ale . a deep rubby brown beer with a thick creamy tan head that lingers through my tasting process .  mouthfeel : nice carbonation , but a little thin in my opinion .

smells a bit funky , notes of oak mix with musty earth tones . the scent is a definate downer but i could drink alot of this .  i can not find the words to describe the way this beer looks as it is poured , but anyone who has ever had one knows what i am talking about . the head looks very creamy , and it never fades , leaving the thickest curtain of lace i have ever seen .  m - medium low body with no noticeable carbonation .

smell has a really strong caramel malt presence , the hop presence is oddly mute for a dipa .  poured a glowing golden orange color with huge carbonation and a fluffy white head .  mouthfeel is very light which may help explain the softness of the beer .

smell : some mild roasted malts and chocolate were noticeable , but somewhat light from what i expected .  the cascading effect was amazing ... but that 's where the amazement ends .  a fantastic combination . thin for the style , though it does n't detract much at all from the overall enjoyment .

smells like white grape juice with a little stewed tomato . fairly sweet and estery , with little yeast funk as you get down past the head that reminds me of agar plates in a bacteria lab .  pours like engine oil , giving a reddish creamy thick head .  leaves a pleasant bitterness on the tongue . not a typical `` fizzy yellow beer '' in my opinion . if you find yourself in goose island territory and you either want a nice blonde ale or want to introduce your macro-swill drinking friends to a better beer , try this one .

the smell is the usual oktoberfest of caramel , grains , and fruits .  this export lager is a masterpiece as far as appearances go . perfect presentation for the two finger thick ultra white head . one can not do much better than this as far as looks go .  pour revelaed an extremely thick and long lasting creamy white head.as it reduced it left rings of lace in the glass.the color presented was orange and somewhat cloudy.mouthfeel wasnt very crisp and seemed a bit watery.the finish left a sharp sweet or tart twist that dissapeared real quick.a bit bitter in the back of the throat with a wheaty grain taste.a spicy aroma thats not too strong but is there.tastes of oranges , lemon , cloves , corriander , and honey are noted.overall good with a medium body .

the smell is that of a nutty malt with some earthy notes as well . light bodied mouthfeel with a smooth well balanced flavor of a slight grainy , touch of caramel flavor , and finishes with a pecan type flavor on the tail .  dark , mahagony brown with shades of red and a robust off-white head laces nicely .  m : very average .

weak , metallic smell . decent watery , slightly metallic taste . smell is not remarkable , but caramel is noticeable .  big off-white head on a luxuriously dark red body .  m : little carbonation with a decent amount of body .
the smell is pleasant , but not very deep .  batch number t8172 blurred-through honey colored with a monumental cool whip textured eggshell pillar rising above .  m.light bodied fizzy carbonation .

the smell is a little thin , but good . banana , hot spices and a tinge of alcohol .  ) of dense hilly off-white head , as stiff as meringue on top . sunk to a modest layer with a huge plateau in the middle , so stiff that cracks formed when it started to break apart . yikes . substantial chunky lace .  body is not quite as big as some imperial stouts , a little more fullness and creaminess would be nice but the flavor is good . overall , a solid example of an imperial stout .

roasted coffee/sour cherry nose . roasted/burnt coffee , sour cherry syrupy flavor , no aftertaste .  a - dark . real dark , with a huge creamy head that sticks everywhere .  good odor of molasses and coffee and maybe a little of the roasted grains that i link to most stouts . flavor is good , with strong hops accompanied by coffee and some sweetness . the coffee and malt becomes a little more apparent as the beer warms . all in all , a good brew . i 'd drink it again if i could get ahold of some down here .

s - roasted coffee , dark 70 % chocolate , but generally mild .  appearance- pours a hazy dark reddish brown with a beautiful one finger super creamy off-white head . a perfect half finger cap and collar remain the entire beer along with thick sheets of coated lacing .  mouthfeel - while i feel it adds some more to the flavor , the carbonation is a bit more on the intense side . body overall is average and the same thing goes with the overall thickness .

eyes ... aggresive pour ( we arent all perfect ) , 2 fingers of off white head , black but not pitch black hue , some amber fading through in parts of the glass , very fluffy lace and head , lacing is very lingering , the head dies down into a ring of froth on the edges ... nose ... astringent smell , sweet mocha , `` light '' dark fruit ... the alcohol is distracting in the nose , there is a lot there but i smell the alcohol .  a - black as tar , tall dark thick head .  m - palate is rather syrupy for the style , but that 's really the only downside to this beer .

copper.. amber.. crystal clear appearance , wow amazing clarity , with more of a , fruity- aroma than a basic citrus . if you are a fan of ipas ... try it , i am fully enjoying this- the price is right and a great change of pace with more of a quality brew * ipa* then there base pale ale .  the most beautiful head is formed on top of this beer . the head is about 3 fingers tall and one full finger of that is above the rim of the glass . great body and form in the head . yeasty appearance with one column of carbonation rising to the top to replenish the head and keep it consistently stiff .  m : heavy body with a very sticky feel .

the aroma consists of wheaty tange , lemmon , and a musty note . a nice tarte flavor that takes this nice clean wheat beer and makes it so refreshing it would be perfect to drink on a sweltering hot day .  definitely in the extreme beer area , the appearance is a beautiful amber red with a rocky off white head that recedes to lacing .  thin to medium bodied and silky smooth on the pallet . finishes thinnish , more in the personality of a dark mild than a porter . this vintage brit held up incredibly well . aside from being flat with an expected cardboard note , it was very enjoyable .
