aroma : light , grassy hops over a sweet cereal-grain malt body . a little light at first , but as it warms the intensity perks and there 's even a whiff of booze to be found on occasion . drinkability : easily drinkable , especially given the moderately-high alcohol content .  pours a deep opaque black body with a vigorous caramel colored head . the head is very thick with large bubbles that pop and take away some of the mass of the head after the initial pour .  feel is not as creamy and soft as i probably expected .

the major scents i get are alcohol , maple syrup-meets malt syrup , and vague hints of cinnamon . the nose is a bit of a let-down , but everything is there for the taste buds to enjoy .  pours with an orange-amber body topped by a thick off-white long lasting head with lots of lacing .  man does this go down easy ... juicy orange with a bit of tanginess . in the nose of this beer . i had this after a session of lawn mowing and it was quaffable.i am just starting to venture into fruity flavors having been a hop dog for a while . i was pleasantly surprised at how quenching these beers are .

s - it is a little mettalic smelling , but still fine .  pours with a big , fluffy head reminiscent of frothy egg-whites and lacing is left done the sides of the glass as the foam settles . the color is very hazy yellow .  mouthfeel : medium light , i would like to see a bit more body .

s - not a whole lot to the nose . hazelnut , and a very light toasted coffee hint . slightest hint of rum . really no hop presence at all .  pours a semi hazy yellow with a fluffy golden head . beautiful .  i 'm not going to do a full review from this one tasting . just wanted to note that this draft example , which i had with lunch at an uno 's chicago pizza restaurant , was a tall glass of diacetyl soup . in fact , i sent it back and the waitress brought me a perfectly drinkable half moon wheat to help wash down my pizza , and to remove the rancid-butter slick from my mouth left by the sam adams . i am normally a fan of sam adams beers -- they do a very nice job on a wide variety of brews . this one was simply yucky . however , in the previous ba reviews of this beer , i do n't see others who encountered the diacetyl bomb , so i 'll give sam a fair second chance .

s - ah , this redeems itself a bit with the weak , but vanilla infused nose . not really complex , but pleasant . t - this starts out slightly tangy and spicy , but then immediately falls flat on it 's face .  massive carbonation dances in the glass with beautiful two plus inch head that stays around for the whole beer that looks like active yeast fermenting .  m & d -- mouthfeel 's a tad too spritzy for me .

the smell was very strong and overpowering raspberry , to the point of smelling like a flavor-syrup additive .  opens with a vigorous whoosh and despite a gentle decant , foams up quickly , forming a meringue-like light tan head which peaks out of the glass about 2 inches , and leaving sticky gobs of foam on the glass as it recedes . cloudy mahogany , near black .  tripel grain tripel , 33 cl bottle . mentioned as the same beer the brewery started producing at their 15 year anniversary . very malty taste too . aftertaste is rather sweet for a tripel . malty . the alcohol comes through quite strong , but it is n't too harsh . overall it 's a well crafted beer ... like many other tripels .

s faint smell of chocolate and wood , roasted malts .  2008 vintage a- pours near pitch black into my ithaca tulip glass . three fingers of thick and sticky foam float upon this brew ! tons and tons of soapy lacing all over the glass ! to dark to see if any carbonation is flowing .  finished clean with a slight taste of alcohol mouthfeel : a bit thinner than i would expect for a brown .

sweet malts were prominent on the nose but there was a very slight hint of hops as well . because of its mildness and hint of sweetness , i think this would be pretty good with spicy or heavily seasoned food .  pours a cloudy orange color with a very tall white head that sticks to the glass extremely well .  m : medium bodied and medium-low carbonation . has a water like texutre that i am not fond of for a ris , but it 's still good .

aroma is the weak spot , but still shows some malt and hop character . flavor has some depth to it and is very complex , with a nice balance between bold hop and malt notes . very nice mouth feel to this bad boy .  poured to a slightly hazy red-orange , with a thick off-white head that lingered for the entire glass and left great lacing .  presented in a clear bottle , should have known what to expect . smells of raw chicken , a terrible skunkiness , overpowers everything . does not taste very well eighter , could keep drinking it , but i do n't really want to . should not have been in a clear bottle .

aroma is muted , but some toasted grain aroma comes through . the flavor is pretty big , and is dominated by toasted grains , some caramel , and alcohol .  this beer poured with an easy and fluffy light-tan head . the body looked black until it is held up to a light where it becomes a dark ruby .  mf : light , perhaps a bit watery , carbonation comes off slightly weak .

this brew also had a very mild aroma . it too was hard for me to distinguish from other smells . it has a very light orange color with yeast particles floating in it . the carbonation once again rolls off the tongue . it is adding to my buzz tonight . this brew is very potent and it added to my buzz for the evening .  poured from the bottle a hazy , sunset orange with a massive , four-inch pillowy head . a nice cap of head remains throughout the life of the beer , as does some lacing . this is as pretty a hefe as i 've seen .  m : combination , lime tang drinkability : yes yes yes ... football beer

this beer reminded me immediately of ballast point 's dorado in the pour , and in a rather welcoming sense in that i knew i would n't have to chew through the malt structure to find any flavor . smell was a bit of a disappointment given my expectations . a good dose of citrus ; grapefruit and tropical notes were present , but not much in the hops department aside of the fruit . hop 15 is in the name more than the nose for this particular pour .  glassware - imperial pint appearance - pours a coca cola color with a 3+ finger off-white head and a lot of lacing . there is a thin cap all the way down the glass which is very nice . very cleansing .  m- creamy and watery with booze burn d- overly sweet and skunky with booze taste .

mild hops , not bitter at all . very smooth and easy to drink . a great example of a red / amber ale .  big , fluffy white head with lots of retention and some lacing . a great looking beer .  m : on the light end of medium bodied , the carbonation level is very high . its only flaw is the carbonation level - which leads to a seemingly thin and effervescent mouthfeel .

smell is pretty tame , almost nondescript , a tingle of rye & alcohol , nothing more .  pours a thick creamy head atop a golden orange body .  very metallic aftertaste flavour is sour . i do n't know what to think . this is n't good at all . drain pour , unfortunately .

round dark malt aroma is the first impression i have on the smell . for an ipa , it 's unusual to have such a low level of hop ... it smells closer to a english mild .  great head retention .  m : a little on the light side of medium bodied , and i 'm afraid my somewhat rough pour put almost all of the carbonation into the fantastic head - it feels a bit flat .

cloudy , yet easy to see through . nutty , hints of tea with subtle sweet spices : nutmeg , cinnamon . easy to drink . well balanced . the beginning is more of an intro .  it leaves webs and webs of excellent sticky lacing . body is a hazy gold . looks great .  frist sip reveals an average body but a little thin on the finish .

everything i look for in a marzen smell : sweet caramel malt dominates . a slight floral/herbal hop scent rides below .  750ml bottle , thanks brad ! pours a very slightly hazy honey orange with a fine soapy head . awesome lacing .  the body feels medium to light on the palate , smooth and refreshing , it carries the day .

not much of an aroma , but the flavor presents nice profiles of plum and a chalky roastiness .  appearance : this poured beautifully with a heavy full head colored orange/tan .  just like my review of pale malt , i think it 's not right to go into a lengthy dissertation on the merits and demerits of this beer as there 's clearly something wrong at the brewery . all of the great grains beers have an intense sourness to them that 's more than just poor judgment being exercised in the brewery 's stylistic interpretation . tornado seems to suffer the worst from this infection problem of all the gg beers i 've tried . the green apple flavor that lends the beer an `` interesting '' tartness when it 's really fresh ( like the day i bought some off the brewery delivery truck ) turned into an overwhelming acid bath for my mouth after about 3 or 4 days of rest in the refrigerator . it 's really too bad that my only local microbrewery makes tainted beer ...

still some nice lacing on my chimay glass . the aroma is quite subtle with some yeast , citrus fruits and a grassy or straw scent .  a- poured a pitch black , darkest beer since bt for me and the 2 fingers of dark brown head with light lacing and clumps of foamy lacing . really nice start to this beer .  actually quite a bit thicker and smoother than pilsner urquell .

s - the smell is a little elusive for me . but i am getting smells of malt and a bit of nuttiness .  has a healthy head at the initial pour of foamy off white that reduces to something a bit thinner but sticks around for the entire time . lacing is more like a thin layer of foam that sticks to the side of the glass .  light in body , but not watery . a small amount of carbonation livens the beer , but does not define it .

poured from a 12 ounce bottle into a pint glass . good lacing . taste : good roasty flavor . biscuity and caramel .  this beer pours a dark , dark brown color through which almost no light can pass .  mouthfeel is medium bodied , a little thinner than i would prefer , perfect carbonation for a stout .

the smell is very mild with a light bit of biscuity malt .  an absolutely beautiful beer .  pours a clear burgundy with a small tan head , good lacing . smell is of sour malt , dark fruit , touch of caramel , and some woodiness . taste is dry up front , caramel , prunes , raisins , sour malt , and a little hop bitterness in the end . overall a nice old ale that improves as it warms .

s : the aroma is a mild coffee and roast barley with a sharpness typical of any beer poured from a widget can . t : : the first flavor is a mild roastiness with a light coffee undertone .  a - pours deep black with a one finger chocolatey head - looks fantastic s - smells of chocolatey malts and a touc of coffee .  palate was light to medium bodied , slightly oily , lively carbonated moderately astringent in its sourness and lightly alcoholic .

the smell is pretty mild , without a ton of hop aroma .  the pint glass was filled with a black liquid with a tan 2 '' head . the head lasted quite a while and some nice lacing developed .  m-very creamy , very light bodied .

this is a mellow double ipa . i would categorize this ale to be on the sweeter side with some but not over empowering hops . the ability to drink this ale is great , such a nice mellow sweet , with just a hint of hops in the back ground . the sweet hits the tongue , then shortly after the hops . tastes very much like a red versus a ipa . this beer snaps at you when tasting it , it comes on so mellow , then all of a sudden you feel the hops . definitely not an 90 minute ipa but is quite a nice choice .  the visual elegance was defined by a sensual clouded auburn color with persistent carbonation .  mouthfeel : appropriate .

good looking pale ale . odor kind of weak , a tiny bit of malt and hops evident .  stayed with me all the way down to the last drop , leaving an amazing ring lace . check out my twitter for the picture , it makes me very happy .  i 'd say it 's medium bodied with the carbonation on the light side ; the mouthfeel is n't all that good but it 's tasty and easy to drink so i give it a thumbs up .

pours an effervescent apricot with 3+ fingers of sand colored head.good head retention & lacing s : slight breadyness t : slight breadyness & peppery hops up front , along with a bit of piney hops .  looks mighty fine thus far ... smell & gt ; but wait ! is that notes of metallic amongst the grain ? taste & gt ; way too bitter and metallic .  the beer is tasty ... not too heavy despite the high abv . here is my first complaint : i consumed 6 bottles of these plus 3 rogue dead guy ale 's and got only a slight buzz . the feel and drinkability of this beer kind of skew the rating , but if that is what you are after , then you have found your soulmate . worth a drink , ( or two or seven ) to get the full affect .

looks a lot like a stout . s : i get some roasty bitter chocolate upfront with some vanilla and cocoa in the middle and hints of cherries on the backend . ok. t : bitter , cigarette-like , roastiness upfront with some hints of cherry in the middle and some cocoa on the backend . more like a good standard stout .  pretty good retention . looks very inviting .  taste : crisp carbonation holds a light to medium body .

aroma - very soft , grainy sniff . given a chance , though , partial redemption occurs as the beer settles , allowing some candi sugar and yeast scents to emerge . light but persistent . mouthfeel - big beer body , the carbonation is elegant , a top shelf effort . now , make an 'everyday ' ginger beer , affordably .  in this heat ( 97f as i type ) , this beer looks beautifully refreshing .  m & d : light to medium body , but overly carbonated imo . the carbonation makes for a brew that stings a bit on the way down .

not much aroma except some faint roasted malt , wonderful roast malt , chocolate malt flavor balanced with hops . finish is smooth that begs for another draught .  appearance is perfect - clear ruby with a long lasting cream colored head and great lacing .  m - dry feel on my tongue while the rest of my mouth experiences a wetness . there is certainly a coarse feel to this brew as well . ~ this a a very good beer .

s : up-front notes of a belgian yeast-like character , some yams come through on the nose but not as much as i was expecting . overall the nose seems extremely muted though our glassware could be to blame for this . not overly impressed here . a really nice beer for the fall , something to warm you up , and fill with flavors of the holiday season .  the lacing is again epic . three finger head and the retention is going on five minutes .  the carbonation is above-average for a stout , which makes the mouthfeel not quite as smooth as it should be , for having oatmeal in the recipe .

smell is pretty dull , wheat malt and a hint of lemon , not as fragrant as franziskaner .  i would normally hate to say anything bad about my favorite domestic beer company , but this scotch ale was simply a huge disappointment . it pours a beautiful dark amber , which would lead me to believe i was about to enjoy another wonderful sam adams ale , but that is not the case .  m -- for me personally , it has the mouthfeel of a good coffee stout . a bit thick , but it works .

the appearance was eye candy to me ! the aroma was light with some pucker grapefruit , a drop of lemon , and ended with a hint of lightly bitter citrus hops .  at breakfast this brew pours a dark , dark reddish brown like used motor oil . there is a big creamy head -- tiny bubbles . the head remains the entire time , leaving tons of ring lacing .  light body .

smell : very mild as only some soft roasted malts were detecable . taste : light roasted malts , dark chocolate , molasses , light bitterness , and hints of nuts made up a very nicely flavored porter . drinkability : very easy drinking porter . recommend this one over the stout if you only have time for one pint .  appearance : a nice amber transparent colored beer with hues of orange . great retention . stays with a sheet of head forever .  this does mean that it is pretty thin on the mouth though .

organic . floral .  i let it warm some out of the fridge and it poured with an amazingly slow to settle , foamy , super frothy , fluffy , iight , off-white head and loads of clingy lace .  mouthfeel is some-what sharp .

i had this while grilling steaks , salmon and a burger for dinner . fairly sweet , but not in a bad way . it complemented the food , but yet still stood on its own ( big bottle so it lasted through cooking until eating ) .  the thistle illustration is beautiful - so much so that i was distracted from the beauty of the beer itself for a moment . bole and copper body with faint ruby highlights - however , when held to the light , the glass glows a stunning alizarin crimson . two fingers of foam reduce to a dense stack of steamed-milk . wonderful retention . heavy legs and thick uniform lacing slather the sides of the glass .  m - the feel was not tremendously enhancing . it was a wee bit thin , and just did n't feel terribly exciting , if that makes any sense .

here you have a very drinkable beer with one caveat . if you 're going to eat , do so beforehand or during your first pint . of course , it does go well with seafood , as said aftertaste is citrus-esque . the overall effect enhances the citrus ( obviously ) and lends a certain sweetness to the beer .  the color was a beautifull hazy and cloudy honey gold .  eli 's is n't a bottled brew . it 's made specially for eli cannon 's a pub in middletown , ct ( i called to ask ) by shipyard . while i expect it is an honest mistake , the shipyard pumpkin the previous reviewer is describing was n't eli 's pumpkin patch but a different variety ( shipyard pumpkinhead ? ) . though i have not had in years since i moved away , has remained my all-time favorite pumpkin beer . on my next trip back i 'll leave a proper review .

some mild lacing develops . smell : very soft hints of caramel , brown sugar sweetness , and whiff of hop bitterness .  appearance - it 's a stout . it 's black when held up to a light . smell - pours a good thick foamy head .  starts out sweet ... finishes with a nutty flavor with a hint of hops ... very light m- pretty typical d- extremely light and easy to drink . a very refreshing beer ... easy to enjoy on a hot day

s - light hops , fruity , soft banana scent . t - delicious !  ( served in a tulip glass ) a- this beer has a dark opaque black body with a hint of light at the base of the glass showing a warm deep brown hue . there is a sea of micro bubbles racing back and forth to the surface where a thick light tan head stands .  mouthfeel - bubbly .
aroma is nothing special on this one - very average . sam you 're a crafty one - no pun intended .  a : pours a dark brown body with a tan head .  mouthfeel is a bit thin .

i was n't overly impressed with the smell , however the taste ; of dark chocolate , coffee and cinnamon more then made up for it .  a- a hard pour yields about three finger of the most brilliant white head that holds and holds . after a bit the head begins settle but not before it leaves behind a massive amount of chunky sticky lace all over the glass and a killer sudsy cap .  watery mouthfeel , slick and low carbonation presence .

great head retention & lacing s : sweetness & malt t : herbal hops & honey malts up front .  orangish , red brew with light tan head that laces down the side of the glass .  m- im used to some more carbonation from my belgians , thats the only serious complaint i have about this brew .

aroma- very subdued . has little smell at all . a good beer to quaff while sitting in front of the fire or watching the rain .  a- a deep , bright rube orange liquid with just the right amount of haze to it to give it a nice crystal ball effect . the bone white head is very creamy and settles to a craggy covering . perfect .  the beer has a medium body with a nice quick bitter sweet finish . fff 's describes this beer as a belgian ale . maybe a little bit off base for this style , but it is a beer that i could find myself sitting down and drinking again .

no real aroma-rather 1 dimensional-somewhat roasted tinge . good amount of roasted flavor-just a hint of harshness to it .  i 've always liked the rounded edges to the bottle and the label looks classy as well . for the style its perfect to near perfect appearance .  the carbonation is pretty low , would have liked a bit more .

s : spicy cinnamon ( like big red ) is the first thing that hit me . winter warmer is n't my favorite style but i do n't dislike it by any means ... this one just did n't do it . it 's very unfortunate , too , since glbc is one of my favorite breweries .  dull glowing amber pour with a monumental head of densely whipped merangue froth that lasts for the duration of the beer . simply beautiful to behold .  stiff pour resulted in tannish head that quickly dissolved . light lacing once the beer settled down . color - nice cooper/brown , with little carbination . initial smell was of hard water/metal and hint of grain . however by mid-beer the smell had changed to pleasant carmel , which encouraged more consumption ... overall good , not great . my expectations were slightly higher than results as sprecher has solid lineup .

a - pours a pale copper color with a one-finger head s - smells of some faint caramel and toasted malts . m - slick , buttery mouthfeel with a full body and a nice touch of carbonation d - this is very good beer . very malty and full of flavor , it is really easy to drink .  the beautiful black color and creamy head are wonders to behold .  m : a very very mild carbonation on a medium full body .

potteri smells distinctly of caramel and sugar . surprisingly , the start is imperceptibly smooth and light .  this beer looks great poured out of the bottle with a big billowy head and cloudy golden color .  m : a little on the lighter side .

the smell of a spicy hop filled my nose which was the tops of this beer . one on my 10 most awful beers on my list !  leaving some lovely lacing . a gorgeous looking beer .  taste : very to the point , the dry hops and yeast bring forth a tangy-sourness ; soft at start and throughout but sour at the finish , which als has a lightly spicy lingering . overall : on point ; first experience with jpaa , ingredients are well utilized that makes for a well-sequenced , very drinkable .

the smell is very vinous and tart , with a big sour and funky nose .  bottle : poured a medium brown color ale with a huge foamy head with good retention and lacing .  m- medium body with low/medium carbonation .

a - very mild roasted malt aroma .  appearance : as with most sierra bottles , this bomber was gorgeous , with a pretty green wax covering the cap . once it was open the estate poured an opaque golden orange with a big , thick , two finger head in a large snifter . the lacing was outstanding , covering about 80 % of the glass .  strong carbonation and a bit of head that does n't last long . too heavy in the mouth but the carbonation is pretty decent and works .

smell- a little sweaty but eventually shows the a decent roasted and lightly smoked malt aroma .  poured from a bottle into a pint glass a - beautiful golden color , almost orange , this beer almost looks like it is glowing , small white head is present s - nice sweet , citrus hop smell t - the hoppy bitterness seems to wrap around and pummel my tongue , a nice malty sweetness up front , the hops really seem to linger after swallowing this one causing me to take another swallow , the bitterness present makes me think dipa not ipa m - mild carbonation and a medium body d - i really enjoy this beer , if this was available near me this would be a regular .  mouthfeel : a bit light for the style imo ; seems just a tad watered down drinkability : pretty high conclusion : not the best american porter i 've ever had , but pretty tasty overall .

s ) not much going on but a pleasant smell of light grains and a faint hop smell .  pours a dark ruby red color with a huge ( and i mean huge ) pinkish head , looks like candy , the real catch though is the amount of sticky clumpy lacing that just sticks to the glass as this thing fades .  m/d - full flavored but thin and watery on the feel .

didnt have a lot of aroma , but left laces all the way down the pint glass . this winter warmer had a nice , woody , spicy taste that finished with a hoppy kick .  the head has excellent retention and is of an off white caramel color . an absolute gorgeous appearance however the flavors lack balance .  light-medium ( leans light ) bodied due to carbonation levels .

this one has session beer written all over it . an agreeable tasting amber ale with finely balanced malt and hops . i enjoyed it enough to have a second pint .  750ml into a tulip . pours a rich dark copper garnet , i love beer this shade . head is towering , dense , small bubbles slowly recedes .  mouthfeel is smooth , having been bottle conditioned , but it 's a bit too thin .

smell : not too much for the nose on this one . i find a little spiciness followed with some sweetness . taste : this is one damn tasty beer ! from homebrewing i know the smell and taste of the centennial hop and it is really apparent on the back end of the tongue and lingers around until the flavor leaves the mouth . seek it out , it did not blow me away but it certainly is a great ipa .  see through body with an tremendous white head !  mouthfeel : crisp and surprisingly refreshing .

the aroma has a touch of vinous characteristics and a low hint of grainy malt . the nose is light and subtle but the flavor is complex . it is strong and bold , and reminds me of rosewood aromas . the light body with high levels of carbonation allow the brew to dance on the palate .  the lacing was almost indescribable ... more a sticky , continuous coating vs. gobs & bits .  mouthfeel is a tad too sticky but the drinkabilty is excellent .

smell is a little weak , but the ginger does come through . that experience made me a fan of gingers and this is a solid , refreshing example of the style .  one half of the black and tan and the yin-yang . a : pours pitch black with medium tan head .  fairly thin mouthfeel and high carbonation , it fits the style , but i 'd have preferred a bit more body and less gas .

the saranack adirondack lager is also listed as a pilsener but this is much better . some nice fruity taste , well bodied , and highly carbonated which makes for a great beer .  pours an opaque black with dark brown and red highlights , medium sized thick brown head forms , looks like tar , settles to a thin ring quickly , drops a ton of lace , this stuff is dark !  taste : starts with a sweetness that is cut by the carbonation . mouth : smooth carbonation not harsh drink : its malty start and earthy bitterness makes this beer more enjoyable the flavor from the finish and the start mix quite well .

the slightly fruity and very slighty spicy aroma left alot to be desired , this was probably the only let down in the bottle .  a swirl is a beauty to behold . the head here is an irregular film and a dark tan collar .  mouthfeel is full of carbonation , and has some burnt afterburn ... mf is maybe the only thing i did n't particularly care for .

pours and looks like a lager , kinda smells like one too . nice rich lush mouthfeel .  a : pours an absolutely massive cream colored orange-tinged head beneath a hazy orange-copper body . when it finally receded it left tons of thick , sticky lacing on the glass and a solid 1/2 to 3/4 inch of foam retained atop the beer . looks great , i must say .  the mouthfeel is a bit thin as far as stouts are concerned , but it 's not so watery as to ruin the experience .

s- smell is somewhat subpar . grassy and a touch malty .  the beer poured a beautiful ruby black with a big pillowy tan head .  smell : piney , tangy hops , with sweet velevety belgian yeast undertones . taste : begins mellow , develops quickly into piney notes , slight belgian undertones , finishes crisp with a piney bitterness . overall : nice example of a belgian ipa , well-hopped and has the best of both worlds , decent abv as well .

smell : grassy and citrus hops in the nose , also a subtle apple scent . i do n't usually pick up pale ales because i 'm a hop head and i figure , why not grab an ipa ?  wow what a beautiful beer . pitch dark black with a creamy 3 finger mocha colored head .  m : light and corbonated d : very drinkable pumpkin ale that is not overdone at all .

the smell is very light although complex with detectable aroma 's of caramel and cloves .  very nice 1/4 inch thick tan head on top . just an all round perfect looking beer .  the mouth feel is somewhat watery , light in body but has a nice medium amount of malt flavor .

i have not had a wide variety of pilseners , but from what ive come to expect from them was a little different than what i got here . for me this beer had a nice hoppy flavor and great drink-ability , another good entry from sammy  appearance was black , dark amber if you put a light through it . head was a brown-tan color and very puffy ; it dissipated relatively quickly but left lacing from top to bottom .  palate is average , could be more carbonated .

perfectly black with a dense head of tight-bubbled bright tan froth . the aroma is slightly off-color though not unreasonably so . i 'd be a little off-color myself if i had to sit in an aluminum can for a month . but sometimes a kiss is worth more than a f**k. beamish is like that .  i really loved the regular yeti and this has the similar beautiful dark body and chocolate milk head the oak changes the rest of the beer .  mouthfeel is a little on the thin side .

this beer makes up for in tart , biting , delicious sour flavor where it lacks in aroma . nearly perfect . a delicious and classic example of the style -- disappointed i could n't pull off more aroma from this one .  got this at de bierkoning in amsterdam ... drank from a trappistes rochefort glass ... pour : one of the most beautiful colors i 've seen on a beer ... thick head with awesome lacing ... abundant carb ... smell : earthy tone ... hops and yeast ?  i tend to prefer it that way , although it 's not extremely strong with malts , and might be a bit thin in the mouth .

s : not a lot on the nose except for smooth sweet dark malts and milk chocolate . t : heavy up front with the espresso and a light chocolate malt follow up .  huge rocky frothy white head , lasting a while .  m - feels like a normal ris .

s - grapfruit and not much else . i 'm shocked at the nose though , just not much hear .  pours a deep copper-red with a huge long lasting orange-brown head that laces the glass .  poor example of a pilsner , surprised how this beer makes it out of thebrewery . lots of off flavours , both in the nose and aroma . clarity is not good either , unless they are shooting for a kellerbier which this does not taste close to . i enjoy other mill st beers but this one is sub par . it could be a great beer but needs more attention in the brewhaus .

considering the best by date was 2 weeks ago , this beer was quite impressive . tasted much better than most other euro pale lager beers .  beautiful brown colour with about 1 and a half thick head and lacing that stayed on through the last drop .  carbonation is average and alcohol is invisible .

smell : faint scent of chocolate and coffee ... not a very complex aroma . taste/mouthfeel : caramel , currant , chocolate sweetness up-front , not cloying , balanced by bitter , astringent finish .  pours with a deep red body topped by a thick creamy head with lots of lacing .  only fault is perhaps excessive carbonation , but i 'm getting more sensitive to that so maybe it 's my problem .

the smell is rather light for a big brew . some light roasted malt notes with a bit stronger nose of black liquorice .  one inch light beige head with smaller carbonation bubbles , but visible rising carbonation along the edge of the snifter . the head shrinks very slowly down to about a half finger . a deep , dark , opaque burgundy color . lacing is thick and of a grainy appearance , but it slowly recedes .  mouthfeel is smooth and even , but a tad thin for an ris ( that 's really my only criticism for this one ) .

leffe blonde pours 2 1/2 fingers of bone-white froth atop a light , golden body , outstanding , and the ommegang glass is exquisitely laced on the way down . the nose is disappointing -- a good deal of wheat comes forth but dominates .  a - pours a luscious black with a dense head . it looks exactly the way a stout should .  the mouthfeel is medium , lightly carbonated and slightly watery .
nice caramel aroma . very smooth and drinkable .  a perfect looking lager .  m - near medium body : a tad too thin ; carbonation is light-medium ; near creamy , yet with a slightly dry finish .

this beer smells musty ! but it 's the sort of friendly musty smell of clothes you wore to the beach and let dry out on a sunny day .  unquestionably , the best aspect of this beer was its beautiful , deep , dark pink color . it arrived with no head , but instead , just a white ring around the edge of the glass .  what balance ? ! this is typically not the style i chase after , but being in switzerland , this was one of the few beers that i could find plenty of . the name sounded nice , so i risked trying a 1l as it would be cheaper in the long run , and i did n't expect this brew to be too offensive . it 's smell was n't rediculous , but the head was big and frothy , yet not long lasting . i would have to say this is a nicely balanced beer that i believe anyone could enjoy . if you are stranded in switzerland and see this brew , give it a try as it is quite tastey . after having another swiss beer , this one gives me hope . i look forward to trying more swiss lagers in the near future .
smell : nice rich malt flavor with a spiced hops aftertaste .  one of the nicest looking beers ever !  m - medium body - nothing remarkable , but no complaints here .

not overpowering in the smell department . roasty malt distant caramel is what i can detect .  the first thing i notice about this beer is it 's fantastic color- it 's a beautiful coppery orange .  m : good amount of carbonation for the style .

not a whole lot of foam here , at least from the pov of a belgian fan . smell was mild and had a wheatie afterkick . taste was buttery with hints of hops .  the pour was nice . rich dark brown in color with a huge head of tan that came up and over the top of the glass , reaching a height of close to two inches and staying there for quite some time . very impressive side lacing as well let me know this was not one to be taken terribly lightly in any means !  mouthfeel seemed thicker than a typical barley wine should be ... i liked it but not following the style i guess .

the smell is very light with some nice caramel notes .  pours beautiful deep ruby color with good clarity and a inch and a half of frothy head .  it smelled like sour cheap grains , maybe a little more sour than the smell of most cheap beers . my favourite thing about this beer was the name .

the aroma actually is pretty malty but with plenty of american hoppiness too ... balanced but fairly nondescript i would say .  a wonderful looking beer ! it looks like a thick pour of apple cider with a frothy head and noticable spices/sediment in the glass .  mouthfeel : kind of thin , which is to be expected .

dry though its taste and afterwards , with roasted grainy taste on the subtle side . great *irish* stout ( not to purposely compare with some very great domestic varieties ) .  reviewed 9/24/2008 ( draft @ flying saucer , houston , tx ) : pours a very dark red-brown colored body , somewhat transparent looking , with a big frothy off-white head .  m : feel was some what thin , a little less cloudy than most belgians .

smell : diacetyl , muscat grapes .  look : orange yellow color , cloudy , huge dense fluffy head with uber good retention and lacing smell : blast of brett funk , with cloves , pepper , citrus taste : up front : brett funk , spices .  the mouthfeel is a bit thin .

*** malty aroma , light-bodied and pleasant enough . there is a slight pale malt , but the smell is overall very hard to detect .  this has a real nice dark brown almost black color . i could drink this beer forever and it is quite cheap .  m- medium in body and very low in carbonation . almost seems flat and a bit dry .

the smell is light straw smell with a bit citrus edge . very faint smelling , not too strong a stink . the hops in this show up much more in the flavor than the smell . the bitter herbal resinous hops rest underneath a crisp citrus edge on top .  presentation : 33cl bottle , poured into my achel chalice appearance : a dark garnet , clear as a gem , with a beautiful frothy tan head that lasted for the duration . very good visual appeal .  mouthfeel might be a touch thin , and it leaves my mouth sticky , but i think holiday porter 's other qualities redeem it , and i thoroughly enjoyed both bottles from the twelve pack .

unfortunately , not much is coming through the nose . a bit of the sweetness that crystal malt delivers , but not a whole lot more . taste is quite pleasant . this would be a nice session beer . it 's a classic amber ale -- flavorful without being assertive , and it 's got a decent american hop backbone to support it . mothfeel is good enough for the style , and drinkability is pretty darned good .  a superb cappucino-brown one-finger head tops a rich clear mahogany body . appearance is spectacular .  carbonation is average , giving this a boring mouthfeel .

cascade hops hit my nose for the most part . somewhat weak presentation on the nose . was hoping for more .  sedimented bottom , and a lasting , sticky head , with plenty of lacing .  feels slick and under carbonated .

the bottle opens with a very light odor of vanilla , but otherwise smells like any other quality american porter .  pours an opaque dark red with a large , fizzy light pink head that lasts . looks like a glass of blood with some sediment mixed in .  m : ok , not as smooth as i would have hoped , somewhat coats the mouth , medium body .

i admit , this is my favorite american light lager beer . i would have to brew a batch of sam without the hops to compare the malts . it has a slight aroma of maltiness , and a little alcohol smell . it is smooth , has some flavor , and is cheap .  5.0 a : exceptional appearance . dark , very dark brown color . two plus fingers of super creamy head with great retention and glass coating amounts of lacing .  m- light and watery - not much body at all d- smooth finish i recommend this one on taste alone .

s. malt with subtle hop profile . t. sweet malty goodness up front with a hop backbone .  a- poured into my corsondonk crystal stemware , haha ... a nice brown head erupts , piling above the rim of the glass without tumbling down the side . i slowly recedes leaving some spotted clumps of lacing stuck to the glass . the beer is black in color and stays black even when held up to light s- kind of mild smelling ... notes of coffee , chocolate , and malt t- very nice .  mouthfeel is much fuller but less creamy than the draught version , extremely dry and carbonation is n't overbearing .

looking for the aroma here , it is not very potent . there is some light citrus fruit notes but they are hidden . in the ipa family , this is the clean cut yet laid-back uncle : tastes are clean , refined , refreshing and subtle which make this beer a very enjoyable spring/summer drink .  the beer pours motor oil black with a tiny mocha head . very slow and viscous pour , noticable from the moment the beer leaves the can . additionally this is as black as beer gets , some deep brown highlights on the edges but no light penetrates it , impressive .  served at `` free '' beer party - 2008 at taco mac lindbergh in celebration of the 75 anniversary of the end of prohibition . smells of malts and bourbon . no carbonation - but who cares when it tastes so good ? the barrel aging brings all of donkey punch 's normally well hidden abv , to the front of the class .

aroma is a slightly subdued but pleasant sweet citrus hop aroma with a hint of grapefruit .  tremendous head and excellent light orange/yellow color . highly carbonated .  mouthfeel - does n't have the full on body of a double , and the carbonation is on the flatter side , making this feel that much thinner .

poured into a pint glass from the bottle very beautiful straw gold color with faint orangish hues at times . the aroma is n't very stong , but it has a distinct hop aroma , followed by an aroma of sweet grains . overall i really enjoy this pilsner . it is very drinkable and would make a nice thirst quencher on a hot day . this would be a good cross-over beer for macro lager drinkers .  it 's a great looking cloudy orange-red with three fingers of tan creamy head that just hangs on and on .  the feel is pretty average , neither watery nor full nor interesting .

s. honestly a little flat due to the powerful wheat and yeast , i get wheat , yeast and a citrus-apple mix . a good beer with good drink-ability overall .  pours dark amber with a half-inch fluffy , light beige head . outstanding head retention , eventually settling into lots of lacing .  it 's pretty interesting , and good m- it 's actually a little too thick for me .

smell is clean , thin malt , with a little smoke at the end .  once it settled down it was hazy golden/yellow color with a huge , foamy and thick white head . it excellent head retention and left some of the thickest lacing on the glass i 've ever seen .  the mouthfeel is kinda sticky and medium bodied , but once you drink about half of one , you feel very refereshed , even for the relative bitterness .

s - smelled like a lager sort of to me . i didnt like the smell that much but smells are decieving .  appearance : beautiful clear golden orange with a dark off-white head that disipates and leves nice lacing in a chimay goblet .  the mouthfeel was a bit thinner than i would have hoped .

not much aroma at all . a tiny bit of citrusy hops , but that 's it . tastes wonderful . not sweet , just clean , bitter hops . good carbonation makes the mouthfeel perfect for an ipa . smuttynose in florida , hooray !  pours an insane head with a nice cloudy orange color . retention sticks around forever .  the mouthfeel , however , was watery for a porter , the body medium and the carbonation light . highly quaffable .

the smell is a little muted , the malt and chocolate is there like you 'd expect just not as strong as i 'd like to smell . a little bit of raisin in there as well . in my opinion , a very well done imperial stout .  the beer is a very pretty dark amber color and looks great when held up to a light .  i 'm suprised how fast this fades , leaves a clean mouthfeel at the finish , not a thick palette coater by any means , but all this does is make you drink it faster .

grainy nose , but not a prominent one at all .  this is just a fantastic looking beer s : piney , citrus notes with a good malt backbone to that backs it up with a touch of sweetness t : more on the bitter side but it has balance as i detected malty sweetness towards the end m : medium-body with a dry finish that highlights the hop prfile d : overall this is a really good apa , definitely put a few of these away ... tasty beverage .  m- tingly sensation that makes you want more .

a wondefully huge head of light tope that rises about four fingers with great retention and equally outstanding lacing that looks like coral reef ... the aroma sadly does n't have that much going on , a little sweet bread but mostly some light hops , i 'm disappointed ... the taste is better , a nice balance of sweetness on the front with a strong hop presence throughout .  this is a beautiful looking beer .  thanks dan for bringing this one to ratman 's last night ; i 'd been wanting to try something from this brewery for a while now . i was a little surprised at how thin this one was , and incorrectly assumed its abv to be around 5 % . the bourbon does a nice job merging with the chocolate , roast malt and smoke on the palate . nice .

s- smells good , but nothing outstanding . but what i can smell is good , just not as strong as i would expect from an iipa .  pours a fantastic , rich tan head that looks like puffy clouds that you could jump in .  m - rolling carbonation makes the brew pleasantly refreshing and very quaffable , though perhaps a little too effervescent . body is lighter than i would like .

i am not a huge lager fan , wheat beers are not my thing ... . and red beer ... i think red dog ... well i was very let down by the taste of their ipa , the beer was a total let down on taste , it tasted like a watered down ipa , and again the ingredients did not mesh well . i see some people like some of their beers , maybe i was there on a bad day , maybe ... something but i would advise all to avoid this brewery  pours black with a nice two-finger tan head but subsides quickly to a one-finger head and stays throughout . had very nice lacing throughout .  deeper in the beer is quite a bit of caramel malt coming through but the peppery hop aroma is really taking this one away . t= the taste is less hoppy than the smell led on which i find sort of refreshing in a style that is becoming more and more hop centric . the hops that hit the tongue with a sort of spicy peppery taste as i assumed but that is swallowed fast by the delicious caramel malt flavor and a nice bready taste . m= this is the down fall of this beer i think . really just average . its sort of oddly sticky and watery despite the wicked head on it . a very friendly amber ale . tame and still extremely delicious . highly recommended amber ale .
smell is pretty mild .  a : the appearance of this brew is very alluring as it shines a gorgeous orange .  body is a bit thin and alcohol is slightly burning but nothing out of control .
a weird kind of hops glow !  pours clear honey amberwith thick frothy head that is long lived and leaves a nice bubbly lace .  m : a hare thin for the style , a bit hi for the carb .

s- strong alcohol , dark fruits , some sugar , and little else . you can tell it is a booze bomb from the nose alone . t- the flavor is delicious if not complex , especially the aftertaste .  two fingers of incredibly creamy and dense off-white head with sickeningly wonderful retention and tons of sticky lacing .  mouthfeel- medium body . decent co2 level .

color is almost burgandy and pouring it into a glass produces a little head which hung around for a bit . the taste of malt along with the spices pleasures your mouth , making mouthfeel and taste very good and unique . drinkability is good too , even though this stuff is 11 % strong , because while you drink you enjoy it 's unique taste .  a fat three finger khaki head that exhibits fantastic retention and lacing .  still can not get the new belgium offerings in the state of michigan - too bad in my opinion . a friend brought a sampler twelve pack for me to try as i 've only had the fat tire and ranger ipa . of the four in the sampler i believe this is my favorite . it is a good session beer that is not particularly strong or bitter at all .

ofallon is a hell of a brewery . i admit seeing floaties in my bottle kind of makes me a little timid , i wrap this baby up in a cooley and let it rip . a great wheat flavor easy on the stomach . my only lacking point is its alcohol content , its hard to catch a buzz of this stuff . as a social drink its great .  it is impressive .  m - too light for my liking , and sometimes even border-line watery . at least there 's a strong carbonation , and it 's nice to kind of toss around on the tongue to search for the other flavors . still , fairly average .

the smell is dominated by belgian yeast , but the taste is smooth and refreshing with a light slightly citrus finish .  perhaps it was the glass at the bar but it was perfect looking , absolutely outstanding .  the mouthfeel is light .

s : not much smell , just some grains and malt t : nice miniature hop kick and some malt balance , a small bit of grain m : almost like a soda , but a bit thicker .  totally amazing . the lacing was also huge .  wow , just not pleasant at all . the sweetness sometimes bordered on cloying . the vinegar tastes were not so strong as to be basalmic or repugnant , but it was getting there . at least they were a bit more rounded . i regretted ordering this after the first sip , but i did n't want to kill myself while drinking the rest of it , so i guess that 's a plus . we need more good sours to come to texas so i do n't have to subject myself to this as one of our few options !

s : lots of spicy rye . some hops come through past the rye , maybe a bit piney .  poured vigorously , giving a big , billowy light tan head , made up mostly of large bubbles , over two fingers ' worth . sits on top of a very deep ruby , almost black , but reddish highlights do shine through . as head falls over period of a few minutes , leaves big chunky lacing on the glass .  mouthfeel is a bit watery , but so is the original mad hatter in my opinion so that is to be expected .

slight java on the nose as well roast tones . an off aroma . ca n't nail it down though .  from a bottle into the very swanky gordon 's finest gold stylized tulip/snifter glass at aufsturtz in berlin , germany . beautiful beer from the pour . literally a pure gold color - deeper than a more straw color like duvel - with a dense white foam that left the glass well laced .  first sip reveals a lighter body than expected but no watery texture just a little thin , the carbonation is very fine and spacious , again not what i expected .

the bottle calls it an amber lager - seems more in line with a vienna amber ( i.e . solid malt with nice hops balance . tasty and quite drinkable .  love the silver can with the simple one color black print .  mouthfeel was a bit thin , but it would help in sessioning it .

pours a hazy light golden with almost no head to speak of almost looked like pop , aroma is very buttery and grainy alot of diacety for sure here.i noticed this beer has a very harsh mouthfeel and the flavors are harsh up front as well and to buttery.a bitter beer but not from hops let me tell you just a bad beer thru and thru and i thought i was doing a decent thing by buying organic !  a : pours a cloudy amber body with orange tones against the light . has a fairly generous 2 inches of head with pretty good retention , taking between 5-10 minutes to collapse into a lighter cap on top of the brew before i can start drinking .  lack of head on the initial pour but this beer is definitely carbonated .

a very nice looking brown ale . s : nose is nutty . notes of brown sugar , cinnamon spice , and a slight oatmeal tarness are detectable . sweet and enticing but faint overall . nothing to really stir the senses .  750ml bottle , split appearance : photogenic pour in hopleaf tulip - bright orange body , steady white cream head with full retention smell : tart apricot , oak , spicy yeast taste : really nice - tart apricot , peach , funky , white pepper , belgian yeast , tangerine , bright caramelized sugars .  the mouthfeel is a little thin .
kind of unremarkable .  pours a big head that retains very well , and with al= wonderful lacing .  mouthfeel was unexceptional , and light to medium bodied .

it has a dark brown head and smells fairly mild , a little roasty .  this porter pours with a dark brown to black body topped by a medium thick creamy tan head with lots of lacing .  mf - the carbonation is n't very high , giving some it some body .

s : rather weak in smell ... coffee and chocolate - not much else going on . o : a very interesting beer , the only thing i hold against it is the weak smell .  smuttynose really old brown dog is a very clear , dense , brown ale with a generous , thick , dense , foamy yellow head that has incredible retention .  m - thin to medium . lots of carbonation . feels crisp .

smell : from an excellent appearance we segue to an average aroma . malt forward with some hops and caramel but it 's all very muted .  pours out a clear deep mahogany in color with a rising tan head .  the body is a bit heavy for the style .

s-smells interestingly of pineapple , some roasted notes and some chocolate notes ... . kind of a weak nose t-i 'm still getting a bit of that pineapple in the taste with chocolate and some very light roasted notes . the mouthfeel is out of this world and if the nose was a little better , i think this would be an amazing beer .  a : clear , light amber with over one finger of persistent white foam . lacing is heavy on the glass with clear step-wise progression for the first two inches .  a very unique apperance . the taste is very hoppy and refreshing . has a bit of a bite to it . i am not a big fan of ipa 's but i would drink this again .

smell - not much , some burnt sugar notes and a little malt . no significant hop aroma , which is true to style . a modest diacetyl note , a little roastiness , just a touch of high alcohol flavor . drinkability - a very enjoyable pint .  a : crystal clear amber colored and topped with a very good eggshell white head . excellent retention and great spiderweb lacing are left behind .  m : a bit dry and thin , which is surprising .
it has mild dark malty aroma .  beautiful looking beer here .  texture is pretty well-balanced , but leans a little more on the watery side .

the nose is quite understated and offers little more than vague cannabis and evergreen notes ; it is pleasant , but perhaps overly mild .  poured into my duvel tulip with a massive two and a half finger milk chocolate headthat left an incredible amount of side lacing and stayed as a thick blanket . all of which sat atop a dark brown brew . the head is unreal on this .  when combined with the relatively light body for style , orval is almost dry , and is thus very drinkable .

smell is unremarkable . a little citus , nothing overpowering .  this looks sublime - just what an apa should look like . slightly hazy body , with a beautiful burnished golden colouring . thick , creamy head of off-white , peppered with small pancake bubbles . lacing is heavy and sticky . just beautiful , and exactly what a pale ale should be .  the flavor is nice and chocolatey , but the body is nowhere to be found . i think it suffers from the lack of body overall .

smells of yeast , slight fruit . wow , a lot better than i was expecting . aside from the kind of bland smell , everything else about this brew is great .  poured into a lagunitas pint/mason jar and was totally impressed with the 2 finger tan fluffy head and nice lacing on this pepsi cola clear dark brown brew .  i think a little carbonation would do this slightly heavy beer good .

this is my daily drinker here in prague . it 's the most most widely served beer in the czech republic , and for good reason . it 's smooth and probably the reason that czechs keep taking the `` most liters per capita '' honor . so in short , nothing special , but nice to have a case around the house .  a : pitch black with brown head . heavy lacing .  medium , silky body , maybe a tad overcarbed .

the aroma is clean and light , with very little in the way of spice .  this beer has a beautiful color , almost like cola with some extra glow , which is one of my favorite things about it .  the body is a bit watery , but very nice and flavorful on the whole .

s-grainy , husk , some alcohol . t-very husky and malty flavor , strong and coarse booze taste .  pours dark brown with a foamy , long lasting , tanned head . good amount of lacing .  saison du buff appearance- very hazy golden , lively white head that dissipates quickly.4 smell- hops - green buds to the max 5 taste- wow . delicious . sweet and citrusy but with huge hop and wheat finish.complex balanced . spicy nutmeg 5 mouf- easy 3 drinkable - oh so drinkability 4

smell : the aroma is rather simple , with biscuity malts and wheat dominating . ) and hop aroma , but these aromas were difficult to pinpoint . taste : the taste was excellent .  stellar tan head atop a dark body . lots of retention and lacing .  a little to watery for a porter .

watered down malt and wheat taste though very pungent . was n't a drinkable beer . it had a value macro-lager rather than a flovored wheat beer taste to it .  pours a brilliant and bright gold with an impressive rich and fluffy pure white head .  i 'm conflicted on the body . it is light and that prevents the nice mouthfeel that should be evident in the best of this style . having said that this is a lighter stout that does n't feel too heavy on a hot summer day and would be enjoyable to drink outside .

i 'm not too impressed here .  tucher kristall weizen half liter bottle unknown bottling ( notched 1 and 8 in the third segment , 333 cap citing their 1672-2005 anniversary ) poured a clear dark yellow with a huge fully lasting frothy white head with good lacing and massive carbonation .  very light ( perhaps too light ) in the mouth , with strong carbonation .

some lacing found after drinking half the brew . rich porter flavor is strong and you know it is there.finish is smokey to me but not overpowering . i am not a porter or half and half daily drinker but i do like the change and would drink again .  wow this is a beautiful beer . huge dense slightly off white head . nice and frothy with a great lacing .  sampled this at the brewery ( portsmouth ) at the end of the tour which is short but wonderfully informative ( thanks byron ) . it didnt hurt that i was a few pints deep from the restaurant already . its been 2 weeks and its almost gone and i have to say its great for a stout . it pours thick and has little head retention so presentation isnt off the charts but taste makes up for it .
slight smell . nice caramel to balance out the nitrogen . weak , but okay .  impressive lacing left behind , and really nice retention .  m : surprisingly light body with lots of carbonation .

taste-wow ... wow , this is damn good . very understated , but everything is in its right place . clean and crisp mouthfeel- so smooth and creamy , like no other beer i 've had in that department .  poured from a wonderfully designed 750ml bottle into a tulip glass . every pour produces a healthy three fingers width of white head .  fat tire beer is great . it is a very drinkable ale that is available almost anywhere here in boise . appearance - nice semi-dark amber color , smells like something you want to drink right away . taste - ahh the taste is great on this ale . the new belgium brewing company really outdoes themselves with this ale .

appearance : 3/4 inch head , black in color , opaque smell : roasted malt , cocoa , and alcohol taste : dark and sweet chocolate , roasted malt , caramel , and some nuttiness mouthfeel : moderate carbonation , medium-heavy body , sweet with light bitterness and a slight bitter aftertaste . i wish the finish was not as dry , but a very good beer . the taste is way better than the smell -- i would look for this again .  great retention . lacing clings to the glass and creates an awesome webbing . color is a darker amber orange with red hughes when held to the light .  creamy , chewy , yet somewhat thin bodied and surprisingly effervescent .

s : stronger malt and hops . smell was familiar , and average .  i do n't know how anyone could give the appearance anything less than a 5 - it never gets old watching the head cascade from the depths of the clear dark ruby beer up into a foamy cream-colored head . then the lace sticks around for the life of the beer - very nice .  m : kind of light in body , i do n't know if it 's the can , but needs more heft , overall resiny and creamy .

however , as i drew it nearer to my mouth the strong , malty and soury smell became more perceptible and less attractive for my first impression .  appearance - hazy , golden yellow body with a beautiful white pillowy head . other beers wish they could look this good .  this beats out negro modelo , pacifico and bohemia as the best mexican brew made ... the only exception possibly being indio or nochebuena , which i havent had the good fortune to try yet ... anyways victoria is a very hard brew to find as well ... basically only sold in southern mexico.. however the hops are very very present in victoria ... probably the best summer quencher you could find especially in parts south of the border ... lime or no lime victoria is tops ... cheers !

the smell is subdued but pleasant ; roasted caramel malts with a nutty character to them .  a beautiful orange hue with pristine cloudy head remaining through the last sip .  light body , with low carbonation , ho-hum .

smell was rather muted , a hint of citrus . the only negative side to this beer was it 's limited aroma , but the taste more than made up for it .  deep mahogany with a very large , off-white , pillowy , luxurious head that sticks to the glass as it ever so slowly recedes .  m - very effervescent , but i guess not much more than most saison 's . a bit thin and watery , especially on the back end .

smell : who 's got time to smell it ? it was cold and i just had a long hard day at work .  a- beautiful looking pour into my goblet . the body is a murky deep brown , not sure about the lacing as this head just wo n't quit . amazing retention & lacing , this deserves full marks .  the consistency seems about right , but the carbonation seems a little much . it feels quite spritzy .

color looks like a dark iced tea or a weak coffee . this beer has a sour chocolatey smell like baking cocoa .  pours a slightly hazy amber orange with a full 2 finger head of thick craggy off-white colored foam that melts to very sticky lacing lasting and lasting to the end of the glass .  m : overly-carbonated mouthfeel , almost stings the the mouth .

written up from notes : enjoyed on 9/25/11 poured a clear gold with a half finger white head , scent is unimpressive , similar to a golden ale with a minimal hop addition , does n't strike my fancy .  pours a really beautiful beer , reddish brown , nice head retention .  full flavor , nice beer taste with bittersweet aftertaste , leaving only the faintest hint of hops . good bock , typical of these end-of-season beers with a richness that comes from fully ripe barley . enjoyable alone , not timid with food .

a - very dark with only slight red around the edge . more bock like than porter like .  poured a brown/amber color into my chimay glass , producing a nice fluffy 2 and a half inch white head that lingered for a bit and left a lot of lacing . very impressive !  carbonation runs a bit rampant , but it 's this brew 's only real flaw in my mind .

pours a nice brownish amber with a nice creamy white head . has all the qualities a good lager should have . over all the high point to this beer is the fusion of good quality brew with great drinkablity and good prices . i commend yuengling on all of their beers for all of these qualities .  very good half inch withe head that lasts almost the entire pint and leaves good lacing .  the body is a bit thin .

smell ; mostly alcohol and some hops with a hint of burnt sugar .  the beer pours darker than the inside of a cow ! head is colossal , creamy ; the lace sticky thick sheets that cling mightily to the glass , both are a nice chocolate color .  maple , chocolate , soy sauce , hersheys syrup , rancid hersheys syrup and other forgotten descriptors were used over these 2 samplings . perhaps marinade is the best destiny for this brew . what if we blended gubna and satb ? could that save both beers ?

had this last night , on tap , at novare res in portland , me . i am all for thin stouts , but this one had the girth of an anorexic . the taste was thin , too , with a lot of burnt coffee and cheap toffee ; finished with an unpleasant metallic aftertaste . needless to say , there was n't even a hint of a chocolate note . but this one just left us in a bad funk , which is the last thing beer should do .  yellow lager colour , not too orange , not too pale , but filtered clear . beautiful appearance - although i do n't know if this cleanly fits into the apa category .  m - very , very thick . perhaps a little too thick for me .

the scent was a bit weak , not much to smell but a bit of malt . it has a very nice sweet taste without being overly malty .  the color matches the gradient on the label perfectly . the head is a white foam , average , and pleasantly lingers and holds at the top for a while .  medium to thin body with smooth mouthfeel .

my favorite of the red ales . hearty , but not heavy . i enjoy with pub food - burgers , fish & chips .  looks soooo good . i love how the nitro bubbles flow around inside the glass . crazy that this beer is lighter than bud calorie wise .  the mouthfeel is just a little too light and watery .
smell - light hops smell .  pours extremely hazy amber color with a nice dense 2 finger off white head with amazing retention that reduces to a fairly thick lacing cap .  mouthfeel is a bit watery .

let me just say the taste of the beer was seriously improved after having a conversation with one of the smartest , most down to earth craft brewers i have ever met . smells malty and slightly toffee-roasted , mixed with the co2 , essentially covering all hop aroma mouthfeel is what really pulls for this one .  appereance is just about perfect . clear , dark amber with the best head i 've seen on any `` big '' beer , and this one is 11 % .  m : about average in the mouth .

aroma - light toasted grains , a whiff of fruitiness for a few seconds , a touch of metal .  damn , black with a dark brown tight head with lots of bubbles .  a bit chalky . hints of grapefruit and bold coffee flavor .

nose is disappointing . overall , a very nice stout .  clear copper-orange with a mountain of rocky pale tan foam that slowly recedes to leave the glass absolutely smeared with lace . simply put , it looks fantastic . bitter herb and lemon oil nose backed with toastier and vaguely sweet notions of bread and nuts .  less co2 would have provided a silkier mouthfeel .

the body of this brew pub offering arrived as a deep glossy brown with red highlights ( as the natural lighting dictated ) . the taste was exceptional in that it started with a semi malty sweetness and finished with a sharp bitterness that had a burning sensation which quickly disapated ... .leaving you wanting more .  out of the bottle this brew was a light copper color with a huge , foamy , tan head . great retention and it left sticky ribbons of lacing all down the glass .  body is a touch too thin .

it is clearly a pilsner . the aroma is that of hay/freshly cut grass . i do n't think i 've rated a pils this high before .  appearance : the body has a dark appearance with good clarity and very deep brownish amber color . on top there is a huge light tan head that has great retention . also it makes for some cool splotchy lacing on the glass .  mouthfeel is slick , with lower than average carbonation .

remarkable clean smell , no stench , quite sweet and a little fruit ( bananas or pineapple perhaps ) .  a- a hazy , luminescent orange liquid with a creamy white head . as good as it gets .  m - light bodied and crisp . at least they got this part right . d - simple , watery , and low quality .

nothing really stands out in the aroma except for maybe a distant hint of honey .  big fat tan head that was rocky as hell . one of the best looking stouts ive ever seen .  the mouthfeel is a tad thin and falla short in this department .

s- does n't really have that strong of a scent , but you can slightly smell some malts . d- very drinkable . overall an extremely good beer .  bloody good ! this is the coolest looking beer i have ever seen ! has a crazy two finger pink head which takes a minute or two to dissipate and leaves some really cool pink lacing behind .  m : fizzy but medium-bodied d : high alcohol flavor gets to me , and leaves a taste in your mouth in the end , overall not too impressed .

appearance : a strongly yellowish yet golden color that is slightly darker than a czech-style pilsner , at least . smell : not much , to be honest : some hops , a grainy , malty smell reminiscent of cereal grains and tinge of lager yeast thrown in . taste : who cares about the smell here , it 's all about the taste on this one . it contains a thick , malty taste , significant carbonation , and a bitter yet fruity bit to it that makes it very enjoyable to drink . even though i 'm a bigger fan of ales , this beer contains the nice , light funkiness of lagers and the thick malty body of ales . as a session brew , it 's crowd pleaser for sure , yet a slightly complex beer that beer geeks can enjoy as well .  pours a golden orange color with a nice big white head and great retention .  mouthfeel is on the light side , with a little more acidic carbonation than i 'd like in this sort of beer .

the aroma is n't strong enough for me . i get some faint coffee and chocolate roasted malts , but that 's it . the flavor is prominant , thank goodness . coffee and chocolate are the main players . this bomber is going down pretty good , and i am sure the next one i buy will too .  opaque brown to even black , poured a one-inch tan head .  m -- it is a little bland in the mouth .

no date appearance very clear ( minus the moderate presence of fine particulates ) straw/light gold body ; 1-finger thick white head breaks down quickly ; steady light stream of rising carbonation ; lace is non-existent ; halfway through the glass , there was a nearly lifeless fluid remaining ; a second pour was dropped dead center into the middle of the glass with very low carbonation exhibited smell brut champagne ; bourbon ; candy ; vanilla ; really not what i expected but its the best portion of the experience taste hyper fruity sweet ; too tangy ; vanilla ; touch of butterscotch ; oak does come through but the full package isnt anywhere near as strong as the oak barrel its aged in mouthfeel a bit less than moderate body ; most lively around the edges of the tongue ; sahara dry and tacky at the back of the throat drinkability nearly unpalatable i usually try another sample to seal a negative deal but this isnt one for which i have faith to retry .  a-poured into my sniffer , pours a deep hazy ruby red color with a huge tan head that slowly and beautifully forms into a thick and creamy head . it has great retention but also slowly dissapates to a thin film on the beer , and leaves really good rings of lacing .  beer follows germany 's purity laws . a : solid black , thin head s : plum , chocolate , fig ; very sweet and delicate smell t : coffee , roasted grains , sweet ; hops are subdued ; light abv makes this easy to drink a pretty good , decent beer .

citric aroma , some subdued fruity maltiness , too . toasty maltiness backed by a touch of fruit and floral hoppiness .  this beer has a great texture ; creamy , smooth , but has some kick at the ass-end due to the alcohol .  i drank this 22oz beer out of one of the new fandangled sam adams pint glasses . the first taste i thought `` oh great another ginger ale . '' then as i tasted it more i focused on the saison character and citrus notes . pretty nice . not as good as 6-6-6 though . when it warms up to room temperature it gets a buttery nose and a quite intense ginger flavor . i assume this ginger will mellow as it ages .

big malt taste , alcohol , spiciness , fruity , yeasty . not a lot of aroma , sweet , jellylike , fruity .  black with a huge and frothy light brown head . looks like sea foam in texture .  - in the mouth it feels thin , and quite carbonated .

it pours a crisp pale amber , with a great head that pillows up creamy smooth like meringue and leaves lots o ' lace . some pine on the nose , along with the copious hops , but not much else . absolutely worth tracking down .  awesome looking brew .  mouthfeel is thinnish , but with plenty of flavor . i found that the fizzy carbonation dissapated a bit to quickly and left the last half a bit flat , but that was my only complaint .

( some lacing ) the aroma is of spice and yeast . the flavor matches the aroma nicely .  the color was an extremely deep amber with ne-quality clarity , which was unusual for a cask .  man oh man , the fiesta of flavor wo n't die down in its rented oral event space , my mouth .

750ml into a pint - 2009 vintage , a bit old a - pours a bright golden color . very strong , well retained . s - some sour fruity notes come through , makes it seem like this beer has been aged more than it should be . the strong off note from the nose is a little off putting , but it recovered nicely in the taste .  this pours perfectly , black as can be with a good , thick toffee-colored head that very slowly dies and leaves jagged , broken lacing down the inside of the glass . beautiful .  m- a little thin and watery with little carbonation .

another offering on my summer tour de beers . ever since this beer first came out from harpoon , i thought of it as `` just another beer '' . good in a pinch , good for a keg party/bbq at my house several years ago , ok if that 's all the bar has on tap , but not really worth seeking out . i bought a 12 pack of cans since it was reasonably priced , cold , was one of the few craft offerings at a bad package store , and i could drink it at my swim club . clean , balanced , drinkable , just enough taste to keep things interesting to quench your thirst . do n't sip it to detect nuances - just drink it . when i 'm dying of thirst the last thing i need are subtle hop nuances or a heavy malt profile .  a thick cocoa head sits like a dallop of ice cream over the body that only recedes after leaving plenty olace . deep black body with ruby edges . drinking this beer opened my eyes to the beauty of craft beerand after that there was no looking back .  the feel is just too thin ; it does not make for a bad mouthfeel , but it is far from the potential heights of enhancement that i envisage .
aroma was of light hops and faint orange .  this is a great looking beer . deep red with a brown tint .  the mouthfeel is lighter than i expected .

consistent bubbling that keeps a thin head on this as it 's consumed . not much to the aroma at first blush - however some dark fruit , burnt malt , raisin and bitter chocolate notes are fairly homogenized here . really tasty .  pours a pitch black with an everlasting 3 finger head .  essentially , this is imported bad malt liquor . cidery malt , with an overwhelming fusel alcohol presence . a strong lager can be done well , or , as this demonstrates , very , very badly .

quite mild smell off hops and sweet butter caramel . didnt smell soo much , maybe my own fault because i had a thomas hardys with exceptional smell just before this one .  this beer looks great . i poured it a little too vigorously and ended up with a huge tan head that did n't fin in my pint glass . the head subsided into a film and left plenty of lace on the glass .  medium to thin body disappoints a little . high carbonation , slick mouthfeel . overall decent wee heavy , a tad thin on the body , but definitely one i wish i had more of .

a -- deep orange color , with an impressive and long-lasting egg-white colored head s -- not a whole lot going on in the nose -- some yeast and citrus t -- nice amount of yeast , orange peel , cinnamon ; excellent malt profile balances out a huge amount of hops . overall : very impressive !  looks very nice in the glass .  m : a little too much carbonation for my taste .
almost smells like a sweet bread . not very aromatic .  appearance : clear cold with lots of tiny bubbles rising and a big chunky head . looks very good .  mothfeel is slightly light .

s : not exceptionally complex but i get notes of dark toasted malts , dark fruits , sweet fruit juice and bready smelling yeast . t : very bready and doughy tasting with notes of sweet candied dark fruits , clove , cardamom , and a hint of chocolate .  it pours black with a brown head . depending on how you pour it , it will keep the head on it until the glass is empty . thus it leaves a very nice lacing on the glass .  a bit thin on the feel though , would have throught it would have been a bit more robust .

nose is where ? it was rather subdued to me . i did pick some roasted malt , cocoa and oats . drinkability is good with a nice abv but still would not drink to many of these at once .  pours out golden amber and sits a foggy reddish amber-brown in the glass . big billowy off-white head caps the beer . very nice .  when left to sit on the tongue , the carbonation was almost non-existant ( due to it being on cask ) i 'm guessing i 'd like this better bottled , or on draft and i 'd definitely like to try it again .

the bummer here is i am trying to do this from memory rather than doing it on the spot as the original was . s : this was surprising , but to my nose , i really did n't take smell as one of the big features of this beer . it had all the hops you would expect from a wet hop beer ( being the main feature ) but also had a smokiness or savoriness that i ca n't pinpoint . i know most pale ales do n't store , but this provided quite the buzz so i am thinking the alcohol and hops may make this age ok ... i 'll see .  pours an opaque black body with well over an inch of light tan head that persists nicely and eventually subsides leaving some decent lacing .  m : feels thin especially for a stout .

scent is definitely spicy , mildly peppery , obviously from the chinook hops . still , the nose is fairly undeveloped on this . tastes full of spicy , bitter chinook hop flavor . i would like a bit more aggressive nose , but would n't change anything else .  a : pours a light amber tinged golden with a large , dense , bright white head that slowly faded into a very thick and fuzzy film that left streaks of lacing down the glass .  an incredibly easy-drinking beer , great as a thirst-quencher but could use a bit more body .

very subdued aroma . taste- here are the hops !  leaves an inch long frothy tan head after a moderately aggressive pour . good lacing .  lots of bitter orange , banana , even cinnamon in the taste , with smooth but underwhelming mouthfeel .

alex was quick to point out the rubber , with another reviewer ( threewisemen ) pointing out an aroma of `` pool chemical smell '' . still an excellent kriek that i would return to repeatedly , particularly a more newly-released version .  corked and caged green 12.7oz with 2.004 stamped on the cork poured into a tulip . pale , hazy gold with a massive ( despite a gentle pour ) head of big white bubbles that has great retention and clings to the glass in odd rocky lumps .  the mouthfeel is somewhat disappointing . i like gueuze to be effervescent , or at least moderately carbonated , but the carbonation i find here is quite low .
