good stuff .  pours an opaque black with some light mahogany hues . head is quite creamy and looks very much like a guinness . i was very pleased to find the beer to have a much more complex flavor profile than ye 'old guin .  reviewed 6/1/2006 ( 22oz bottle ) : pours a yellow-reddish clear colored body , with a big head , off-white yellowish in color . some good lacing . has a nice sweet aroma , some hops , malts , northwest beer aroma . a bitter taste , some malts , slight acidic aftertaste .

smells malty , noticeably chocolate ; nicely dark oat beer , but not spectacular .  this beer pours a dark polished brown color ... like deep dark wood flooring . two fingers of off-tan foam that laces evenly and soft .  the only hint of carbonation i could find was a few bubbles on my tongue . sipping and taking huge swigs it tasted good . my first lambic and after this , i can imagine i will try to seek out more .

s -- mellow , spicy hops with the lightest of grain back .  a : slightly hazy amber with two-finger , frothy white head that stays awhile . nice bubbles and very good lacing . o : great to look at .  m : the body is medium and so is the carbonation .

s : malt with some belgian sugar and yeast . very subdued .  this beer was , however , enough of a shadow of those beers to almost bring a fond tear to my eye . poured a crystal clear rich golden straw with a delectible 4 finger head that had the consistency of clingy marangue .  mouthfeel overall is thin , slightly malty and citrusy .

for a double ipa , this brew lacks intense aroma , but it is still there . on the nose there are hints of citrus , honey , and cedar . even someone just getting used to the style would appreciate this offering . i would not suggest it be drunk in quantity , due to it 's alcohol content , but as something that finishes of a good meal .  this was poured from the bottle into a pilsner flute . a - ultra-clear light golden straw color with a thick foamy head with excellent retention s - balanced light hop and malt aroma with a touch of sulfur t - malty up front with a moderate crisp hop finish , clean m - medium-light body moderate carbonation d - this is a nice american interpretation of the classic german style .  mouthfeel : medium to light body .

its nose is subtle , mostly consisting of hops , raisins , and metal .  a - amazing dark head , blackest midnight body .  below average carbonation with a smell of sweet roasted malts . tastes of smoked , roasted malts , with chocolate/coffee overtones . very balanced and very tasty this one good beer . drink and enjoy !

nearly no smell on this . if i stuck my nose in the glass , i could pick up a slight fruit smell , but really , there was n't much ; taste was outstanding !  a - poured an almost black , cola-like color with slight red hues . picture perfect .  the mouth feel is light and has slightly higher carbonation which makes it a very refreshing beer .

s : very subtle in the aroma department . just a mild bready maltiness with a tinge of hop bitterness poking through .  magic hat jinx is a hazy amber ale with a huge , fluffy , cream coloerd head . the retention and lacing are excellent .  definite hop rom a with a fruity grapefruit smell . taste was quite hoppy in a good way . i 'd heard a lot of hype on this beer , and overall i 'd say it was n't a letdown but i do n't see myself craving this anytime soon .

almost explicitly roasted malts on the nose , rather like the boston lager .  this beer pours deep black with a light tan head .  crispy , mouth watering . tastes good & is n't watery or light . medium to heavy body .

very slight `` fresh '' aroma . great kolsch taste .  this is one of the best looking hefewiezens i have ever seen cloudy copper in color huge white head that stuck around for a while leaving nice lace on the way .  creamy mouthfeel , although a bit thin .

short version : tasty stout with off-the chart appearance . overall a little mild on the nose . finally i picked up some dull burnt tartness in the smell . excellent stout but not off the charts .  poured a dark dark brown with a super creamy light mocha head .  mouthfeel is a little lighter than what i had expected , verging on watery .

a : beautiful black color with nice brown head s : burnt coffee and choc . t : chocolate , roasty coffee , maybe a little caramel m : good creamy feel , smooth d : for what i paid for this ( $ 7.50ish ) i though this is a solid doub .  a- absolutely pitch black , with an orange head that settles to some splotches . this looks mean .  m - medium with light carbonation , seems a little flat .

the aroma is more subdued for an american ipa . light citrus hops with some very prfound amber , crystal , and pale malts blneding with the light hops .  pours a glowing copper body with a huge , creamy , rocky , moonscape of a head that just lasts and lasts . incredible .  lots of hops in the taste , more than expected actually , along with roasted malts , coffee , and hints of bitter chocolate , and carmel . lingering bitterness on the palate . recomended .

overall , this porter has a fairly subdued aroma . t - mild chocolate sweetness with a bit of nuttiness and some mild roasted maltiness . d - solid porter from ballast point . still , this is a nice porter that is quite drinkable despite a nose that is fairly lacking .  a perfect example of the style .  it tastes a bit thin and tinny .

beautiful . aroma : a pale wheat base with decent hops and some hints of citrus .  stout like appearance , deep black , with a fluffy/foamy head , looks great .  mouthfeel and drinkability : light bodied with surprisingly low carbonation , it fades almost as quickly as it comes into play .

smells of sweet , sweet malt liquor goodness . corn , funk , and alcohol .  this beer looks amazing , it has a white head that wo n't stop and reminds me of duvel .  m-pretty smooth with a slight creaminess to the carbonation . seems a bit on the light side for an oatmeal imperial stout .

there was little to no aroma that could be ascertained from the brew ; however , after some persistence on my part , i could identify a slight hint of toasted malt . i could not detect any presence of hop on the nose . starting flavor is mostly that of toasted malt which lingers into the midway where a simultaneous introduction of hops can be detected .  a - this pours a beautiful transparent golden color . it has a big white fluffy champagne head , that overflowed from the glass and went all over my counter top . the head also left little bits of scattered lacing as it fizzed down to a small ring at the edge of the glass .  i know plenty of girls who live for it though m= high carbonation which in my opinion made it a little more drinkable d= hard to do more than one without something in between .

great draft german lager . nice golden color and lacing . would recommed to anyone looking for a decent german lager .  brown-ish copper color with a big tan head , good carbonation , and good lace sheets .  all light beers have deficiences . this one at least has a nice hop bite , very rare for a macro beer . no sweetness .

the aroma is certainly belgian like but with an herbal weirdness to it . the flavor is of corn , hay , fresh cut lawn , earthy , and mustiness . because great lakes is in my top 5 breweries i can forgive them because they rock .  it pours a damn near perfect looking hazy amber/orange colour with a very nice looking creamy head that is off-white in colour and is slow to dissolve .  the body is softer than you would expect . the light body leads me down this path , but the abv could hinder drinking a lot of this beer .

the scent is very light with a mild fruity sweetness .  it looks pretty much exactly like the picture on the bottle . once it dissipates some , it leaves tons of lacing and has a nice layer of head left on top of the beer .  finish leaves a mass produced adjuncty lager flavor which is slightly unpleasant and makes you want to drink another sip to get rid of it .

nice bubbling with good pillowy white head . smell : not much of a smell , similar to the organic . tastes : malts with light hoppy grass flavor . not as much as the organic , but very nice .  epic head for a helles : three-fingers , creaminess , great retention , thick lacing . flawless .  for a winter brew , the mouthfeel is a bit thin and light .

s - fresh smell . notes of lemon , ginger and wheat is there too .  anchor has the head perfect - this thing was towering over the top of my glass , absolutely monstrous for a bock . the color is gorgeous , cola-like red-brown .  mouthfeel : meduim carbonation is shown in a bit of thickness in the mouth that dissipates quickly and leaves the mouth watering .

`` lager '' as we call it is a smooth crisp ... well , lager . not very hoppy and little head . mouthfeel is light and is overall a very refreshing drink .  22 oz bottle a : pours a clear golden under a foamy white head . excellent lace and excellent retention .  seems a bit thin , shame , because i really like this brew . the carbonation is good just seems that it is watery .

aroma is subtle hops .  the body is a hazy dark brown with red shining through when held to the light . the 2 finger , tan head is creamy , huge , and rocky . all the bubbles are tiny and the head leaves clumps of foam on the glass .  nose has a metallic hop quality , but overall is fairly faint . palate has a sour , spent grain flavor that is n't simply not very good - it 's actually has a bad taste . what are they thinking ? and no , the bottle is not defective . finish is unpleasantly bitter . has an unwelcome sulfur component as well . could n't finish this one . i hope the kitchen drain enjoys it more than i do .

nose was quite mild , on a a faint wiff of malts was apparent .  ceremonially decanted in a snifter , the `` holy water '' takes shape with bubbling alacrity , it wears a deep pollen-crusted yellow orange hue , like the hot cadmium heart of a van gogh sunflower . the head is fair and delights when the drinker tips his glass , for it quickly scribbles in chalky lace some memorized stanza of medieval prose .  slightly more carbonation would aid the drinkability imo , but otherwise this is a very enjoyable and unique ipa - glad to have tried it !

i liked the honey color of this brew ; each time it appeared slightly hazy . good scent- apricot , maybe ? ? the mouthfeel was smooth and delightful .  i love the color of this beer . medium to dark bourbon amber with good clarity .  mouthfeel : medium body with a medium to high amount of carbonation .

this was a great porter , on draft in homer , at cups cafe , which is a fantastic restaurant , do n't let the coffee shop name full you ! the aroma was sweet malt , light toasted , a bit of cola .  a : pitch plack with a nice mocha colored head that is moderately thick and retains very well . it leaves almost wine like legs when swirled , exactly what i am looking for in a stout s : tons of roasted malt character , bitter coffee and chocolate notes are the most prominent .  i got this beer orginally thinking it was a japanese lagar . this beer is a very light sweet tasteing beer wich is a nice change to the bitterness of my useal sout . the aperiance is a trnncelucent gold color with a decent head and is very drinkable do to the sweetness with just a hint of bitter hop all in all a very good beer

s. not much going on here some bread , a little caramel t. what a suprise considering the nose was a little weak . reminded me of some winter stlye ales . molasses cookies , nutmeg , maple , cinnamon doughnuts . first taste was a definate wow , compared to the aroma .  hazy golden with a hotd type of generous white head . lacing is top notch , rocky , it 's a battlefield to admire as it diminishes a bit .  m - maybe my problem is the carbonation .

amazing clear honey color and a sweet smell . taste was unexpectedly pleasant .  a dense off-white head of three-fingers has fantastic retention and even better lace ! incredible looking , it could n't get any better .  the beer is a little under-carbonated for my liking and is also a little more body than i would like .

smells of sweet biscuit . it 's creamy , which is something that 's totally new to my nose . finishes with floral hops . although this is more sweet and malty than i expected , i was surprised at how much i liked it .  open bottle and poured into a hefe glass . beautiful head and sunburst orange .  m : a little flat in the mouth , sticky and slick in a disquieting way .

it did n't have too much of an aroma to it but it was pleasant in appearance and the flavor had just a little bit of something different about it .  a gentle pour produces a thick , custard colored head , the consistency of the foam is creamy and milky . lacing is gorgeous , very delicate bubbles slide across the glass . the body color is the same as the brown bottle glass .  carbonation is sizzling , a bit too much in my opinion as it has the pop rock fizzy jones . i can see how this would be too sweet to some but i think the carbonation really sizzles away the lingering residual sweetness . upper 3 's if it was n't for the lackluster appearance and pop rock mouthfeel .

smells pretty weak .  a : pours a clear golden-amber body with a steady column of carbonation leading up to a perfectly lofty head of frothy bright-white foam .  carbonation is moderate , but i think the body is a tad light for my liking .

d : overall , a good and enjoyable beer , but with an odd scent that i did not find pleasant .  somewhat cloudy dark ruby color . one of the best heads on a beer i have ever seen . definitely a gorgeous beer .  m - a little slick for my liking .

s - very subdued . some sweet malt and a bite in the smell . t - nice sweet malt and bitter hop mix .  color is a pure jet black . first pour brings a massive brown head that slowly recedes .  m- lighter bodied than i would have liked .

the smell , however , was alot lighter than i expected . i could only smell a slight hint of coffee and roasted malt . this is a very good stout that should not be missed .  a - fantastic cascading that never ceases to tantalize me . one finger , dense-as-cream , tan head with impeccable retention and thick lacing .  a - nice golden yellow , very bright and clear s - malted corn smell with a light aroma t - great taste ( again to style ) with clean flavor , a sweeter corn taste and very fresh and crisp m - just average here , although the carbonation adds to the crispness of this beer d - very drinkable for this style .

primary aroma i catch on a deep whiff is alcohol , but also has the sweetish malty aroma expected for a big barleywine .  almost jet black with a thick creamy head that leaves lacing behind until the beer is gone .  mouthfeel is light does n't really laste , but conversely its very drinkable for a stout .

aroma is very light and soft ; clean , crisp , and rounded with a pale grassy , whole grain maltyness that would seem like what a pilsner should smell like . just not very aromatic in any fashion . a nearly perfect pils .  appearance- deeper golden colored pour with a two fingered and creamy head . leaves behind some large sticky patches of lacing .  mouthfeel : plenty of carbonation and definitely thick , but not as smooth and creamy as i 've had in other oatmeal stouts . nothing special .

it had a lite scent , malt was present . it had a nice clean malt taste that was accompanied by a slightly bitter hop taste .  a : gorgeous presentation . pours a milky , ruby red color with a 1/4 inch light red head .  the body is medium-light with moderately high carbonation .

the smell is predominantly of lighter grains and sourness . the tastet is quite sour , and has a touch of hops .  this is one great looking porter .  main complaint is that the mouthfeel is a bit thin .

smells of fresh hops ... ipa ... , alcohol , bready , all good , but , an off-flaver here i do not like ( musty ugly barfy flavor ) . hmmm .  impeccable retention and lacing . really just about perfect looking .  mouthfeel is competent . worse than corona .

22oz bottle i picked up about 3 months ago ( i know a shame to hold it this long , but i always struggle to make myself open the big bottles by myself ) at a local megamart . poured with a great caramel color and a half inch of head , but that did n't last long smell was n't really a strong component on this beer for me , but i would chalk a lot of that to the on coming cold i have and my delay in opening . beer tastes great , strong hop flavor without being overly bitter which is a pleasant surprise from such an aggressively hopped beer .  dusty brown 2 finger head that lasts . rolling bubbles leave amazing lacing on the glass .  perhaps a little more watery than i expected from a `` cream '' stout .

this beer pours almost a copper/red-brown color with a light tan almost white head . the smell is sweet with some hop in there as well as malts . its hard to seperate , but a plesant sensation regardless . it has a smooth medium body that is not heavy at all and makes this drink more robust but still very drinkable . very good al , highly suggest trying .  a : a very nice amber glow shines through glass . topped off with an ice cream like head , with a full on belgian lace .  a very thin initially light ale taste quickly rounds out with a nice hop bite . high carbonation inhibits the taste at first making it very foamy .

light malt aromas of chocolate and some yeast in the nose . coarse . exquisite .  the beer poured into the duvel glass ( do n't know why , but it seemed appropriate ) inky black with a froth dark brown head that was everlasting and made the glass scream for mercy as it coated it with lacing and foam .  though i found the body of this beer to be quite thin , it may have just been the effects of the cask , but overall this brew was quite quaffable and the alcohol was n't noticeable until after i finished a pint .
light malty sweet smell but very minimal .  poured black , with a tan head .  m - nothing typically outstanding in the mouthfeel , but it is more than made up for in taste .

subdued aroma . i 'm not a blonde fan , but this one is tasty .  ) , tamed 10/06 medium pour in an english pint poured black , with barely noticeable dark brown highlights , with a huge bumby frothy mostly lasting light brown head with excellent lacing .  s : roasted malts , coffee , chocolate with a citrus backer m/t : light to medium body on the tongue , not a huge feeling beer . d : the lighter body of this beer makes blackout stout a pretty drinkable beer , however the strong malt and semi bitter aftertaste can catch up with you .

smells clean with a hint of washed concrete .  a- black , black , black , black , black . humong-o four finger mocha-colored head that 's foamy on the sides and puffy on top .  mouthfeel was the only place where i was disappointed . too thin for my taste . but for what it was lacking in mouthfeel it made up in drinkability .
mild aroma of coffee .  bottle : poured a deep slightly hazy golden color ale with a large pure white foamy head with good retention and some pretty nice lacing .  light carbonation .

a slight caramel characteristic comes through at the end but the aroma really betrays the taste ... t : rich , intense flavors of cappuccino and sweet roasted malts hit you upon sipping and subside into undercurrents of coffee , toasted oats , and subtle dark , bittersweet cocoa .  beautiful near black with the slightest light showing through , this beer had a 3 in head poured correctly with eternal lacing .  old foghorn has a lighter body than i would have hoped , but it is excellently carbonated .

i could smell the hops from a foot away during the pour . does n't seem overcomplex , just a strong quality hop aroma with citrus grapefruit undertones .  the hazy , bright red , brew swirls into the glass , as the thick caramel head fills it to the rim then dissipates to a small layer of foam . moderate carbonation rises to the top and releases the fruity aroma with a malty character .  m : smooth , not as robust as i would like in a ris , a little thin , pretty average . d : the lessened mouthfeel adds to the drinkability , making this probably the most drinkable ris that i 've ever had .

the smell was rather faint ( i do n't have the greatest nose ) and it did n't impress me as being particularly good or bad . i am a fan of stout to begin with , so my review might be a bit biased in that respect , but i have to say that beamish is hard to beat .  great clarity and enticing .  the mouth feel is somewhat watery and is the only flaw in this beer .

the nose is pretty faint , i ca n't pick up much chocolate or chili spices .  i poured this from the bomber into a pilsner glass and was rewarded with a beautiful straw color . the beer is mostly clear with a billowy head of sticky foam that left copious amounts of lace down the sides .  order a `` pint '' in scotland pub , they will give you a pint of tennents lager . sweeter than other lagers . cool , refreshing . i love this beer . if you 're looking for that nostalgic scottish pub feel , mmmm .

a- hazy golden orange with a good sized off white head s- floral and citrus hops , a little bit of sweetness . not as strong as i would have imagined or liked . the flavor is amazing . its so smooth , and downright refreshing . a great example of the style and one ive had time and time again .  pours perfectly with a three finger thick head of a bright white color .  more sweet than sour ; it has a predominant taste of cherry m - does n't linger as much as other , imo , more complex sours/lambics .

mgd . s = slight hoppy fruitty smell . m = see above d = expensive and crap .  it was probably one of the best looking stouts i 've ever seen . it was a dark , deep ink color and the head was at least three fingers and a creamy wheat color .  it 's a great balance . nothing overpowers - not any of the flavors or the alcohol , or the carbonation . the drinkability is the main factor as with all my beers .

amber colored , not very dark smell : not much in the way of smell , even as it warms in the glass . taste : very well balanced between hops and malt , the alcohol ( 6.8 % ) does not come though at all . at first i thought this is a great lawnmower beer , crisp , nicely hopped , perfect on a hot day .  a- clear orange gold hue , etching in duvel glass expresses a beautiful trail of bubbles that hold the white lace together . speaking of the lace ... absolutely wonderful as it sticks all over the glass .  m : very light with little to no viscosity . tap was much better , but most likely force carbonated .

goes down very easy . has a rich caramel-like flavor and an almost roasted aftertaste .  pours deceptively like a belgian pale ale with ample head , copious lacing , and a yellow body that is the furthest thing from transparent .  m : light body , medium carbonation , starts crisp but thickens and becomes creamier toward the finish .

aroma : light aroma of dark roasted malts present . little to no hop aroma present .  this beer looks amazing from the pour i just made .  the smell is bold pizza sauce , which basically included oregano , garlic , bad tomatoes , and bready crusts . i just get bready yeast and very grainy corn adjunct that is short and stinging .

s- not hugely aromatic but smells of spicy hops .  a : pours a hazy honey color with four fingers of billowy white head that recedes into a nice white cap with good lacing .  mouthfeel is a bit thin .

overall , not a great example of either a wheat or a fruit beer . the fruit taste was mild , but noticable . do n't suggest you try it unless you are in love with blackberries .  this brew pours up a clear dark amber color with a beautifully perfect off white frothy head . endless lacing . the appearance of this beer with it 's never ending head gets a perfect score .  standard bottle poured into a pint glass . the aroma was of sour peaches , smelled wonderful . it tasted sour than i expected but the more i drank the more i liked it . it was super easy to drink and is one of those beers that you crave on a hot summer day .

smells like nut and malt . taste is very smooth , slightly dry and bittersweet .  a - beautiful rocky tan head of two fingers . muddy , amber body . after the addition of the yeast into the glass there are swirls of brown in the head creating a nice visual effect and the head stays thick throughout , leaving mild , spotty lacing throughout . a beautiful beer .  it 's so much smoother and has much body to it , compared to all the other crap macro out there .

s : not a lot going on here , some nice grainy sweetness , almost corn-like despite corn not being listed on the can ( barley , wheat , and oats mentioned ) . appropriate nose for style .  great looking beer .  medium carbonation and body . nose is the normal malty/hoppy-ness of a porter , starts malty and hoppy and finishes with a nice mostly malty bite . very fresh - brewed 12/13/03 . the abv is 4.5 % .

s : some malts , some chocolate . slightly sweet but was hoping for more .  a : pulpy guava , huge voluminous soapy white head , copious clumps of lacing .  m : thick and moist - rather surprising , more carbonated than i would like and no body .

sam adams came up with one that won my heart over with the double bock . if you do n't like beers that use a sweet taste to cover their high alcohol content steer clear of this one . my only critisisms of it would come from the mouthfeel . it tends to be a bit thick for my taste , but you ca n't have it all i suppose .  appearance- color is a very dark , rusty brown/black . the head was a lovely two and a half finger head with great retention . maintains a good , thick filmy head throughout the entire beer .  m - medium bodied with a bit too much carbonation .

a fairly muted affair with the aroma of alcohol , fruity esters and some peppery spice . t - things get back on track with the taste . m - medium body and quite smooth , with medium carbonation that verges on being too hard at times .  the appearance was very good - a deep rich red color that was clear and brilliant . there was lots of head composed of minuscule bubbles which towered over the rim of my glass .  mouthfeel is on the thin side , and there is perhaps a little too much carbonation .

i have to give it a 5 because of that head , unseen for an american micro , let alone a spiced pale ale ! smell is on the soft side , ginger and tropical fruits .  pours very dark brown color with a nice 2 finger frothy tan head with good retention .  winter warmers are one of my favorite types of beer . however , i 'm a rheinheitsgebot type of guy . i taste nutmeg and maybe ginger in this beer . that 's outside the boundaries for me , even if the flavors were managed through some odd hop/malt/yeast combination . i had to dump it down the drain after a couple of tastes .

s - malt aroma accented by yeast and very faint hops . t - the hop flavors are smooth and unabrupt .  a : dark , almost black , opaque . have a thick , rich caramel colored head . it holds onto the side of the glass pretty well .  it maybe was a little bit thin in the mouthfeel , but this was a good beer overall .

s - predominantly pine hops a slight malty note as well . it is about what i would expect from a solid apa .  a : as with all guinnesses , it really is gorgeous .  t- roasted malt flavor with some hints of burnt malts , sweet chocolate during and in aftertaste , coffee in aftertaste , nutty flavor , ice cream shake like finish , gets sweeter as it warms m- smooth , at times the body felt solid then other times it felt rather thin .

weak aroma of cinnamon and pumpkin . highly drinkable ; by far the most enjoyable pumpkin ale i 've tried .  i found this in a 12 oz bottle and got very excited . when i poured it i was very happy when i saw the dark color of the head which dissipated rather quickly and left gorgeous lace .  only quibble is that it seems a little thin , does n't have a lot of oomph or gravitas to it , just the flavor .

bready and yeasty scent seems to linger . t- wow , this one has a ton going on .  a- coppery orange color , ample head , large and frothy .  this had an average head color was dark brown.aroma was of pine , raisin.sweet caramel.the taste was of raisins , malt , and prunes.the mouthfeel or palate was average.finished slightly bitter and dry.good , smooth , complex beer.has a biting , dry finish.i like the finish .

smell was subtle with some hops and sweetness . taste was superb , hoppy and malty , great balance , nice warming feeling .  22oz bottle into tulip glass . a -- -it poured black with a creamy tan head .  the some rum notes come through as well alongside a slight boozy aspect . a slight toffee flavour is present throughout . alongside a slight alcoholic warming component . overall , the flavour leaves a bit to be desired , but this is still worth checking out . an interesting take on a scotch ale from a belgian brewer .

3 '' vanilla ice cream colored head that seemed to be both creamy on top and fizzy on the sides at the same time . smells of grass and lemon with some other citrus chiming in faintly . i can see it in either style , but feel pretty comfy just calling it a damn good americanized hefe .  a - very deep amber in color . beautiful beige head with good retention and very small , fine bubbles .  medium-bodied and moderately carbonated , the flavors throw back to the aroma , with a pronounced hoppiness that is balanced well by a base of biscuity grain .

aroma is of toasted malt and molasses . very faint .  insane retention means it 's sticking around for quite a while . as it slowly lowers , the sides give way to create the plateau with ridiculous amounts of lacing left on the glass . the color is a deep orange-amber that looks thick and tantalizing .  f - more than almost any other beer i 've tried , this one leaves a stickiness in my mouth , and makes me quite thirsty .

ruby in color and clear as day . nice malty presence right up front that mixes with dark fruit flavors . very drinkable and would seek out more !  pours from a 12oz bottle into a pint glass a pitch black color with a huge three finger sized head that in very tan , very creamy , and very beautiful .  mouthfeel was medium with a sugary sweetness that made me wonder if it is possible to develop diabetes from a single can of beer .

surprisingly reticent nose .  huge , foamy dirty white head . excellent retrention and great lacing . lots of little bubbles quickly rising tro the top .  very good beer , albeit a bit on the thin side .

aroma here is n't too powerful ... there are some pine hops and a bit of caramel malt ... but honestly , it 's somewhat faint compared to expectations . pours a clear brown in the pint glass ... .head of about 1/2 inch or so ... pretty good retention . taste is a pretty good marriage of sweet , caramel and toffee malts plus a pretty good degree of pine bitterness much like that found in a standard ipa . i 'm impressed with the balance here .  a : deep opaque coffee brown with a beautiful frothy tan head of 2-fingers that settles into a 1/2-finger lace . glorious .  the first swallow is sharply bitter , much starker than an american ipa . this is woody and tangy more than the citric fruitiness we yanks have come to expect from a beer labeled ipa , unfairly . with a solid malt undertow and a nicely balanced bitterness , i feel this is a very under-rated offering . ( # 2688 , 2/6/2007 )

overall , the bouquet is quite shy .  pours a unique red color like a red soda with a thick foamy two finger head that gives way to very little lacing . the color is very nice , and i will give it that it is different and i like that .  the drink is on the light side of medium bodied but is somewhat overly carbonated .

smells of caramel malt and a bit of citrus .  the total appearance was stellar ! smell - grass field , hops , a little earthy , doughy , bit of floral from the hops , definite alcohol whiff .  mouthfeel is a little thin for the style but really , it 's the best brew in the smokies .

smells like hops , a tiny bit of bready malt , and that sour sharpness that lagers always have . pretty straight forward and standard . i 'm used to vienna lagers being a tad sweeter , but this is still quite good and is absolutely more deserving than bud to be called `` the great american lager '' .  dachsenfranz mrzen pours with massive amounts of tight tan head . the body is a beautiful copper gold color .  feel is bright and slightly thin - refreshing , but could be a little fuller .

nose was roasted malts and cocoa and even a bit of sourness .  a : very beautiful . i love the nitro head on a non stout .  the mouthfeel is a bit thin and dry for my taste , but it is also very drinkable .

the aroma is a bit faint and fairly average overall . the lack of a hearty aroma hurts this one a bit .  pours clear orange with a huge orangish white head .  the mouthfeel is medium bodied with low carbonation and kind of watery .

s : hints of citrus and banana . the appearance and smell , while average , are less important than mouthfeel and drinkability , both of which were excellent .  great appearence with a pillowy foam .  this was one of my first craft beers that was not oberon , blue moon , etc . smell i do not really remember too much because i had just started getting into craft beers . taste was great for a new craft beer fan , pretty light not too strong or overpowering but tasted great . i could drink these all night and love it .

smell is a bit chocolatey and roasty , but it has a very light smell to it .  poured black in color with some bright mahogony highlights and of course the big cascading nitro head that evenutually evened out into a creamy dark tan thick head , the highlight of this beer is defenitly how good it looks .  mouthfeel is a little thin and watery .

tastey beer , i love the creamyness of the nitro . when i bought this beer i thought for some reason it was a stout . a malty beer , kinda sweet , not very bitter at all.. very little hop aroma . as a matter of fact , not much of an aroma at all . i suppose it 's part of the pale ale style . a very solid ale , very drinkable .  poured to a dark , opaque brown with thick tan head and great lacing .  i love cherry juice . this is cherry juice ( 25 % ) and a gueze lambic . the general characteristics are of cherry juice . sweet but not cloying like some other fruit beers . comes across as mostly juice . best as a summer or desert drink . might even work over ice for the heretical among you .

the confusing can of brewed in ca , canned in mn , and it being aged goes against most double ipa logic for hops preservation . the beer is a little malt forward for a double ipa with the hops more at the back . the vanilla and oak came out much more as it warmed and really balanced the beer . not the best out there but would still recommend trying this beer .  looks incredible . s : smokey , peat aroma with bittersweet chocolate and a touch of hop .  mouthfeel - when i think scottish ale , i think big mouthfeel . this beer lacks that mouthfeel .

in pa all you need to say is lager at the taproom and you will get served yeungling . this is the beer that put a hurtin on the big boys like ab and the likes in the philly area . this is an outstanding blue collar beer with white collar dignity . beer drinkers need to show much respect for the oldest brewery in the usa !  beautiful black body topped with a full tan head and perfect lacing . looks better than i remember .  the flavor left lying on the taste buds lasted an average amount of time , and was bold and flavorful.. mouthfeel was creamy and a tad oily in texture , and medium to full in body with a flat carbonation .

the aroma was disappointingly weak as a hint of malt was detectable .  stellar head retention & lacing s : some piney hops t : piney hops and little chocolate up front .  m : light chalkiness is on the finish while medium carbonation and viscosity are the main .

the smell is a little weak with a spicy and grapefruit scent . their is a light aroma of malt but the hops dominate the scent .  dark brown in color with ruby edges and a thick tan head that left some good looking lacing all the way down the glass . toasted coffee and oatmeal with chocoalte syrup on top in the aroma .  a tad thin on the tongue ( possibly desired for style ) but all in all a good changeup .

i tried this earlier today with friends , bottles were nicely chilled - everybody loved this , and there were more remarks about chocolate flavor than coffee or vanilla - now i 'm having a glass at home , served a little warmer - pours a deep chestnut brown , nearly opaque the 1 finger head recedes to form a 1/4 inch collar around the glass with spotty lacing on the sides and a swirly 'crema ' on the surface - not much aroma from this - taste is complex and smoooothe - yes , i can taste the vanilla notes and the coffee , with a little choco/toffee on the finish -very well balanced - i can not taste the alcohol in this 10 % brew - damn !  pours opaque black , thick tan rocky head that lasts and lasts . very nice .  personaly , i 'd like the mouthfeel a bit fuller , but perhaps i 'm spoiled by the big pilsner which initiated the hoffmann series .

s - smells bland , nothing special . no `` nose '' at all , really . smells like any old lawnmower ipa .  a- pours a hazy copper with a fluffy three finger head that slowly dissipates but leave a nice cap . leaves a ton of lacing behind , one of the best i 've seen .  stella artois pours a pale yellow with a fluffy white head from a green twelve ounce bottle . aroma is standard euro lager skunky hop profile . the taste also reflects the same skunky hop profile . not particularly good to my taste . there 's cheaper and better alternatives to this . not recommended .

pours straw yellow with a brilliant white head . has a nice barley malt smell , like a typical pilsner . mild hops in the smell as well . the mild smell belies a very flavorful beer .  a- poured dark brown ( almost black ) with a thick , brown head that lasted for most of the glass .  how they got the enhanced mouthfeel is beyond me .

they tend to smell very neutral . this is truly imperial .  poured into a beer mug pours a beautiful sunset orange with a gorgeous white head that caps and laces beautifully .  the mouthfeel is decent , but not what i expected , which was a heavier feeling .

lots of malt in the aroma , with a touch of caramel .  it pours out a beautifully glowing orange hue and had a giant head that grew quickly out of control .  the body is lush and thick , though unfortunately it 's marred by a fairly high level of carbonation .

still a refreshing light beer , medium golden color . it has a good drinkability and i enjoy it mostly on picnics . at a local supermarket at home it costs about 1 euro .  a : deep red , tall fluffy head , plenty of lacing .  extremely fine carbonation that lends both sharpenss then smoothness ( beyond a somewhat soft malt character ) . seems a bit watery at times .

s - light malty smell . t - smooth yet a lot of bite .  amber/orange with a fluffy white head with tons of retention and all sorts of lace , even after the glass is finished .  mouthfeel could be thicker .

at first , peppery alcohol in the nose , and what i can only identify as pungent yeast ( bottle conditioned , ill be more careful with the next pour ; note : i was more careful , and the nose was clear of that off scent i couldnt place . ) as it warms i get hints of rock candy or charms lollipops . after a couple gentle swirls to release some of the aromas , it turns to sweet silk .  a : a solid pitch black beer that yields no light , a half inch head in a cafe au latte color that laces nicely .  mouthfeel- light-medium body , medium carbonation , smooth , but does n't have much to offer on the palate .

good lacing & very good head retention s : slight cereal & lemon notes t : lemony hops & grassy notes up front .  pour is quite the sight to behold . three fingers of thick , lasting off white head over a murky red/brown liquid and insane amounts of carbonation in my nucleated glass .  mouthfeel is light with low carbonation .

served at a moscow mexican restaurant/bar that had a decent selection of international macros . came out a deep dark clear burgundy under a one finger tan head that was very creamy and full of body . the nose was way too mild , however , to the point of being almost imperceptible . the mouth was heavily carbonated , and heavy bodied . a solid product , but nothing spectacular after the great optics .  a - pours black , completely opaque . even brown/black head s - very faint smell , subtle hints of sweetness and bitterness t - extremely complex taste .  this is a decent beer with a subtle nutty flavor to it . i typically enjoy drinking these in large quantities usually at the local bar while playing foozfall and darts . the beer emits a subtle aroma of malt , that is followed up quickly with a fairly well balanced taste . it has excellent drinkability . the only problem , and this is slight , is that it tastes a bit watered down sometimes .

obviously raspberry . the tartness in the smell is a bit intimidating until you sip it then ... wow .  pours and golden color with a perfect white head .  3.0 m : medium body , which is lighter than i was expecting and much lighter than i had hoped . good carbonation . mouthfeel was lacking , but did n't effect my overall impression too much .

there is not much smell , just some sweet and sour notes with floral overtones . the taste is quite odd , but interesting and refreshing .  the beer pours a jet black color wtih 3 fingers of tan head that falls to a quarter inch over the beer .  m : fairly smooth , either needs to be a little more carbonated or a little thicker .

a bit disappointed with the smell . it took awhile to find anything , and once i did it was a pretty average copper malt . i liked this beer , probably more than the piranha pale ale .  the beer poured a rich amber with a nice tan head , the presentation left you saying now that 's what a beer should look like .  lots of malty and caramel characteristics as an imperial brown ale . slight hint of like a scotch ale almost , but without the over-alcoholy taste . would definitely drink it again at that price and would even bring it to a party with average beer drinkers .

aroma : light , nice malty aroma .  appearance - pours a hazy tangerine and churns up a finger or so of snowy white foam . really cool to watch this one go from bottle to glass . lots of bead action in the glass .  mouthfeel : smooth but a little watery or thin . nice carbonation .

s - very chocolate-y with pleasant slightly sweet malt aroma . t - much better than aroma .  pours chestnut with 3 fingers of fluffy mocha colored head . rings of lacing cling to the glass , plus primo head retention s : molasess & roasty malt t : roasty malt , slight coffee grouns flavor , molasess , plus dryness up front .  thin to medium feel . this is my favorite saranac by far .

i could not get much smell out of it but it did have a spice like ting . this is a good beer.i will have another pint or two before springtime comes .  ( a ) - pours a near pitch dark brown ; almost black color with the tiniest maroon highlights . produced a huge foaming eggshell colored head that is taking forever to dissipate .  while being the first irish red beer i 've had , it was very good . the reddish amber color and the malty flavor all made my pallate explode with joy . the overall experience of this beer was very good for me , while i have heard other people say that this is n't the best one out there , i enjoy it from time to time , and will continue to do so .

it smells like chocolate and coffee with distinct british malt .  an absolutely beautiful pour . black as sin , with a caramel/mocha head . great retention and coating of the glass with a few bits of lacing .  5 it 's a bit thin and the carbonation works to emphasize that .

weak in the nose with the standard qualities there but only barely . looks nice , laces well , but a bit pale in color .  on tap at barbara 's at the brewery , downtown l.a. looks beautiful in the afternoon light , kinda reddish burnt sienna color with opaque sandy looking head .  m - very bubbly , a little too bubbly , for my liking .

aroma - rather faint and not enticing aromas of medium and dark roasted malt . t markedly more flavorful than aroma suggests : a somewhat spicy rich malt flavor that leads to a fine and lasting finish featuring dark roasted malts .  appearance : wonderfully dark with a slight cream colored head .  very deep hop aromas , with huge citrus hop scents over a very nice deep maltiness . excellent flavor , with a huge malt forward and a great hop back that lasts on the tongue , with great citrus hop flavors . there is a fair bit of hop roughness , though .

( s ) - lots of roasted malt richness with a potent woody spice and afterthoughts of creaminess . the smell certainly waned due to its age .  pours coppery red with 2+ fingers of chunky sand colored pudding-skin head . very good lacing & excellent head retention s : rich cakeyness , toasted malt & some grainyness , flattens out as this warms t : caramel with metallic & herbal hops up front .  mouthfeel is a bit thin , slightly astringent , but somehow also smooth .

the smell of roasted malts was evident . the flavor was just like the way vynal smells . do they have vynal tanks ?  looks beautifully outta the bottle , big lacing down the glass .  the taste is very pleasant with a citrusy sweetness and a little bit of tartness that almost reminds me of a cider this beer is extremely drinkable an i could imagine reaching for it over and over again . i 'll definitely be picking this beer up again sometime in the summer , it 's very refreshing .

bottle from sams beer and wine in carrollton ... thanks matt pours a deep dark black with about 3 fingers of head that keeps growing out of the glasss ... not much on the nose here at all , smells sweet , thats about it ... maybe a bit of barley . definitely an interesting barleywine .  apperance : the dreadnaught is an amber orange , and reminds me of leaves in the fall . a beautiful beer just to look at .  500 ml bottle from riga , it is rimi supermarket beer pours golden with rocky and fizzy head with rather good rention , some lacing . aroma is sweet grainy malty , feels rather sharp and is dominated by alcohol . taste is extremely sweet malty with alcohol and warming aftertaste . i could not manage more than a few sips from this beer .

subtle sweet notes on the nose . very smooth flavor with crisp citrusy tastes well balanced to hints of sweet malty flavors .  i loved the way this beer looked . a very nice dark red color with a little head from the pour . just beautiful .  feels a tad heavy with a micro-carbonation that thickens this one up quite a bit .

s - i smell nothing . maybe a hint of smokiness , but nothing really all that noticable . this stuff is fantastic . i do n't really detect huge amounts of `` smokiness '' ( similar to the smell ) , but it 's a big flavor with coffee and some bitter chocolate flavor .  this beer poured a very deep and clear mahogany brown color with ruby tints . had a large creamy and clingy tan head .  i typically love belgian ales , limes , and unique beer - this one definitely falls into all categories . the smell was mildly astringent . the taste reminded me of the smell of the detergent my gradeschool janitor used on the floor . someone else mentioned anbesol and that would also seem quite accurate . i 'm disappointed , as a lime-kissed belgian blonde ale sounds fantastic . this one does n't quite do it .

the aroma is a bit muddled , with the voluminous dry-hopping fighting with a slightly nutty malt aroma . they might not have worked very well together on the nose , but they work wonders on the tongue !  pours out a deep dark amber with copper highlights . a four finger tan head sits atop and leaves big thick sticky clumpy lacing behind .  it is nicely carbonated ; the bubbles last till the end . the first sip is overwhelmed with carbonation and a tangy citrus under tone : almost like that first time or soda when the bubbles hit you , but this dose not last . the over all taste is a bit watery leaving a slight tangy-hopp after taste . it is a very easy beer to drink . the beer is a great beer to replace the useless monarchy of the current king of beers . for people who dont care what beer they drink and morally just go to bud , this is a great beer to get them hooked on .
s : pale maltiness . grassy . citrus hops . o : delicious pilsner .  brilliant , vibrant golden orange .  mouthfeel is medium bodied , a bit drying on the back end .

i literally only tried this beer because of the label . man was i surprised . the smoothness and the color were incredible . i enjoyed it in the bottle but i loved it in a pint glass poured from the bottle . the taste was extremely smooth and not bitter at all . not thick nor over powering by any means .  superb pour ; an impressive black body with a impressive brown head , nice lacing .  a little rough from overcarbonation .

leaves very nice lacing . s- gives off a slight tartness from the raspberry . though the nose was disappointing , the taste and overall experience make up for it .  poured a 12 oz bottle into snifter , served at 55 degrees f. a- jet black body with an ample , thick frothy/bubbly chocolate brown head , about 2 inches tall .  m - thinner than expected .

the aroma is the weakest link , as it is not a strong aroma . t - excellent . sweet malts and honey flavors .  16.9oz bottle a- pours a dark brown color with a massive light tan head that sticks around forever and leaves a good amount of retention .  i suppose an islay whiskey drinker might like the novelty of this beer . as a fan of wood aged beer and not of islay whiskey however , i would call this the worst thing i have ever tasted . i was the token beer geek in the group and as such i was the only one to finish the 3 or so ounces of beer in my glass . comments were : `` must be an aquired taste '' , `` aweful '' , `` that 's the worst thing i have ever tasted '' , and dumping the beer down the sink in descending of order preference . well , that being said , i am glad i tried it . it 's important to temper one 's taste for beer with the occasional dog brew .

s - mild and inviting with a light hop character and almost no booze .  which makes me laugh at how ludicrous it is to charge $ 10 a bomber for what is nothing more than an infected version of a normal recipe ... ok ... a : looks quite like hopdevil : a translucent amber with soft white head that forms pillowy clumps as it recedes .  slightly darker copper appreance . nice strong stench that fills your nostrils . it has a very unique strong taste at first but leaves a nice smooth after taste . i have never had it on tap but bottled is just as good i assume . highly suggested if you have not tried and are a big bock fan ...

from the smell , i 'm not getting a dipa , seems much milder . the taste is pretty pungent , but it seems like much of this is the alcohol . the hops are pretty tasty , but one dimensional ( as described 100 % centennial hops ) . i guess that explains the minimal hops in the nose . interesting technically as the 100-100-100 ... feat .  this is a great looking beer , the color is just beautiful .  body seemed a tad thin .

s- the nose is very clean with a faint hint of smoke coming through but no band-aid qualities . as the beer warms quite a bit some lighter notes of dark malt come through but are still covered by the smoke .  nice thick delicious looking three finger head that looks amazing . lacing clings all the way down the glass .  m : medium-light body . carbonation is medium-light .

very thick urine yellow with a thick head . smell : touch of fruit with a hint of alcohol , still not very impressed taste : execptionally smooth , strong fruit flavors but nothing over powering .  a : pours a beautiful hazy dark amber/brown color . a two finger head forms and sticks around .  m : medium bodied mouthfeel , seems a bit thin and not a lot of carbonation o : a well-done , not over-the-top stout .

nose is a bit odd , at first opening . after the beer was allowed to breath outside the bottle , the offensive smell was gone . smells like a top-notch witbier now . notes of spices , yeast , and tropical fruit fill the nose .  18.7 oz bottle into imperial pint glass : a : black opaque body with slight ruby highlights , and the great creamy light coffee head with excellent lacing , and permanent hold .  the mouthfeel is better than its parent beer , probably just swimming in maltodextrin boosting .

weak aroma of coffee dominates the smell . oats are noticeable as well .  a : poured a deep amber ( brown bottle ) color producing a cascade of effervescence along the insides of the glass reminiscent of sparkling fountain fireworks . this one filled the glass as a dark black but when held to the light it shone with ddep burgundy accents . the thick almost caramel colored head fizzled out slowly leaving huge amounts of residual lacing .  m : medium to light bodied .

s : funky . kinda like apple cider that turned to vinegar . t : awesome .  pours a beautiful deep copper color with a substantial beige head and ample lacing . very pretty beer .  m - almost medium bodied , i wish there was more creaminess and more body , definitely the most disappointing part of this beer .

chocolate aromas mostly , maybe a little smokiness .  pours a pitch black color with a thick , brown head that recedes a bit after a minute or two . good job here .  m - a little like bodied for a stout , but still light and creamy .

smell : smells like light grain , certainly not offensive as compared to similar priced beers , even though it was served less than cold .  12 oz bottle poured into pint glass a : black , black , black very little dark tan head , but it leave a very nice ring around the glass thought out the session ... great lacing ... wonderful looking brew .  m - not too carbonated , especially given the foaminess of the head .

smells somewhat like a subdued rauchbier with notes of smoke and jerky ... almost like dogfood , haha , the least pleasant feature of this experience .  `` a liquid poem to the glory of the hops ! your palate will be left blank ; with an enduring finish you will be able to take the next swig with bitter grace . great rich golden ipa , if you like hops this is your buddy .  body is light and yet seems to be a bit too light .

it looks luscious and rich . smell - not a whole lot on the nose . some roasted malts in the form of coffee , but it 's faint .  pours opaque tar-black body topped by persistent mid-sized brown head that sticks to the walls and forms stable collar as it sets .  the feel is a little thin , but still enjoyable and easy to drink .

the smell was average with hints of chocolate and coffee and roasted malts , definitely as i expect for this style of beer . the taste is nice , with a slight more carbonation than i like , but overall very pleasing .  pours a deep brown color bordering on black with a huge fluffy tan head that shows moderate retention and mad lace .  mouthfeel is light and fizzy , and drinkability is low due to the poor flavors .

this was my first taste of a heavier bodied beer , and it grew on me as i drank it.i found this beer to be well balanced.the taste was bordering on assalting me , but somehow it made me appreciative of the complex taste.i think i 've met women like that.very drinkable.i am yearning to taste the other versions of beer from this brewery .  it looked impressive , that 's for sure .  my one complaint is that i feel the body is slightly lacking for an oatmeal stout , especially one that 's on cask .

i could n't place the aroma as it is faint , but smells lightly of fruit , cherries and apples , maybe . the taste is very good , again with a hint of fruit , tangy and somewhat spicy .  a - pours a hazy golden amber color , two-finger off-white head with awesome retention and lacing , especially for the abv , really a great looking beer s - big pine , grapefruit and orange citrus hop bouquet on the nose with a substantial caramel malt component providing some depth , i suspect the aroma may have been a bit more hop dominated closer to the release , but the hops are still plenty present , light alcohol heat in the aroma as well t - the hops may have faded a bit more in the taste than in the aroma , but once again , this is still a very hoppy beer , big punch of sweet and bitter orange citrus up front with lighter notes of grapefruit and pine , midpalate is a bit sweet with a nice caramel malt component providing a backbone to the hop bitterness , the finish has a really nice bitter but lightly sweet orange marmalade flavor , definitely on the dry side , but not overly so , the alcohol is relatively well hidden with only a light boozy heat on the finish m - medium-to-full bodied , moderate carbonation , finish is on the dry side , nice alcohol warming d - quite drinkable for a big dipa , i suspect this has become a bit more `` balanced '' since it 's release , the alcohol is there but not overwhelming at all , very interesting and clean flavors another very impressive beer from surly .  it smells and tastes so nice that the thin body is even more disappointing .

the aroma 's not bad , it 's just nondescript . the flavor is , well , interesting . there 's a lot going on here . norfolk and waypal .  impressively dark reddish brown for a bock . beautiful lacing .  it was medium in body with moderate carbonation .

s : less aroma then i expected , initial hop and malt smell . nothing very over powering or impressive about it on the initial pour . pine and citrus notes as expected .  a - poured pitch black with no visible carbonation . rocky beige head is quite nice . great chunks of lacing around and great retention with a full finger on top .  sometimes a beer has kind of a vomit taste . not full on vomit , just kind of . this was one of those times . it was from an hours-old growler . i 've had a couple of other beers with that prominent flavor note , and once it was with a beer that did not normally have a vomit taste . is it me ? or is it some particular thing that has gone wrong with the batch ? i do n't know . but with so many yet to try , i do n't want to try this one again to find out .

s. earthy hop aroma . o no one flavor stands out .  12 oz twist of bottle poured into a pilsner at cellar temp - 2007 bottling appearance : this beer is a transparent brown and orange colored brew with a better than 2 inch head . great retention .  mouthfeel slacks off a little .

a-dark honey colored with a nice frothy cream head s-smells like stale grass with caramel hops . t-a very quick experience but its awesome . m-low carbonation but very thick with a dry finish o-it started out really good but it did slowly deteriorate , though still enjoyable all the way through .  [ best served in a english pint ] poured a clear medium amber with a medium sized creamy head that was fully lasting and had excellent lacing .  mouthfeel is a little thin for an oatmeal stout ( or ris as stated in the style here ) .

) the aroma is a little fruity and yeasty , with a touch of alcohol . it 's not really remarkable in any way . it 's very fruity , semi-dry , has a touch of pale malt flavor , and a characteristic belgian ester quality . light in body , and very spritzy .  lots of good lacing . the color is a perfect amber .  i have n't yet had 100 different beers , so this takes the title of oddest beer to ever cross my palate . this beer tastes like bananna-flavored lemonade . just esters , hops , and yeastiness . ( i tried one without yeast , then one with yeast since the back label says you should dump the yeast in . ) i did n't notice anything about moutfeel one way or the other , so i give it a score of average . as for drinkability , this is a highly-flavorful light beer that a person could have quite a few of in a drinking session .

shockingly almost no hop nose . deeply bitter front to back .  huge three finger head of mocha-like foam that retained beautifully and left curtains of sticky lacing on our glasses .  mouthfeel is ok , syrupy but as expected for such a liquor .

the brewer i believe has made a great malty ipa but it is lacking some of the ipa aroma that is normal for the american ipa style they are attempting . bitterness is predominate , however the american hop aroma the citrus and other aromas is not prevalent enough to make this a truly outstanding beer , when i go to freetail this is one of the first beers i order , the outstanding drinkability of it stands out , as one of the best beers for people that are hop heads . with the lack of the proper aroma that the style that are going after , i have to down grade the overall beer . here is hoping the second brew of this beer will have a stronger aroma and additional flavor given perhaps by dry hopping the beer .  bottle pours into a goblet the way an imperial stout should look - thick , viscous , covered in a dense blanket of tan foam that clings to the sides of the glass . light barely shows through at the edges , revealing a light brown tinge to the color , though it 's all black in the center . just beautiful velvety lacing .  this beer 's a little thin in body and the flavors are n't the strongest on the tastebuds but all in all this is a very good beer .

the smell is not strong , but i do n't have an exceptional sniffer .  on cask at rock bottom , braintree , massachusetts , nov 10 , 2004 this was a fantastic looking beer . it was a thing of beauty .  little bit chalky like most widmer beers ... - overall it 's a fantastic stronger version of drifter . just a bit thick and carbonated heavily for my taste in a double ipa .

great cascade of nitrogen after the pour . s- sweet roasted grains , chocolate covered coffee beans , licorice , raisins and prunes . m-nitro plain and simple . highly drinkable and infinitely enjoyable .  very striking black with red highlights and topped by a heavy tan head .  m : here is where is is lacking a bit for me . it a bit light , and over carbonated . if the mouthfeel was smoothed out a bit.. creamier , this would rank much higher in my estimation .

some faint toasted aromas and a hallertau scent , but mostly clean . toasted pale and pilsener malt sweetness meets a noble hop bitterness for a magnificent balance .  appearance - dark brown color while still allowing light through . solid head that dissolves slowly . average lacing that sticks to the side throughout .  hops do the bite the tongue quite sharply , but not as intensely as i was hoping , and as a previous reviewer stated , the flavors are not there to match . body is shockingly thin/light for a supposed double/imperial ipa , ditto with the abv . more intensity in hops , a better body , maybe some more balance with malt could bring improvements .

red hook ale brewery -- mud slinger spring ale nut brown ale -- '' complex -- malty nutty -- caramel '' -- 2010 12 oz . soft milk chocolate nut hint mild hop front . mild hop satisfying end . 6-pack $ 5.99 .  pours a beautiful black color with an wet , stick , and quite dense brown head .  mouthfeel : pretty full-bodied as far as ipas go . sharp and crisp too , with the alcohol peeling itself off your tongue afterwards .

i 'm an alesmith ipa freak but when you are looking for a smooth ipa please look at the racer 5 . i was pleasantly surprised with this ale . this beer is awesome , can hardly imagine it being an ipa , .  pours a 1.5 finger light tan whitish head over a crystal clear dark orange-gold liquid .  wish i had taken better notes in my beer journal t - funky , spicy ; in essence all over my tongue . love the complexity m - not the beer 's strong suit . another instance of judging on style vs. judging categorically d - considering its complexity , this is a very drinkable beer

it has a good color , but the smell wasnt very impressive . it didnt stand out much .  enormous tan head with exceptional lacing that layered perfectly after each sip .  taste is good , nice malts , good alpha - maybe too much . bubble is sharp but small and not foamy .

the aroma is a bit hard to decipher , which is a frequent problem at beer works because of the constant , potent waft of pub food odor interference .  poured from a bottle into an imperial pint glass a- black as night with a tan head , light carbination and some nice lacing of the glass s- very nice coffee malt alcohol , wioth some chocolate undertones t- far far out of whack , too young needs some years under the belt .  body is a little light for a stout .

s : the aromas are mainly bakers chocolate and cocoa . not much barrel in the nose and a bit weak for an imperial stout . t : damn the nose did not prepare me for the taste .  a : huge white frothy head over translucent golden . the head takes its time to mellow out , and retention is frothy .  this beer was an amber color with a thick white head that dissipated quickly . a nice fruity/spicy taste , with some warmth in the aftertaste . it was a little too fizzy for me , but still a very smooth and drinkable beer

a - pours a clear ( some might say crystal ) yellow with a gorgeous head on it s - at first i thought this was going to be a very old beer as it smelled very off on the first couple of whiffs . but as it warmed , hints of banana , spice , and clove came out of hiding . t - very clean taste - all the scents noted in the smell took over the palate .  pours a deep dark black being in a cave with no lights black , sitting on top is this big dark brown head , mud from the cave no doubt . the head receeds to a ring surrounding many clumps of foam floating in the middle , leaves a light coating of lace , a very fine looking stout .  the mouthfeel is medium bodied and a little watery .

smell is pleasant but so very small in stature that i can barely detect anything .  a - pours a fairly clear dark amber with 2 fingers of off-white head . dissipates slow and leaves beautiful lacing .  palate is slight corn and slight malt with a slight bitter hops and the carbonation . odouls is a slight of everything brew , no yummy malt , no well bittered hops bite , just a lot of gas ( carbonation ) and if you ask me , its a slightly boring brew .

this brew poured a very straw golden color with a half fizzy , but thick head on it that was a decent quarter inch and never fell . aroma is slightly hoppy , but not over the top like sam adams ' imperial pilsner , another good hoppy pilsner .  poured black with a tan head .  low carbonation dominates , with earthy and mellow malt tones . a bit flat , but it works for the esb . i do not find the normal citrusy american hops , maybe they have reworked the beer .

this head faded quickly smells a touch metallic , of cherries and a hint of sour . my initial reaction from the aroma was negative , but this really grew on me . nice beer .  poured a darkest coffee black with a large , fluffy , frothy brown head that slowly settled into a thin bubbly , sudsy lacing , small amount of ringed laced sticking , very impressive .  i get a whiff of something like sparkling mineral water , a hint a citrus , and light grains . the grapefruit is only slightly more prominent on the palate . has flavors of light , nondescript grains , with a few drops of watery fruit punch , with nothing really popping or asserting its presence . i do n't detect much in the way of ginger ( which the label says it was brewed with ) . easily my least favorite of the shiner lineup .

smell is very light , alcohol and chocolate . expected of this style .  huge cascade that works throughout the entire glass . black liquid follows a lighter brown , mixing with a deep brown.fun to watch , takes quite a while to settle .  it has a mouthfeel of cough syrup . the one saving grace is this still had some carbonation left in it .

not too much aroma to it . taste is medium bodied and very creamy . finishes nice and clean .  this beer pours a golden yellow color with a thick , fluffy white head . the head fades very slowly , leaving a thick sheat of lace .  my complaint is the really light body , something this dark could easily have a bit more weight to it without being overpowering . strong carbonation , mixed with the light body , almost gives a cola feel .

aroma : surprisingly peppery upfront with some dark fruit and cherries blending in . the aroma is quite light overall with only subtle hints of chocolate and caramel trying to come through . not a whole lot in the nose on this one . appearance : initially you 'll think this beer pours a jet black , but hold it up to the light and you 'll find a deep cherry red with nice clarity . overall : while the beer lacks aroma characteristics , the real payout is in the flavor and body .  poured black with a small bubbly brown head that didnt last long .  body is on the thin side of medium .

had this out of a bottle poured into a pint glass ... a : cloudy golden yellow color with a large white head ... s : some bitter hops and some faint malt ... t : wow , not as bitter as `` brutal '' implies . but starts with a nice maltiness the leads to a flowery bouquet of hops which are quite subdued , and actually taste very good , and not very bitter ... m : smooth and low carbonation ... d : a very good beer , i suppose the `` brutal '' part of the name may scare some people away , but it is actually quite drinkable ...  a- pours a dense white inch tall head that has ridiculous sustainability .  it feels a touch too thin and watery .

it is a nice aroma , but it is very faint for a tripel .  the beer is a bazy deep copper color , plenty of fine floating sediment and a huge frothy head , maybe 4 fingers worth .  i work at a distributer that sells this beer so i had to try it . at first open i thought that the high alcohol smell would make for a bad beer . after a couple sips , it was actually pretty good . i would compare it to miller high life ... .except that you get smashed after two or three beers . since beer is for the purpose of getting drunk ... this is the right one . if it taste good and serves it 's purpose , why not take this one . since i do work at a distributor that sells high end beers , if anyone ask for a good beer that will serve its purpose , i will highly recomend camo & gt ;

i get very little aroma off of it . it smells good , nice toasty malt , but its so faint that it is barely there .  appearance : heavy amber with a thick haze head : nice frosty dark tan head smell : heavy sweet malt , coriander is there with some heat taste : get some heat right off the bat that turns into a rich malty layer with a subtle bitter hop weight : light body with a high to medium carbonation finish : bit of a dry on the end with a rich maltyness and back notes of a subtle bitter hop .  light bodied with a bland feel on the palate and touch of carbonation tingle .
the aroma is fruity sweet and slightly tart . hints of yeast .  this beer pours and smells wonderful .  a thicker then water feel , but not much . o- very much on the lighter side for a hefeweizen .

( s ) very surprised in the fact that it didnt have much of an aroma at all . it had hints of chocolate in the aroma but other than that was very bland and was not impressed .  really really black . great looking .  the ultimate cross-over lager to bigger and better beers . still , it was the first `` national '' beer i can remember that decided that a brisk hop aroma was not a bad thing as the macro brewers had seemingly ordained . the body varies somewhat between light to medium-perhaps based on the brewery from which it was contracted ?

the aroma of this beer is rather sweet , that of caramel type malt and maybe a sherry aroma , judging by this and the bottle date , the beer may be a bit over the hill , well see . i can not detect much of any hop aroma . overall i truly enjoyed this one , not as much as the uerige sticke , but this was very good . i would like to try a fresher sample sometime and see if the aroma is any different .  look : pours a cool looking copper color with a great 1 inch off white head and great retention and great circular lacing smell : great hop aroma .  moderate carbonation , medium-light body , this part of odouls is decent .

the nose is of bananas , pears , bubble gum ... what would you expect form a hefe ? the what aroma finishes things off quickly . well , damn . this is amazing .  drank from a 341 ml bottle served in a pint glass the beer poured an absolute pitch black with a tight , frothy , near three-finger , mocha-colored head that faded to a flimsy film .  the body was medium light and just a bit on the thin side .

smell is mild , with the scent of hops and alcohol coming through .  dark mahogany colored pour with a massive , frothy , off-white head .  mouthfeel is n't as stellar as the taste . there is a distinct lack of carbonation that i like but the beer finishes very dry which does n't work to well . good thing this one tastes so good because the flavor of this almost full bodied beer distracts from the lackluster feel .

the smell was average a little hoppier than some . the taste was great . very hoppy all around with a little more malt at the end .  pours sandy brown with a silky tan head . excellent lacing and retention .  yielded a monstrous thick white head.a very cloudy yellowish-orange.very inviting aroma with hints of spiceskind of smells like unibroue 's la fin du monde.a very crisp mouthfeel almost harsh like seltzer.very citrus flavor with a slight bitter finish that lingers in the back of the throat.a bit but not much lace.high drinkability with this one.very crisp , clean , and refreshing .

on opening , the aroma was mild and malty , the slightest bit of citrus in the background . the pour : i was surprised by how light this beer is , but still , a very nice light gold , slightly cloudy , small white head that fads fast , this is a very inviting shade of gold .  pours with one of the most gorgeous orange/golden hues imaginable . super hazy with a generous foamy white head that just wo n't go away . but this is seriously one gorgeous looking beer !  this is a little lighter in feel and really does n't give that nice buzz that railbender 's 6.8 % leaves you with .

grimbergen dubbel pours a very dark amber color , with a moderate head . there didnt appear to be a very strong smell .  it 's pitch black and shiny , with a giant brown head , leaving great lacing and retention .  did not like this beer at all . i have had many worse , but i found no compelling reason to finish this one off . the look is pretty nice , but the aroma is overpowering with a over malty smell . the same goes with the taste ... was it sparged too hot ? i 'm not sure but it tastes like that too me . it does go down nicely considering the taste . i did n't finish off the beer and do n't see why you should either , it 's just way to malty for a pilsner for me .

nose is ... weak . if the nose was weak , that did n't carry over to the flavor . very nice finish leaving you wanting for more .  a- poured into my dfh snifter ... starts with a ridiculous white head that fills the second half of the glass and continues to pile above the rim ... has great retention and leave an abundance of lacing behind . beer is a cloudy straw color with light activity s- sweet wheat , citrus , bit of brett t- sweet wheat and citrus , spices , with a tiny bit of bitterness in the finish .  m : carbonation and weight are really just average .

smell : fruity and cheesey . it smelled as though i should have a good cut of cheddar to go with it . oranges , tangerines , orange colored fruit . i felt like this could replace the standard `` lawnmower '' beer . replace that feeling with and beer with a don de dieu , and you 'll smile through the next mouthful of grass clippings  hazy orange body with an extremely large fluffy white head with extreme retention . leaves massive pillows of lace everywhere and a pile of foam behind after i drink the whole glass . raises the bar one step higher for top notch looks .  the pint i had had no head , and very little if any carbonation .

s - chocolate with a hint of coffee . t - long roasted malt revealing a chocolate flavor that is smooth and soft .  appearance : very impressive . body is a brilliant hazy straw color with a neverending stream of bubbles rising to the top .  m - the feel is rather watery with a coarse texture .

22 oz . the aroma was soft semi-chaulk . some toastyness . the taste was good , not super cold so the taosted malts faired well along with some roasted coffee bean and chocolate . overall good drinkability , low abv so happy st. pats and have another !  appearance : a full three inch head that persisted with some lacing .  the mouthfeel on this seems somewhat like it 's mostly carbonation , which disappoints somewhat , but it 's full and silky .
the aroma is typical pilsener .  as with most nitro cans , great head , and as always , watching a guinness poured right settle is pretty satisfying .  the body and mouthfeel are decent , at least .

not much scent to the beer . very , very smooth taste and feel , with slight bitterness .  santa cruz ale works dark night oatmeal stout is a dark ruby black ale with a brown sugar colored , gel-topped dense foam that has outstanding retention and lacing .  kind of like chocolate flavored sparkling water . ok here .

autumn gold in color , nice malty aroma , sheet lacing . not too much head , but left beautifully striped lacing all through my glass .  a - the body is the color of deep mohogany . it has a thick nitro-like head with excellent stamina . ~ this is a good drinker .  the mouthfeel is medium to full bodied and kind of watery .

smell : not very strong , but it could be me , this is back to back days . taste and mouthfeel : delicious , nutty dark malts with a rich flavor , mouthfeel was rich and buttery .  poured a nice 2 finger head which left an incredible lace on the glass.had a reddish brown color .  the body of this brew is a little skinny , but the flavor profile makes this one a nice drinker .

s - it 's not an overwhelming smell , but picking up some traces of roasted malt , coffee , and chocolate . a bit of faint fruits way in the back end . t - actually a pretty full sweet coffee taste , almost a bit mocha-ish with the combination of the chocolate . it 's not the best stout you 'll ever have , and there are better coffee stouts out there , but this is a solid brew .  pours an absolutely beautiful dark , opaque orange with a two-finger off-white head . great looking brew .  mouthfeel : a bit thin for a bottle-conditioned weiss beer ( at least i 'm assuming it 's bottle-conditioned ) . still , there 's a enough great things about this beer to offset the rather pedestrian mouthfeel .

thin head which gives off a dense malt barrier . medium balanced , lots of malt , nutty but subtle with a good hop bite for a clean finish .  as the beer begins to settle and the cascading effect kicks in , a beautiful scene in a glass takes place .  m - mouthfeel is light and thin , though not terribly so .
