it has a dark golden color with a very nice unfiltered haze . smell is the only lacking part of this beer . i can smell some sweet caramel malts and some dark raisin-like fruits . one of the most well-balanced saisons i 've ever had that also maintains a lot of good tastes in it .  it poured a minimum head that dissipated rather quickly . the color had lovely hues of dark red on an amber background that captured the light when held up in a way that made the whole thing quite brilliant . i was literally captivated by the appearance of this beer .  fresh mouthfeel , but not much taste at first , clear chocolate and a bit of coffee in the aftertaste though .

the smell was not too impressive but it was very tasty .  nitro-can , 3.6 % abv a : pours amber , with a thick white nitro head , sticky full lacing . certainly looks great .  mouthfeel : overcarbonated . if this was poured and left out for say an hour at a controlled temp it would be amazing .

these babies are so light but not a light beer and typically i dislike light beers . the smeel yes i understand is n't great but the flavor and the knowing you are taking part in a beer your grandparents drank is great .  huge frothy tan head has super strength retention . a beauty to look at . on the weak side in the nose . notes : an amazing appearance , blank nose , and a lighter but toastier version of a belgian strong dark ale .  m : carbonation is light , and the feel is a bit thin , especially considering the roasted malts in here .

purchased at cheers in carrollton , ga aroma : very light aroma .  absolutely a beautiful beer . pours a ruby red with a small head that lays on top throughout .  what this beer lacks in a thinner mouthfeel actually makes up for it in drinkability .

s - light and malty with a fruit punch hint .  poured into a tulip . a : pours a golden/orange with an explosive , creamy head that dissipates extremely slow leaving behind a thick layer of lacing . excellent clarity and moderate-heavy carbonation .  m : tingly , very prickly carbonation d : i could only drink one glass of this , but it is delicious !

taste is off coming right of the fridge ( and was bad when they poured it right from the tap at the brewpub ) , but it really flexes its awesome muscle as it warms up and approaches room temp . but that quickly dies down on the tongue and a rain of ( good ) carbonation helps give rise to a wave of gorgeous , raw , and heavy malts .  dark , murky brown color with a huge head of fluffy , tan foam . the head stays for a good while before leaving copious amounts of lacing stuck to the glass and swirling around the surface .  12 oz bottle into a dfh signature glass wow what a mess this beer was . while it looked fairly innocuous in the glass what was hiding in its depths was anything but ... butterscotch . lots and lots of butterscotch . this is where diacetyl men and diacetyl women meet up to have little bastard diacetyl babies . if saranac would change the label to saranac butterscotch porter they would probably have an award winner on their hands because this sure as hell meets that description . in a word ... terrible .

s : not really much smell here . the only real smell was a little bit of malt , but mainly fruit . t : very complex . malty .  golden body with an immense white head that leaves a frosting of lace on the glass .  somewhat thin but easy to drink .

very drinkable winter seasonal . big sky always has had good beers and this `` winter '' seasonal proves it .  appearance & gt ; pours beautifully . a nice hazy warm brown colour .  mouthfeel is a little dry once you kill one or two of these bad boys , but the taste and smell definitely makes up for it .

aroma was astringent and really soapy . had a mild molasses and orange peel tinge .  pours very dark with a big pillowy brown head . nice cascade effect if poured down the center .  thinner and lighter bodied than i expected , but it does n't detract from the enjoyment of this beer .

the smell was light , but very sweet and malty .  dark caramel brow color with a lasting beige head of fine bubbles .  it smells like rotten fruit ( bananas , apples , and grapes ) . it tastes like cotton candy ice cream mixed with bittersweet oaky busch light . in the words of samir nahinanajad : `` this ... is a f -- k '' update : the last 2/3 of this went down the drain . this is the second beer i 've ever done this with ... i do n't waste beer .

poured a mainly clear pale yellowish lager golden with a foamy white head , but there are some tiny pieces of sediment floating around in glass , not something i want in pale lager . the freshness date indicates that this only around six months old , so i find the tiny chunks of sediment to be strange , and well , kinda of scary . aromas of sweet bready pale malts , lemony and hop spicy , generic , but not that bad .  the beer after it release from the 22-ounce brown bottle sets in the glass an ebony color with the head majestic in size and creamy in texture the color a winsome light chocolate , as it slowly erodes the lace forms a fine sheet upon the glass .  i found this beer to be incredibly fragrant and smooth , with a fairly strong hazelnut flavour . not particularly heavy or bold , and would probably not be easy to drink more than one because of the powerful almost coffee like flavour . the hazelnut flavour and aroma is n't quite overpowering , but it 's close .

it 's a bit underpowered imo , but it smells pleasant enough though it 's a bit lacking in complexity . needs more oomph in the nose department , but it tastes wonderful and goes down like nobody 's bid-ness .  the beer poured black with a tan head .  the body is typical for the style .

the aroma is very subdued , soft florally hops and maybe a little lemon/lemon rind .  it 's beautiful . enough with the head , the body is a nice gradient from yellow at the bottom to a dark orange at the top . kind of hazy , occasional carbonation bubbles rise up and add to the head .  tingly mouthfeel brought in the flavor of more hoppy fruit-sweet malt mix .

this was one of the worst lambic beers i have ever had . it 's tastes of composting fruit , rotting wood and sandalwood .  black as night with a thick tan head perfectly perched on top . tons of sticky lace all over the glass .  finishes a little dry . mouth feel is almost champagne like and very effervescent .

really does n't smell much like anything , but tastes fantastic . dubbels are my favorite style of beer and this one does n't disappoint .  beautiful to look at and very easy to drink .  its possibly the second smokiest beer i 've smelled behind the alaskan smoked porter . the flavors are very well integrated . it drinks a little light for a porter but with the flavor profile its ok . this beer is pretty superb , i 'm very impressed , its an excellent smoked beer .

the smell is perhaps not this beer 's strongest asset , but it 's still fair , and more interesting than most local lagers , truth be told . butter , fruit and leafiness , with a strange something in the background that 's a bit off-putting . the taste more than makes up for the nose , however . not overly thin ; nice to see a lager with a bit of meat to it . a great sessional ( given the abv , probably a plus !  a hypnotising dark amber color , very pretty to look at . a very hearty looking beer which brings you back in time .  i have enjoyed several growlers of this beer . it pours dark , with a nice head and good carbonation at first , but it goes flat if you do n't finish the growler in 1 night . probably normal , but too bad since i ca n't buy it in smaller containers . taste is smooth , with roasted chocolate flavor , and very drinkable . not so drinkable that i can pound away the whole growler in one sitting , but very enjoyable as a refreshing beverage in warmer weather .

very good head retention & lacing s : biscuitty malt & some toffee & slight citric hops as this warms . t : biscuitty malt , lemony & herbal hops up front .  when this beer was poured into my glass , it had a large tan head with fine-small sized bubbles that was fully diminishing . the body was mostly clear with lively carbonation observed .  mouthfeel is a bit lacking .

smell is almost not at all but slight chocolate coffee taste is nice !  the appearance of the beer is truly amazing : a towering , everlasting , rocky , white head tops a coppery-caramel colored liquid .  m : sweet , citrus , malty .

clean aroma with a slight sweet malt and floral hop , and mild bready yeast as it warmed .  great deep reddish brown color , with an impressive three-finger head .  appearance : brown nutty color smell : nothing notable , somewhat sweet taste : delicious sweet barley and hoppy flavor moutfeel : medium carbonation , not full bodied drinkability : good enough to enjoy as a regular

s - no real fruit smell but smells of yeasty malts and bread .  the retention was outstanding and the lacing in curtains , an excellent looking beer falsely pumped up by nitro jets , like a woman with fake d cups .  the fizzy yellow stuff of the great white north , as far as i 'm concerned . that 's right , corn . prominent in the aroma and taste , along with some traces of malt and hops . i was quite thirsty after a bout with us customs , and this failed to satisfy . difficult to finish .

first off let me say this beer has my all-time favorite bottle ... two goats drinking out of a chalice ... gosh those are some lucky goats ! ... amber in color with a nice soft creamy lace..not as thick or heavy as s.a , or salvator , or optimator ... .pretty easy drinking with a good but not overbearing sweetness ... .some mild hop bitterness on the back of the tounge on the finish ... this does not feature the magnitude of complex flavors of salvator or s.a. but is solid nonetheless..definitely some caramel tones with a slight hint of raisens..does not have the molasses texture and flavor some doppels feature ... definitely worth trying if you see it ... reasonably priced too ...  picked up at oak knoll liquor in orcutt poured a nice straw colored yellow with massive carbonation . the head was white and massive and a clean white .  m not very much mouthfeel .

smell : very subtle . would have expected a little more . light , grainy malts and a very gentle , slight floral hop presence .  thick , opaque black with a thick creamy brown head . looks like a frothy milkshake . quite lacy and tantalizing . a newcomer to atl and a welcome one .  appearance : dark orangish yellow , good head that recedes too quickly but has good white lacing . smell : reminds me of a homebrew with a bacterial infection . taste : i do n't know but get it off my tongue ! somebody grab a water hose ! who buys this garbage ? ! drinkability : if you tried to force this on prisoners , they 'd complain to the warden .

smell is surprisingly light , definitely getting the hop scent . pretty floral overall , i 'm not picking up a whole lot else .  pours a four finger light tan , rocky head that fades slowly to a thin layer leaving some lace . nice deep , clear amber color .  m : the mouthfeel was the only disappointment , as i was expecting something a little bit more evervescent given the light color - in my mind a light ipa needs to be more carbonated than a dark ipa .

a - dark brown , chestnut s - light malt t - sweet and malty , lighter than newcastle m - very crisp , biting i would definitely have this beer again - it was served up with a spicy plate of red beans and rice .  pours amber with a a 4 fingers+ fluffy sand colored head . great lacing & head retention s : a hint of caramel & malt t : sweet malt & herbal/piney hops ; finsihed prickly & semi-malty mf : light/medium bodied with pricklyness , not balanced drinks average , this is a different beer than bottled version ; i 'm so confused ?  what a name ! good thing this one lives up to that mouthful . a cloudy ( unfiltered ) straw gold extra special bitter with orange hues . developed a creamy , glass-crawling white head with good retention that left some nice lacing . strong , hoppy aroma with a medium-heavy body . malty bread , apricots , butterscotch , citrus notes . yum . a great example of their extreme series , bold and complex .

the smell is alright , i suppose . a little malty , not really much here . did n't smell like much of anything .  there was a thick half inch of thick foam and a strong persistent lacing .  great brew to enjoy on warm or hot days . apricot aroma eclipses any malt or hops on the nose . taste is predomanantly apricot/peach , with just a slight bite of hops in the finish . the clean malt helps to balance out the apricot . a great , simple , summer session beer for hot days .

there is a slight bannana aroma here with a little sweetness remniscent of honey . the nose is on the light side , but beckons me in for a closer encounter . its a nice one , and a great climax to an enjoyable journey of wheat beers . cheers to bell 's for giving me the opportunity to try all of the wheat beers , but especially this one .  a : brilliantly red in color with a crisp foamy white head , sticks to the glass like no other - and perfectly clear .  the flavor is there , it 's just a little thin .

no real smell at all though .  bright orange/amber color and absolutely clear . incredible lacing for this brew - this is one nice looking beer .  if this brew has a weakness it is in the mouthfeel , it is light for an oatmeal stout .

smells a bit acidic , with only a hint of caramel in the background . overall , a very good , though not great , beer .  12oz bottle with freshness date app : deep , deep ruby red with hues of brown and orange . a small , tan head with tons of lacing smell : sweet , thick malt .  mouthfeel smooth and milk-like . i would prefer the carbonation be toned down a bit for a silkier , less astringent effect .

smell : mild nose . some malt sweetness and a slight fruity tinge of apples and pears . decent , but unfortunately too mild to really make a statement . looked great , felt great , but just the weak nose held it back a little . definitely a great drinkable belgian blond .  looks really great for an english brew due to the richness of the foam .  mouthfeel light body with a bit of carbonation .

poured from a 40 oz bottle ... .gee , maybe i could get a 6 pack of this stuff sometime ... the pour foamed up pretty well , smell was allright thought it might be good afterall .  a thick sheet of lace formed and lasted for the entire length of the sample . a great looking beer .  mouthfeel is near average , a bit more body and flavor concentration would be welcome .

nose is n't outstanding with this one and there is n't a clear aroma that stands out . in fact , i really have to breathe deep and use my imagination for this one .  11.2 oz bottle a : pours deep mahogany/brown color with an impressive foamy head on top , about 1.5 fingers in height , just off-white in color . really nice retention , this thing is not going anywhere .  mouthfeel is light , but some weight from the yeast sediment , but the carbonation is weak .

a-nicely clear copper brew . s-caramel maltiness , slight berry fruitiness . t-caramel malty sweet , countered by a firm hop bitterness . m-medium-light body feels very smoothe and finishes clean , making it quite quaffable .  black . black black . big dark brown head of tiny tiny bubbles - you know it will last .  surprising hoppiness is only accentuated by the high carbonation level .

i freaking love this beer ! i have not had an abita beer that i did n't like . it 's a brown ale , similar of a newcastle or sam adams brown ale . very nice maltiness with a smooth chocolaty finish .  a - deep ruby hue populated with suds rising up to the head , perfectly poured . mild retention , and the lacing is beautiful .  the mouthfeel is a bit thin with low carbonation .

aroma - malty and raisiny sweet as expected , but not real intense . drinkability - tasty and dangerous , they are smart to serve this in the smaller 10-ounce goblets .  excellent retention and an awesome web of lace was left behind .  mouthfeel is a bit syrupy for me , but this beer far outweighs any cider around .

this is a very decent lager worth checking out . it is so good to see boston beer company checking out new styles .  a wonderful hazy copper color with a fluffy white had that subsides leaving a single horizontal rim with vertical spokes . a very unusually consistent pattern the aroma is best described as sweet .  mouthfeel - light smoothness , carbonation is a tad low . average weight .

i thought i 'd be hit with chocolate in the aroma but all that really comes out is a little bit of toffee and maybe a bit of roastiness . it 's like there 's a ton of dark malt aroma there but they all cancel eachother out into one muted sorta sweetness . the taste is what i would describe basically as a pretty good but not too unique imperial stout .  look is perfect in every way - amazing retention , head , lacing , carbonation .  my first scotch ale and it made me feel pretty good on an empty stomach . the great dane makes some great beers , but they make everything too thin .

though i dont remember this from previous bottles of celebration , the smell is quite boring , just beer-like . smells almost like a dark german lager ... bready , yeasty etc .  pours golden , opaque with disturbed sediment and lots of tiny rising bubbles .  m - medium bodied with extremely lively carbonation that is a bit too brisk and prickly .

its smell is very faint from the glass . but there is a coffee scent from it . its taste is very rich and good . its definately a strong stout .  appearance : perfectly dark with a wonderful head from the nitro that left great lacing all down the glass .  very light body . smooth from the over active carbonation . i 'm not a big fan of light beer .

smells toasty and malty . not a strong smell however .  poured a deep dark black with the darkest brown head i think i have ever seen . nice lacing and retention as well .  the mouthfeel is medium bodied with little carbonation .

then the scent of the hops kicked in .  appearance : pours a hazy orange caramel color with a huge 4 finger thick and creamy off-white head . a touch of sediment pools right on top of the billowy head . the head was so big it rose a full 2 fingers above the rim of the goblet . perfect head retention .  there 's just something off with the taste that did not work m : crisp and light d : drainpour .

i ca n't smell much , but that could be my nose . i get a faint molasses smell .  im sampling a cold draft pint poured straight from my kegerator . the beer pours a clear copper hue with soft fluffy eggshell white head foaming up several cm and fading gradually .  mouthfeel is creamy , and would be even better if half of the carbonation was n't so harsh , with sharp edged bubbles .

toasted crystal malt and light grassy hop aroma with some citrus/grapefruit just pulling thorugh . first sip has a touch of pale malt sweetness and a husky grain taste .  really dark body , garnet highlight when held to the light . light tan head on top . voluptuous head 1 '' thick that reduced slowly leaving thick lacing behind . good head retention . this has everything i 'd look for in appearance , even if it might be a little dark .  for real , closest mass-produced craft beer to snpa . coppery , high crystal malt appearance with nice head and typical bottled carbonation . grassy . flavor is a bit bitter at first followed by some mild hoppy/flowery/cascady flavors . bite at finish . not too much but bitter enough to say this is a pale ale . fine everyday drinking pale ale but nothing exceptional or cheeky . b+

the nose is somewhat disappointing . did n't get any cherry initially because the burnt malts kind of took over . as it settles a bit , the cherry starts to come out but still subtle .  a : amazing creamy white head and excellent lacing . strangely lighter than most ipa 's .  feel is moderately light with a fair amount of carbonation .

an obvious sweet citrus hop aroma but that 's about all going on .  poured into a thick glass mug . pours almost pitch black with an off white , cream color head .  oy gevalt ! pours an interesting reddish brown slightly hazy body with a finger of beige-white head . head lingers and it laces the glass well . aroma is nice and sweet . tastes very hoppy with dates dark fruit notes . a bit of a bite in the aftertaste , that is not pleasant !

aroma is lacking again on this one . could use some more of that amber malt aroma and some hop aroma but you can smell a bit of citrus and some amber maltiness . i would say it 's very similar to my favorite red from three floyds but missing some of the aroma they get . nice malty red flavor but with a nice hop flavor too .  pours a nice copper orange color with a two finger head that falls to about a 1/4 inch cap , but it stay from top to bottom leaving sheets of lacing as it goes down .  mouthfeel is watery with a crisp finish .

good balance of malt and hops ( taken to the extreme ) in the aroma . leather/earthy aroma very slight star anise/black licorice flavor . bitterness is there , yet very tolerable .  then it became a cloudy orange . super huge moutainous large bubbled pock marked head . nice chunks of lace left behind .  aroma is orange and lemon wedges , sweet and sugary . taste is nicely balanced , lemon zest and pepper for a little kick of spice , but not quite a hefe in the traditional sense . slight bitterness at the end from the hops . nothing to write home about but a very sessionable ale . a solid american wheat ale , a good choice to have while watching some baseball in the summer or at a fourth of july party .

i love the look , the smell , and it has a creamy mouthfeel .  a - red body topped bya medium tan head standing over three inchaes tall at first pour . the body is clear and offers some transparency .  flavors are big , and the mouthfeel is incredibly full and well rounded .

very nice coffee malt notes hit your nose , along with the woodsy hops afterward .  poured into a chilled pint glass . beautiful color of chestnut brown -- nice head and decent lacing .  mouthfeel - very smooth with easy-going carbonation . a healthy body , really lifts up the flavors .

feels somewhat flat o : has a great smell , but the lack of carbonation leaves the flavor a little unbalanced .  full copper colored head with excellent lace and retention .  lush and extremely creamy on the palate . super fine carbonation structure ; uncious and smooth , velvety even . the booze becomes a bit burdening , as is expected with the high abv .

the body is a smidge to thin given a stout , but still good . d- nice coffee stout , especially @ $ 7.49/6pk .  appearance- pours a hazy dark reddish brown with a beautiful one finger super creamy off-white head . a perfect half finger cap and collar remain the entire beer along with thick sheets of coated lacing .  m : right about perfect for the style ( or nearly any style ) .

complex , balanced and very nice . t - honey sweetness and spicy clove with apple , pear , lemon , belgian yeast , bready wheat and bubblegum blended in the background . i would like it a touch dryer but it is still nice .  darkest mahogany , almost black , with a thick light tan head .  excellent mouthfeel , i enjoyed this one a lot .

s : as sweet as you can get . caramel and chocolate covered raisins . this is one of the most chocolate smelling beers i have had the pleasure of drinking- like liquified charleston chew . american strong is a catch-all category and i guess this goes there but to put this and compare to a beer like arrogant bastard is not right . enormous full body with low carbonation and creamy .  beer pours a really beautiful golden color with a nice head , looks perfect for a pilsner , perhaps a bit more color than many .  as in the nose , some alcohol in the finish m : incredibly smooth , creamy mouthfeel . full bodied with just enough carbonation d : great , easy drinking imperial stout .

the aroma kind of rivals goose island 's bourbon county stout , which is extremely impressive . t : smooth , rich dark/chocolatey malt with a hint of vanilla right before the bourbon takes over and floods the palate .  the beer pours an all encompassing black , with a massive , gorgeous light chocolate head rising up and displaying some staying power . gobs of lacing cling to the glass and leave happy ending as one of the best looking stouts i 've ever seen .  silky smooth mouthfeel with only mild carbonation makes this one lean a little to the full side as far as body goes . full bodied or not , i could go for a few more of these .

a - dark copper with a thick white head and excessive lacing s - pine , grapefruit , apple , malt - smells tasty t - huge amounts of pine and grapefruit fighting for tastebud domination .  appearance - the ideal pour . motor oil on the way out , a reverse cascading head . thick mocha cap is creamy with some large bubbles . a sticky layer of solid lace adheres all the way around .  absolutely a wonderful mouthfeel perfectly carbonated hiding its abv very well .

piney , citrusy , and fruit punch aromas attack your nose . super smooth and malty with enough hops present to remind you this is beer . full and chewy mouthfeel.very tasty ale ; i want to drink more , but high abv prevents that .  poured a beautiful slightly hazy deep golden to orange-y colour into a kasteel glass .  mouthfeel is great . very smooth and silky thanks to the oatmeal with just the right amount of carbonation .

smell absolutely delicious . sweet , very chocolatey , milk , and some malt . taste was very nice too .  pours honey colored with 2 fingers+ of fantastic fluffy pearl white head . insane lacing & head retention s : fruitty with grassy hops , plus candi sugar t : herbal hops , dryness & much apricot , along some warming booze up front .  mouthfeel is thick and creamy chewy . mouthfeel of manufacturer 's cream .

the fruit loops of beer ! ! ! i love this stuff , nothing else out there tastes anything like it . the menagerie of fruits and beer blends perfectly into a concoction unlike any other .  a - huge pillowy head . great lacing . orange hint of color .  the taste is mellow chocolate on the front as it glides down with its thick silky mouth feel . almost a fudge aftertaste .

nose is huge chocolate and roasted malt . overall , a very nice beer , although i have a guess at the steep price and probably wo n't be dropping the loot for another .  all sorts of red , yellow , and orange hues . one of the most beautiful beers ive ever seen .  it is quite pleasing to the pallet and has an amazing mouthfeel , i also had no problem finishing up such a large bottle because of its wonderful drinkability .

smell is the best part of this brew in my opinion . the smell is flowery and a light sweetness with honey . amazingly refreshing and evokes the senses creating a surreal dreamlike experience . a hint of fresh flowers .  dark as an abyss with a large tan head on top that effortlessly stayed on top throughout the session , and even when it did fade a touch , left behind a large amount of lacing up and down the sides of the glass .  m : medium-light bodied , remarkably smooth and creamy . d : very enjoyable and satisfying .

very nice . wow - where to begin with the taste , again tremendous complexity .  a - moderately vigorous pour produces a huge mocha-colored , dense , sponge-like 3 '' head that recedes to a broken 1/8 '' head that remains to end leaving heavy lace .  the mouthfeel is absoutely perfect for this style ... thick , creamy and subdued ... as i mentioned before ... the consistency of a nitro , yet this brew still maintains is flavour .

it looks good , smells delightful , tastes good and feels quite pleasureable on the palate .  12 oz bottle poured into a nonic - fridge - best by 7-18-09 appearance : pours a very clear , pale yellow , urine color with a 2.5 '' tall white head . it shows great retention , and lots of foamy , gobby lace .  mouthfeel is large , with almost a creamy texture .

aroma is - woo wee strong , seriously hoppy with a strong citrus tone that is a mixture of good grapefruit and sweet orange . it pours a nice clear orange amber with an average pale tan head that leaves minimal lacing . flavor is quite hoppy , with a good evergreen tone , minimal bitterness , and an undertone of grapefruit with just a whisper of sweetness .  it 's enormous and has great retention . very dramatic lacing goes down my entire sa perfect pint glass .  almost a perfect mouthfeel , both for the style and for a beer in general .

an intense and fully enjoyable aroma . mouthfeel is medium to light bodied , crisp , medium to low carbonation .  a : deep black body . large light brown head . good staying power .  nice mouthfeel and great body to it along with quite a flavor punch to your taste buds .

this beer has the most awesome aroma . sweet fresh juicy grapefruit and it never leaves . so nice . smallish white head that settles to a ring and a smear , covers an semi-clear amber of orangish red .  pours a gorgeous bright glowing orange color with a lasting offwhite head .  i like the unique green apple and middle eastern-style rose candy flavors , and it has a nice , full mouthfeel for such an easy drinking brew , with lots of dark yeast floating at the bottom .

clear , copper hue with visible carbonation topped by a thick off-white layer of foam that receded within a minute or two . fantastic smell of floral hops ( maybe some distant grapefruit ) and an underlying biscuit aroma .  amazing retention and lacing .  mouthfeel is great . alot going on in the mouth . full bodied and crazy carbonation .

a good combination of biscuity malt and hop bitterness . dangerously drinkable . an excellent candidate for long ageing .  huge creamy head , one of the darkest i 've seen . awesome retention and super sticky lacing .  mouthfeel is excellent , best i have ever had from an ipa , i know this is coming from the oatmeal , but this is serving as inspiration for me to make a good oatmeal ipa at home now , too bad this is n't around longer as it was a great beer .

aroma is wonderful . light and playful . makes me think of summer days .  no apparent freshness date a : clear , dark orange with a thick , meringue-like head that leaves thick lacing . a very attractive beer .  mouthfeel is buttery - so smooth with just a tinge of carbonation .

aroma : smelled very floral , almost like lilacs . very powerful . a little pine and citrus was also present . very pleasing and good in the mouth .  dark amber with ruby highlights , a rocky tan head and wonderful lacing .  m : medium-bodied , low carbonation results in a creamy and silky smooth mouthfeel .

aroma is fantastic , with a load of molasses , evolving into coffee , chocolate , and dark fruits . do not take me wrong , it is a great taste ; just not as great as the aroma . once you get over that ( slight ) letdown , it is all enjoyment .  a disappointingly small amount of lacing is the only thing keeping this beer from a perfect appearance .  has a great mouthfeel .

a fruity blast that brings to mind peaches mangos melon & pineapple , nice.a hint of caramel sqeezes through . tropical fruity goodness and malty caramel dominate .  i also had it from the hand pump which made a great beer even better . its like a stack of pancakes without the full belly .  mouthfeel - it has a nice blanketing feel , a moderate heaviness that coats without being a filler . full body matches the flavor perfectly .

intense aroma , tremendous estry complexity . cloves and other spices join the banana topped off with phenols and a note of solvent alcohol . this taste matches the scent better than perhaps any any other quality brew i 've had . medium bodied creamy mouthfeel .  a : it comes in a clear bottle and is a dark amber colour ; it pours the same with a one finger white head with webby lacing . this is the best looking beer ever .  it is incredibly smooth and creamy in the mouth , certainly one of the creamiest feels i 've ever had .

the aroma is where this beer begins to really score well . prune , wheat , black pepper and cloves dominate the nose . taste : carmel complements the cloves that were so dominate in the aroma . this beer 's relation to schneider weisse is pretty evident .  it poured as black as a stout with a supprsingly phenomenal tan head .  mouthfeel is full bodied with minimal carbonation .

s : chocolate , dark chocolate , big roasted malts , espresso , and some bitterness . t : main flavor is chocolate here , big boozyness comes with the taste .  pours very thick dark brown/block with chocolate brown head .  buttery , syrupy mouthfeel , like butterscotch and cream . this one is truly a treat ; it has seemed to age really , really well , with a wonderful balance of flavors and a vinous profile that is not overpowering or overwhelming .

my favorite part is the smell , the head on this beer is amazing . definitely not as smooth as the nocturnum , i would say it deserves just as much appreciation .  this stout pours with a balck body topped by a thick tan head with lots of lacing .  fuller body , decent carbonation , sticky , silky smooth , and creamy on the tongue . i 've heard some people say this needs some time , but this is fantastic right now .

appearance : a dark copper color , with little head smell : sweet , apples , smells so good , like a sweet apple cider . wow , this is great . very sweet and tart at the same time .  even a day after it was tapped , this nitro pour esb collaboration between sierra & the three penny bros. was exceptional . this was the last keg left of this brew , and it lacked any discernible aromas .  m : damn near perfect . smooth , silky , easy .

aroma is thick , heavy , and reminds me of grandmas kitchen on thanksgiving ( although , we always had thanksgiving at my parents ... odd ) ; caramel , cookie dough , sweet cinnamon and vanilla , and pumpkin of course . this one smells like a freshly baked pumpkin pie and i feel like i can put whip cream on the top of this one . delicious beer to share , since it is a heavy one .  pours with a medium thick creamy head atop a deep amber brown/mohagony body . a nice amount of lace is left behind .  body is quite full with a nice creamy texture , no apparent alcohol and good carbonation . very good overall and easily drinkable which makes this one the best in this series .

s : astoundingly complex . bourbon , oak , lots of vanilla , chocolate , caramelized sugar , raisin , apple cinnamon and coconut . wow . t : the roasted sugar and chocolate appears first closely followed by vanilla and oak .  a solid ipa in a can ? beautiful , brilliantly clear coppery orange beer with a thick cap of ivory bubbles that lasts throughout the whole drink . wonderful sticky lacing .  m : thick and chewy d : the massive flavors make this one a sipper , but unfortunately , due to the liqour like alcohol burn , this one is n't very drinkable ... .yet.. as the one i had is already aged 1 year , i 'm guessing this thing needs a good 3-5 years to really smooth out .

do i dare put my nose near this thing ? as i put my nose near the glass , i hear a monumental explosion . suddenly , chunks of bubble gum , lemon drops , pears and peppers come spewing out . very good beer though .  this tastes much better from the bottle though , which is where this review comes in ... a - pitch black , like motor oil or even paint . the head looks like chocolate milk and there is a great amount of lacing , head .  once she warmed a little , i got an amazing mouthfeel of chocolate milky smoothness . very creamy , with some hop sweetness with a touch of vanilla .

aroma is very appetizing and very belgian , with big bubble gum and spicy pepper . peppery and a bit hot going down , this one is exciting and still very drinkable . feel is fine , though not quite as dry and spritzy as i expected . i enjoyed this a lot , although i would not drink more than one in a night as the hotness would most likely bring on a headache .  appearance : a monster three finger ivory head that is creamy and foamy .  the feel is super tannic and sticks to your mouth .

smell is quite interesting . lemon , citrus , wet cardboard , touch of white grapes , floral notes of lillys and lavender .  pours a pitch black with a large tan head that maintains great retention , and some of the best lacing i have seen on a beer .  m/d : a medium to full body that is velvety smooth . very rich and creamy .

s : loads of citrus here . smells amazing , especially for such a low abv beer .  500ml brown bottle poured into a hobgoblin pint pot a . deep copper with a soft white foamy head .  this beer feels thicker than it is .

as it warms i can pick out a trace of vanilla . superb . the flavor is bit more subdued than i had hoped .  can poured into a snifter appearance - reddish/copper color with huge , foamy tan head that lingers smell - this is kind of faint , but what i am picking up is caramel , molasses taste - flavors are a bit muted , but picking up a little bit of caramel , molasses , cherry mouthfeel - watery and thin compared to other entrants of this style that i 've sampled , creamy and smooth , well carbonated .  mouthfeel : medium to bodied with an air of hops , alcohol and what i can only assume is the effect of the oak cask all mix with the hoppy bitterness to create an amazing mouthfeel .

this is probably one of the best smelling beers i 've ever had , it 's almost like smelling a nice perfume . most frustratingly for me , the orange peel aftertaste actually settles in the back of the throat like a bad cough medicine and is quite unpleasant .  poured black with a brown head .  yet this red ale has an absolutely amazing full , creamy mouthfeel , wholly unexpected for this style , which leaves me duly impressed , it is a textural pleasure to drink this ale , a damn palatal masterpiece , worth the price alone .

smells amazing . t : you guessed it , hazelnut .  a : a vigorous pour straight down the middle produces a sky-high off-white head that perfectly fills the oversized tulip glass . as the rocky 3 '' head slowly recedes it leaves tons of lace . in summation , gorgeous - far better looking that i ever expected .  mouthfeel : creamy and round and full like no other , like a caress of silk towards the palate . the carbonation is , as expected , low but it should n't be in any other way considering the smoooth outcome !

amazing . great aroma .  made the great mistake of buying the growler . as i poured it i noticed it blocks out light better than an eclipse . dark and rich are an understatement .  thick smooth mouthfeel and mildly carbonated . the creamy smoothness is more apparent and delightful now .

light creamy head poured big , thick and meringue like then faded very slowly to good thick layer ... lots of good sticky lacing ... aroma - loads of spicy belgian yeastiness , rich creamy and spicy fruits ( oranges , apricots , overripe bananas , pears ) , some medicinal notes , quite strong aniseed notes , honey / candy sugar sweetness , candied peel , some grassiness , floral notes , butterscotch traces , very light malts , some sulphur traces ... taste not quite up to the standard of the aromas ... . spicy fruits ( bitter oranges , apples , pears ) , light biscuity malts , nice peppery hop bitterness , light candy sugar / honey sweetness , faint anise notes , some saltiness , quite floral and perfumed ... feel - pretty smooth and creamy with a little bite ... medium bodied ... very drinkable although at 7.5 % it might catch up with you pretty quickly.. overall - an excellent belgian pale ale although the huge chunks of yeast might be a bit off putting ... .  appearance : this beer looks perfect . beautiful copper color , nice 1 '' of medium thickness , off white head with above average retention .  mouthfeel : wonderful . feels like champagne and the sourness makes my mouth water .

this is one of the best smelling ipas this mans nose has come across . the taste of this aipa was awesome !  a really beautiful looking beer , fantastic head and lacing .  mouthfeel was silky with a nice interaction of hops and malt on the tongue . finish was super smooth , going down like a champ .

heavy malt sweetness , very fruity and deep . taste was big , no , make that huge on malt sweetness , thick and heavy with a very big mouthfeel .  pours a deep , rich , opaque sable , nearly black , with a thick , dark tan head that dissipates slowly .  m - incredible . the creamiest beer i have ever had .

still an outstanding beer with an unbelievable aroma .  no head momentarily , but bubbling up to a solid finger with ample lacing . i cant imagine a red looking any better .  mouthfeel is spot on . thick and syrupy with just enough carbonation .

aroma- smells like a cross between a vintage old ale and a porter ... the leather , mildew , and century-old hardbound book elements blend together in glorious fashion with tootsie roll chocolate , dark fudge , and dark fruit . no coffee in the aroma , surprisingly ... but that 's fine with me . mature and stately , it 's grown up ... a beverage with time and sophistication under its belt . the flavors , difficult to decipher individually because of the superb integration , are so cohesive that i marvel at its balance . figs and plums dance in a molasses-soaked liquor of divinity .  appearance : pours a pleasant clear amber color , with 2 fingers of foamy head in my darkness tulip . as the head begins to recede , sticky lacing clings to the edge of the glass .  feels lovely in the mouth .

a great , rich coffee smell that has hints of cream .  a : very dark and very nice to look at 2 finger light brown head that goes down to a nice sheen and pretty collar . the lacing is almost solid up and down the glass very nice to look at .  m : so creamy and thick .

smell : absolutely outstanding . boasting hints of everything from pine to fruit to tropical esters.. this beer had it all .  poured into an imperial pint glass , formed a 1 1/2 '' beige head over the clear amber brew . head lasts very well , with delicate yet plentiful lacing .  felt smooth and creamy in the mouth .

i thought it would be overly sweet , but it was very tastefully done . very tasteful . i loved the smell and the taste . big fan .  pours a deep mahogany , clear ruby when held to the light . big , creamy off-white head .  mouthfeel is creamy smooth and full bodied .

the aromas are are yeasty with papaya and rich decay notes .  poured from the bomber into a tulip glass the beer was a dark mohogany brown color with three huge fingers of thick tan head . some carbonation rushed to the surface to feed the head and lacing was ample throughout the sample . very nice in the glass .  velvety-smooth texture with full body . the hops stand out at this young age .

overall , a lovely aroma . very sharp taste to start that gets more complex towards to middle .  purchased as a single from wine and beer westpark in glen allen , va - pint shared with a friend - quite tasty pours a very very dark black with dark brown head , everything i look for in a stout .  a really creamy smooth mouthfeel that feels almost cask like .

very roasty , with hints of oatmeal , vanilla , caramel , chocolate and butter . overall impression : delivers an intense yet superior look and smell with a less-impressive yet solid flavor , finish and feel .  it is a bright , sparkling gold with a medium , long-lasting , creamy white head that leaves beautiful , even lace .  mouthfeel the mouthfeel on-cask is unbelievable . it is so smooth and pleasantly foamy it literally makes your mouth water .

huge fragrant floral bouquet with strong citrus notes . very perfumey ... pomegranate , honeysuckle , absolutely incredible . like the aroma , tremendously perfumey ... perhaps too perfumey , in fact . ... perhaps a bit less perfume in the taste ... but oh well ... a fantastic beer nonetheless .  from a bottle , pours crimson red , bright and glowing when held to the light , with a big , pink , cotton candy head that actually has little specks of blackberry seeds or something on top . could not be more attractive to look at .  mouthfeel : incredibly mellow and smooth . a perfect feeling beer , truly .

s - great hoppy aroma . this is one of the the most well rounded hop aromas i 've encountered in quite a while . there is more earthy and pine notes in the flavor than in the aroma and although there is nothing at all wrong with the flavor something unquantifiable just does n't impress as much as the appearance and aroma . m - light , dry and refreshingly crisp .  bottle into a standard pint glass burnt-orange in color , with a huge cloud deck of rocky , creamy foam . nice looking beer .  m- big , creamy , great carbonation , spot-on .

what a wonderful aroma ! taste : grapefruits .  superb clarity , an exceptionally clean looking saison .  superb mouth feel , a full sensory experience . the after taste is delicious , tongue coating , coffee , full bodied .

lacing retention is ok. s - delicious pineapple , papaya and mango . pretty nice carbonation . the smell is just great but it lacks in the taste .  this beer poured a large creamy off-white head with small-medium sized bubbles that was long lasting . the body was clear with a lot of carbonation observed and the hue was orange .  mouthfeel fantastic . one bottle went to the head .

sweet aroma with some passion fruit , spicy pepper , flower ( rose ) petals , and other goodies . a real clean and crisp aroma . it makes me want to jam my nose right down and in ... and take a huge whiff . spicy alcohol warming and a really good yeasty floral bite make this one a winner .  appearance- i know a beer should have onyl a two finger head , but with this particular beer , i enjoyed gazing at the five finger head as it almost overflowed the big weizen glass . had the most uniform looking lacing i 've ever seen .  m - mouthfeel is perfect . silky smooth bubbles and full bodied texture .

smells like fresh gingerbread cookies hit with a little of cinnamon and nutmeg .  you can see the bubbles floating up the glass . the lacing is outstanding , and sticks all over the glass , showing each sip . this is a great looking beer .  on the palate it is very supple and silky , with beautiful integration of aggressive ruby red grapefruit flesh flavors with dry impressions of honey . it is cascading , dry and very grapefruit-infused tonic ( a quality i usually despise in beer ) . a beautiful sequence of spice , honey and grapefruit in a very dry , mouthmelting texture package .

aroma ? spicy . citrus zest , coriander , soccer-mom-fresh orange wedges , grains of paradise . earthy , too , with a hint of funk and herbal hops . i could smell this one all day long ... the flavor is as rich as the aroma suggested . seven is inviting , but deceptively simple in its profile , with orange peel and grapefruit leading the way . vegetal & musty mid-palate with traces of white pepper . bottom line : delicious . i would gladly have this one again .  9.4 oz bottle into a flute glass . pours a gorgeous , burnt copper hue with hints of orange and deep pink around the edges . amazing depth to the color of this brew . lots of carbonation seeping up from below makes for a well retained cap of foam .  exceptionally smooth mouthfeel , a buttery diacetyl eases it along .

wonderfully spicy aroma with a blast of cinnamon , clove , ginger , brown sugar and nutmeg . the abv is extremely well masked without even a slight touch of alcohol heat making it extremely quaffable .  bottled sept 30 2010.. enjoying feb 13 2011 ... a - this beer has a beautiful way of making the bubbles fill the glass . very pretty amber color .  m : i love how smooth this beer feels in my mouth .

wonderful smell . nice and strong .  a : pours an opaque , burnt-orange with an impossibly creamy and pillowy dark khaki colored head on top . retention is fantastic ! gobs of sticky lace were left clinging for dear life to the inside of the glass .  creamy , a textural marvel really ... .likely the creamiest and most velvety beer i 've had .

sweet and creamy milk chocolate malted shake with cinnamon , vanilla , and essences of coffee . amazing smell that i cant get enough of ! has an interesting french vanilla creamer aroma to it . ( t ) - ample roasted malts that are lightly bittering that is followed by dusty cocoa and sweet creamy vanilla on the finish . ( d ) - a unique stout with the addition of being brewed with vanilla beans .  pours exceptionally well . there is about three fingers of clumpy light tan foam , along with a clear dark copper colored body .  mouthfeel- silky smooth , even though it was more tart than i usually liked in my beer .

i think citra is the best smelling hop in the world , so its easy to understand why i think this beer smells great . the flavor is a bit more subdued than the nose , with a nice blend of fresh hop flavors , some piney bitter backbone and a touch of sweet malt creeping through the hop assault .  looked amazing , even as i drank there was lots of bubbles s : hops , bitterness , floral and some citrus t : my first sip was chocolate malts followed by floral hops and bitterness .  mouthfeel is full and creamy with a sharp smooth . very crisp with a dry finish . excellent beer .

nose has a marvelous hop floral spiciness with a sweet and somewhat earthy malt aroma , lime like in its crispness , fresh and so inviting it just makes your mouth water in anticipation , start is sweet and delightfully malted with the top middling in its feel to the palate .  it pours from the can nicely into a guinness pint glass with about 2 fingers of thick beige head which accumulates as the cascade falls . the head creates a nice lacing as it recedes into the glass .  the incredible thing here is the smoothness -- this beer goes down so easily , and the flavor is so well-integrated . medium-light carbonation massages the tongue amidst a creamy medium body . it 's very lightly fizzy . absolutely incredible drinkability .

impressive and pretty . s : huge , towering , and scarily impressive . dry ( an oakiness ? ) , with giant alcoholic fruits , coffee , and distinctive grape . indescribable . i really like this beer .  pours a hazy golden color with an absolute beast of an off-white head ... .rocky , dense , and long-lasting , foamy lacing clings to the glass .  the mouthfeel is beyond silky it is down right syrupy !

hmmm mmmm mmmm . the smell is my favorite part of this brew .  pours a deep ruby red color with a large pink head that fades to a lasting ring of pink foam .  just enough carbonation to balance the syrupy nature of the beer .

tons of soapy lace left behind . the aroma is full on brett boquet . lots of dry dusty wood and wet straw . overall hands down the most complex saison i 've ever sampled .  appearance is dark amber , a small head , and with moderate carbonation . looks excellent .  where this beer really excels is in the mouthfeel , which is everything you can hope for from a cask . its smooth and full , with a wonderfully deep texture that shows baird know how to make a great cask .

the pale , hazy complexion , the clean malt and cascades hop flavors and aromas and the tangy finish is always welcome . a very well-crafted brew .  it creates a rich deep tan head that rings the glass in lace .  smooth and hoppy with that cask-pureed-banana mouthfeel .

one of the more interesting and odd smelling beers that i 've come across that actually excited me .  | 9.5 % abv | 2011 brewer : great divide brewing company style : imperial stout glass : crystal mug appearance : a billowing mocha head of foam and turbulent ebony body below makes this one hell of a good looking beer .  wow.. good powerful stuff . super smooth in the mouth , and almost creamy in feel .

s - absolutely amazing . bourbon , vanilla , tart cherries , port wine , toffee , cinnamon , and nutmeg . one of the best beers i have ever smelled . just perfect . t - oh my goodness .  very dark pour , totally opaque . huge head and good lacing .  very silky smooth , awesome all around .

the nose is absolutely fantastic , i do n't think i could ask for anything more . rich milk chocolate , fresh brewed coffee , and smooth bourbon each jump out of the glass , no aroma dominating , but all of them quite pungent .  it poured a jet balck with a cascading head that faded beautifully into a lacy quality .  m- very smooth with an easy carbonation on the medium to full body .

the smell is pretty unreal . huge orange notes , complemented by some lemon , some pine , and some tropicals . very good ipa .  a : pours a crystal clear dark gold showing very vigorous carbonation . lacing is beautiful . one of the prettiest tripels i 've seen . it is a gorgeous beer in the glass .  i do n't normally give 5s in a category , but old viscosity and ten fidy will always get an exceptional rating for mouthfeel .

smell- glorious cherry cordial nose , slight hint of chocolate chips .  on tap at the brickstore pub in decatur , ga ... i made the trip out just to try this one ... i had this a couple of weeks ago ... just getting around to entering it in ... pitch black body with a dark chocolate head . beautiful lacing .  here is where the beer shines , on the palate it is pure velvet . the texture is lush and liquor like without any heavy alcohol notes . really fine finish that comes off with some hints of bitter tannins .

flavor is not quite as good as the aroma , but it is still pleasing - smoky and oily with tones of coffee and molasses .  same label as the picture , glueing technique seems to have improved as the label is flush flat on the bottle sans bubbles or tears . time shrinks the head.. but leaves strong cavernous lacing and at no time does the surface of the beer become exposed- a dark khaki cream top stays with the beer until the last sip .  medium to low carbonation . really smooth for 10 % abv .

last st. bernardus brew out of my christmas stash from my wonderful girlfriend , actually last beer out of the stash period..besides my case of snca resting in my cellar just waiting to me drank : - ) looked wonderful in my glass , rich burgundy in color with a full two fingers of head , that gave way after a few minutes but stuck around long enough to release wonderful aromas of banana , apricot , and apple skins , along with a wonderful fresh baked bread scent .  poured the palest of pale yellows ... almost white ... whiter than any wit i 've seen . head was a very impressive 3 fingers of snow white that seemed to never melt .  perfect . o : while this was a tasty beer , i have such high regard for the brewery that anything that does n't blow me away really disappoints me .

smell is exceptional - banana and cloves are the predominant forces , accompanied by other spices and maybe some pear . one of the best aromas i have found in a beer .  in the orval glass it fades from golden on the bottom up to orange and it 's just beautiful . the head on this thing is massive and it requires a very slow pour . carbonation is drifting up like mad . excellent head retention as well .  mouthfeel is very comforting - like a fall evening in a cabin in the woods . incredible . this has a little bit of everything ... a collaboration of brewers yields a collaboration of ingredients in an exercise of beautiful chemistry .

really incredible aroma . wow , where to begin .  a : slightly murky amber with big-bubbled white 2-finger head even with a slow pour with good foamy retention and a coating of lace down the glass . exquisite .  mouthfeel is rich and creamy and with huge grapefruit flavors , followed by pine and then resin . beautifully balanced .

it had a nice appearance and an awesome apple phenol smell . the taste is very nice and has a nice caramel malt profile .  poured into a snifter , revealing fluid black body with a tall and thick beige head . very pretty .  m & gt ; lovely . perfect .

the nose is a beautiful cherry , peach , pear mixture , absolutely incredible . i only hope it can taste this good ... the taste has a lot of lemon taste , but the others mentioned previously do make a short , subtle appearance .  poured from its 16.9oz bottle into my snifter a crisp clean amber color with an incredibly thick off-white head that had tons of bubbles in it and held together very well .  carbonation is extremely pleasant and elegant on the tongue .

leaves a weak lacing . aroma : holy wow . light , spritzy hops . tangerines . pineapples . wondrous in its fruity expansiveness ... most of which im sure comes from hops , but lacks any astringent botanical character . expertly balanced.. like the 5-course bubblegum in the willy wonka movie . overall : really , one of my favorite new discoveries of summer 2005. shame i didnt have the chance to get more of this ( hard to find locally ) .  pours a cloudy , dark brown on top that fades to a dark copper . great retention and great lacing .  mouthfeel is big , heavy , chewy , and viscous . very nice .

s : a very funky nose nose to this with a lot of the must and sweaty sock type of smells you get out of drie fonteinen beers . as with the aroma , a mild oak note , but overall , the flavor is not quite as good as aroma . m : the body is medium with medium to high carbonation . o : this is a really nice gueuze .  the brew poured into a pint looks spectacular . it 's plum red with huge , thick , frothy light tan colored head standing almost three inches tall .  great balance , just a little lacking in potency still . the palate is great in balance and freshness .

i thought the mbcp nose was incredible but the no crust is down right insane . kudos to kevin , ryan , and the rest of the buddha crew ... .  served in an 8oz tulip glass . poured a deep , dark black . big tan fluffy head that dissipates surprisingly quickly to a thin tan layer ! very nice lacing down the entire glass .  mouthfeel : lighter then most riss . less oily and thick . really nicely balanced bitterness and fruitiness .

the nose is amazingly distinct and cedar-like , but there are other spice aromas in there as well including some nutmeg , a pinch of black pepper , a brush of cinnamon , a sprig of pine , and a spritz of citrusy fruit juice . i prefer the cedar in the nose ... . but i guess the two go hand in hand .  appearance - jet black with a two finger cream colored head .  mouthfeel - very smooth , pretty darn heavy too .

complex and beautiful aroma . dark roasted malts and ( what a surprise ) elderberries . amazing . no trace of the big alcohol .  beautiful , cherry-brown color , similar to a rich hardwood with an incredibly persistent off-white head .  the mouthfeel is excellent and about as creamy as i 've ever had in a porter .

s : the nose is very complex . lots of smoke , peat , toffee , and chocolate . really impressive . this is really nice .  a : pours an oily , tar-like impenetrable black with 1 finger of chestnut brown , fine-laced head that dissipates slowly . this is one beautiful looking beer !  mouthfeel of pure velvet and again , this radical brew is reminiscent of amantillado .

nose : incredibly aromatic and complex . this beer could be used as an example of the potential in the depth of beer scents . mouth : most prominently smoky and bitter , the fruity entrance of this beer does not meet the expectations set by the complex aroma . also , i would prefer that the beer maintained a more strongly carbonated mouth-feel , but i think that the size of the head ( which remained consistent to the very last glass of the bottle ) uses up a fair amount of the bubbles . the oakiness , while very interesting and enjoyable , seems to be so bitter as to cover up the much needed malty sweetness .  exceptionally pale cloudy yellow colored beer with a billowy snow-white head . an extremely powerful head forming beer it almost over flowed the top of the glass . looks exactly like .  the mouthfeel is incredibly smooth and the finish is clean .

big wafts of fresh raspberry and not much else , but it smells fresh , fruity and interesting . wonderful on the nose .  serving type : 12 oz bottle poured into 16 oz nonic pint glass a - creamy beige head , opaque black , only a slight hint of red hues when held under bright light s - very chocolately smell , though not entirely strong , with a bit of alcohol scent shining through t - bitter taste all over , roasted malts are , as expected , the dominant force , and as a note , the bitterness tends to linger around throughout m - good tingle from carbonation , with a thick creamy body in other words , pretty much everything i was expecting it would be .  leaves your lips a little sticky . this beer is the perfect belgian tripel .

juicy , tangerine laced citrusy centennial hop nose upfront , followed by smooth medium lovibond caramel malt and subtle toasty malt .  a- the head on this beer stood a full two inches over the rim of my pint glass , wow ! beautiful rocky , frothy tan head with some really extensive lacing that travels the whole length of the glass .  s : coffee , chocolate t : roasted coffee , toffee , chocolate m : wonderful , full mouth feel , but not a heavy beer d : why not drink a beer that tastes like a meal , but is n't heavy on calories ?

4.5 s : wonderful ! all the best aspects of a brown are here - plenty of nuts , toasty , caramel , toffee , and brown sugar . then the maple syrup kicks in making this unique and the pecans kicks the nuttiness into overdrive . very well done . 4.0 t : the taste is sweeter than the nose suggests .  poured into a rapscallion glass , formed a 1 1/2 '' brown head above the opaque dark brown brew . dense , frothy head just is not going anywhere , with tons of thick foam left in the wake .  great body and smoooth . highly drinkable .

thick dots of lacing cling to the side s - outstanding aroma ! d - this is a good beer . it 's flavor is n't as great as the smell , but still ... it is nice . i would n't mind having this again .  illumination pours with a vibrant , glowing orange body with just the right amount of yeast haze that allows one to see the streams of carbonation in the middle of the glass , but not entirely through to the other side . the custard head is tall , creamy , and slow to recede -- good lacing to boot . vibrant applies to the aroma , too , perhaps a bit of a surprise since this is a & gt ; 4 month old iipa .  viscous , perfect . rough .

damn it smells good . it combines two great food types into one : smoked meat and beer !  fred pours smooth , retains head for hours , and is amber and hazy in appearance . definately can see bubbles from ample carbonation .  the mouthfeel is exceptional . the oatmeal really gives this beer a great body .

overall a solid , and particularly great smelling , ipa .  bottle ( 2011 ) k & b wine cellars san diego , ca a dark as night pour but with some dark ruby edges along the edge . big and thick , persistent , chocolate milk head . leaves the glass supremely messy .  spot on creaminess .

i love it ; tons of hops ; that great hop smell you get from fresh hops when you homebrew taste : awesome ; very hoppy : ) ; not very balanced ; maybe a hint of citrus mouthfeel : medium to full bodied drinkability : its a little thick , so two in a row might be tricky , plus the hops assault your tongue ; great to have one to start off the night like i 'm doing right now though overall , a quality beer .  brown , creamy caramelle looking 2 to 3 finger head and leaves a wonderful lacing on the glass . color is almost fully black ( like coca-cola ) .  mouthfeel is great , thick and syrupy .

the smell is exceptional with a hoppy centennial ? aroma that just hits the nose perfectly . the taste is rich espresso like coffee tones with hoppy undertones that balance the malts beautifully .  a-pours a pale , golden copper with a white , one-finger head s-toasty , and really pronounced caramel malt with an understated spicy hop characteristic .  mouthfeel is full and round .

scents of some kind of a peachy , grapefruit hit the nose . extremely refreshing . super beer for year round consumption .  pours a clear deep ruby bodied beer with little to no head .  mouthfeel - absolutely exquisite . very silky and velvety . exceptional .

immediately recalls the feeling of sniffing fresh creme brulee . aromatics suggest some sort of strange starbucks concocction with caramel , exotic flavored coffee , and french vanilla . smooth in the nose like smelling a fresh crepe before it 's filled . strikes me as a bit `` engineered '' -- but good . one of the most unique and impressively creative beers i 've ever tried .  poured into a perfect pint . pours a pale gold with a thin white head , leaving no lace .  this beer feels exactly like it appears pretty damn close to a stout shake !

smells of world class cherries a not much else .  poured into a pilsner glass cold hop has a pretty , subdued gold with a decent whitish head that dissipates quickly , lacing the glass for the duration of the drink .  a beer i have been looking forward to trying since it came out , poured into an impy pint glass a deep mahogany brown with a slight chill haze to it a pillowy one finger almond colored head atop with good retention.complexity the word to describe not only the nose but flavors of this beer , at first i picked up juicy fruity malt aromas like orange with brown sugar sweetness the hops are subdued but do provide some floral character.i would say malt tilted but hops are there on the palate the whiskey barrel aging shows itself with some real vanilla/oak sweetness along with a chocolate covered nut quality the rye is actually somewhat irrelevent just a very slight lactic-like bite.the complexity of this beer gives high marks sure iam a hophead and was expecting maybe more of a hop profile but its a damn good beer , the creamy mouthfeel is to die for.a `` nice '' beer here it is well crafted .

exceptional . t : huge scotch flavour , without the burn .  yes the head quickly disappears but leaving more room for topping off your pint .  sensual body slides against the tongue , with the perfect amount of carbonation satisfying any beer-drinker 's palate .

d : this had an amazing scent , with very nice taste and body . very enjoyable brew .  nice colour with a very light head , no lace .  overall , pretty damn good , beautiful mouthfeel and fairly drinkable .

smell : dipa hoppy , but distinctly different . spicy , minty , floral , a bit of orange juice a-la bspa and a bit buttery . amazingly , a malty caramel sweetness comes through loud and clear .  fairly light straw color and pretty clear as well..slight haze . big white head that went away fairly quickly .  it 's definitely mellowed a bit , but still has a nice hop edge , and is wonderfully warm and spicy.the aroma is mostly of slightly toasted malts..the mouth feel is big and smooth .

taste is also dominated by loads of peat smoke malt which are very tasty . i never had an imperial stout with so much smoke notes before .  a - dark , dark cloudy red/brown . head is unspectacular .  while the flavour did n't do much for me , the mouthfeel is simply awesome . soft and pillowy , its all you could hope for in a beer , and works well with everything else going on here .

appearance : great roasted coffee smell with a very faint sweetness ... perhaps chocolate . bits of chocolate , vanilla , and coffee round out a wonderful smell . taste : tons of roasted coffee like the smell .  cool artwork , but he does seem to have some varicose vein issues going on with his legs ... a - opaque dark brown body with a tiny cap of beige head . i 'm a little disappointed by the lack of head on this beast ... especially since i expected at least two heads from what the label depicted .  the spices sit on the tongue and create a festive atmosphere in the mouth .

the smell is one of the best i 've smelled on a beer . it is a cherry and cinnamon combination that is well balanced and clean .  pours black from the can with a very short tan head and a very light coating of lace .  this amazing and smooth stout is aged in a burbon barrel for a year . it is amazingly smooth , warming you up instantly .

s- this aroma is really nice . it hits you right off the bat with a wall of tropical fruits .  looks much like a labatt blue , but this is where the similarities end ... smell is above average , with a huge hops presence and some wheat .  this is the best mouthfeel i have experienced in a brew in a very long time .

quite a big scent , quite complex , and excellent . t : a great tartness blend of cherry and green apple . a beautiful wood subtleness in there - not quite as complex as the scent suggests , but nice nonetheless .  develops very little head , with a slight collar and light laciness .  perfect for the style .

s - very pleasing sweet fruit aromas , with hints of implied sour and bitterness . the smell alone is addictive , so with the overall pleasing taste this a very drinkable beer .  it pours a golden hue and cloudy ( unfiltered ? ) . decent lacing .  m : light-bodied , crisp and clean . very easy to drink . seamless .

nose is a brilliant actualization between twangy , high-alpha acid hops and earthy , woody old-world hops and a great 'english bitter on steroids ' malt bill . has a bit of a twangy , herbal or chlorrophyl thing going on that detracts a bit from the overall package . very good ... and man do these guys have some balls putting this directly up against some of the world 's finest draft beers .  pours dark brown with a small tan head which turned to film rather quickly .  bottle into pint glass a massive cream colored loose head forces a short pour , moderate recession speed leaves scattered patchy lacing to a thin pillowy layer , brew is a hazy brown amber 4 s grassy , florals , milder citrus biscuit apricot & caramel notes 3.5 t lots of flavor , bitter hop edge up front , a caramel malt spine takes a back seat and lets the hops shine in a quality way , lots of complexity and a unique balance in an american ipa 4 m excellent mouth feel , medium body is very rounded and carbonation is great as well , soft & smooth drinking , abv is transparent 5 o a very good ipa , try it . rare for me in the hop levels where i still consider the malts as adding so substantially to my enjoyment , very good balance with a great mouth feel and good drinkability 4.5

it smells very good . the hops are not overpowering but there .  average retention and lightly spotty lacing . pretty average .  first i notice the taste of bananas , pears , and pineapple followed by a spices and hops at the end m : perfect carbonation , very full beer d : tastes best as it warms and goes down relatively easy

superb aromatic quality ... i get candied fruit , biscuits , and caramel .  pours surprisingly fizzy , comes out very sparkling from the bottle , like a vaseline model 's teeth . champagne-coloured with a pleasant dusty haze through it , minimal but steady bead , but the notable exception here is the head . none .  m : medium body . the mouthfeel in particular is excellent for the style , and this is surprisingly polished . who knows if this is what it actually tasted like in the 60s - this is a very good american lager right now .

s - smells of super bright hops and grapefruit , just awesome . t - bitter orange peeling and hops , with maybe some pear juice .  purchased from the centralia safeway because dick 's has dumb hours ... decent head , not much lacing at all ... smell is nice chocolate malts , hops are faint but present ... taste is smooth , medium bodied , again all chocolate with a nice sweet tasting hop finish that sticks to the tastebuds for a while ... very drinkable , this would kick ass if it were cask-conditioned ... cheers !  mouthfeel makes the beer great . chewy and soft and oh so smooth . brewed with oatmeal ? must be to get this mouthfeel .

smells nice and citrus fruity .  poured with a nice off-white head and some lace . color is a medium hazy amber .  very smooth and it represents itself very well ine mouth . delicate but throughout . nice .

thanks again to thorpe ... looks like the other fears , black with an ok head ... a really awesome aroma of peat , smoke , and pork , balanced and just awesome . a hint of red wine is great ... the taste does n't translate as well , the front is tons of fresh oak ( a little too harsh for me ) , oak kills a lot of the smoke and pork , which is my favorite part . still good just a disappointment of what i was expecting ... this is very good , my 2nd favorite .  a- hazy golden color body with a decent , lingering white head .  slightly oil mouth feel ( the hop oils ) but with a great crystal like cleanness that just blows me away . exceptional .

s - awesome , ohh yes . doughy , mildly grainy nose , full of true pumpkin gourd aroma as well as cinnamon and loads of nutmeg and molasses .  pours exactly like hoegaarden , only less turbid . carbonation is very low , hence the 3.0 score .  mouthfeel : fantastic , you know you 've got a meal in your glass !

an abundance of floral hops hits the nose hard . two hearted is one of the best smelling beers in all the land .  a -dark honey , initial head leaves quick , lacing almost non existent .  m this beer has an almost pillowy thick mouth feel . just the right amount of alcohol and carbonation .

s. lots of bourbon , vanilla , and cocoa t. bourbon , brown sugar , vanilla , but not as much spice a the other variants . m. thick body with a bit of booziness d. very drinkable . my favorite smell so far of the barrel aged ones , but i love bourbon .  sampled on 6-24-08 best before end 2009 pours a cool orange/brown color with a bunch of chunky floaters .  great mouthfeel . thick , luscious , decadent , and somewhat chewy . very nice .

slight bourbon , molasses , brown sugar , berry compote , fantastic !  a : a frothy , medium brown head of 1 finger goes quickly . the body is completely black and nothing can be seen through the other side of the glass . as the drinking continues , half sheets of lace are stuck behind . not bad , but a very standard appearance .  m - a nice full body complements the hop kick on this brew d - very smooth despite the noticeable alcohol .

nose gives of banana and clove phenols , leaning towards dense , almost meaty banana bread with bready malt sweetness very present . exceptional smells that i could n't get enough of .  poured a straw with a one finger foamy head . there was decent retention and lacing .  i love the full mouthfeel on the speedway stout .

n : immaculate floral bouquet of pineapple and grapefruit -- very impressive and powerful ! t/m : perfect creamy body and light mouth-feel .  a-pours very dark brown , nearly black . there was no head to speak of .  m : incredibly smooth and creamy .

sumptuous and enticing nose , gregarious with compelling tales of prune and oak , rum and evergreen , and stories still earthier : coffee , olive , tobacco , leather . a lovely thing , smelling this makes my whole head perk up .  22oz bottle a : decent lacing a very cloudy amber/copper color with lots of sediment floating around .  mouthfeel is great . like many good ipas , it has that coating feel that stays in your mouth , without the sharp bitterness that some ipas leave , and its flavor lingers a very long time .

it 's pretty good and better than i anticipated . overall this is a very solid beer and was pretty damn good fresh .  have n't seen this one at the bars yet , but i got this one in a bottle . the head started out fairly big and fluffy , but died out very quickly , to little laceing . overall it was a very drinkable beer .  m : feels wonderfully smooth in the mouth .

superb . taste : it had a nice tang to it , more raspberries than blackberries , some rust .  pours out to a murky dark golden with copper accents , forming a modest white head with average poor retention and sparse lacing .  streaming carbonation . still gorgeous as the light syrup , full body fills the mouth and the carbonation leaves the palate clean . this 500ml of a delicious , meaty , full , german beer is about as satisfying as i 've encountered .

s : absolutely astounding cocoa smell . that 's amazing . the best cocoa smell i 've had in a beer to date . that is absolutely excellent . tiny dry espresso finish . o : this is hands down the best `` chocolate beer '' i 've ever had . absolutely amazing . would recommend to anyone .  silicon valley ba crew is the best beer crew ~~ r1d3 2gether di3 2gether , ba br0z 4 lyf3 . a : nice golden color . my pour came from towards the end of the bottle , so the yeasties clouded it up ( and there were some funky orange chunks of them floating in the beer ) but i could see from other pours that the beer was actually supposed to be pretty clear . unfortunately ill probably never see another bottle . overall , i think this beer sold me on the idea that there is more behind yellow bus than just hype -- c'mon tomme , just brew another batch and give the beer a proper release .  lively mouthfeel that dances the labamba on your tongue .

smell : ok , i think i 've nailed it : fresh cut lumber . yes , this beer smells like sawdust , home depot , and all the good memories you have from your days with a circular saw .  the appearance again is average , but that shouldnt scare you off .  the mouthfeel on this is fantastic ; full , smooth , and perfectly carbonated ( i.e . not too much ) .

aroma is fantastic , showcasing tropical rays of amarillo sunshine . think mango juice or even tropical bubble yum . bitterness is n't really that harsh at all , and pretty approachable . for an 8 % dipa , it drinks incredibly smooth , and is refreshing .  a-no light coming through at all , its black as night . there was n't much head at all , just a thin off white layer that dropped quickly .  top notch as far as mouthfeel goes .

i loved the smell . the taste was molasses , alcohol and dark fruit ( prunes mostly ) .  color is a dark orange amber . slight tan head that was very thin with no lace .  it 's very flavorful and has a perfect mouthfeel going on .

nose is downright spectacular - full of tropical fruits ( pineapple , mango , tangerine ) , citrus fruits ( grapefruit , orange , lemon ) , floral hops , and a hint of pine resin , all backed by the most delicate of malt bases ... pure artistry . coming from such a glorious nose , the taste is a bit of a let-down though in no way is it faulty . nothing over the top but it seems like there could be a bit more of everything and still be balanced - i 'm thinking that what the tap version would taste like - fresh , balanced , big . the tap version of this ( or pliny the younger ) might be my perfect ipa .  this beer has a caramel hued amber color to it almost identical to more mass produced ambers and a violent pour will not produce much more than a 1 & 1/2 finger head .  taste : mouth feel is perfectly constructed to be both elusive and comfortable .

the menu says that this beer is `` brewed with 500 pounds of fresh watermelon .
