s : fruity smell with aromas of lemon zest . t : a detect very little flavor , mostly just intense bitterness and astringency .  appearance : amber , great clarity , absolutely no head even on a hard pour ( just some pitiful foam ) aroma : cinnamon buns , cardamom , saffron , yeast flavor : a bit watery , light sweetness and a lot of spice ( mostly cardamom ) , finishes dry with more cardamom in the pitiful aftertaste mouthfeel : thin , low to no carbonation overall impression : well , i think the score speaks for itself .  m : syrupy . thick and decent carb .

what comes out of this bottle is n't so much beer as it is ... well ... hop juice . those beers exemplify the fresh citrus/pine bite , pleasant bitterness , and heavy malt background that are the hallmarks of the style .  miller genuine draft pours a typical macro yellow , with a white head from a clear twelve ounce bottle .  soft mouthfeel .

a - a hazy golden honey body with a generous amount of white foam . s - sour granny smith apples , lemons , white grapes , earthy yeast , soapy hops , spicy belgian yeast . t - green apples , tart cherries , lemon , pears , faint banana .  pours a light caramel/gold color with a white head with sub-par retention and an almost total lack of lacing .  the first sip delivers some hints of malt that are immediately shoved aside by the hops . some smooth , creamy textures ease up the hop flavors . pretty empty in the malt flavor department . just a hint more of malt and maybe a little more diversity from the hops . a lot good things happening in this beer , but not enough to get me to drink it again .

the aroma was very bold , with roasty , malty notes , some milk chocolate and sweet coconut . cask condition ales should be more creamy than this .  ( loses 1 appearance points for that ) .  m : medium to full in body with a moderate carbonation .

smells like a dubbel : malty , bready , fruity esters , caramel and a presence of hops .  this poured out murky amber with hardly a scattering of bubbles on top . no lacing of any kind .  the mouthfeel is fine , drinkability is ok , the aftertaste is n't excessively long or unpleasant , but it 's just not that tasty .

floaty bits there too . aroma is balanced with hops and malt .  the beer pours an almost clear color with a slight yellow hue . it has a frothy white head that quickly fades to spotty lacing .  mouthfeel is very full .

the aroma is malt and caramel with a hint of licorice , nice .  small fizzy white head forms but dies down just as quickly . no ring , no cloud and no lace .  the carbonation is moderate low and there is a smooth mouthfeel .

i 'm not so much as disappointed with new belgium as i am with the wine shop where i picked this up last week in st. louis . as my wife even said , it 's sour .  this american wild ale leaves the bottle with a hard pour to produce a dark yellowish brew . the white cap of foam above vanishes , i mean vanishes , quickly . a that is left in the glass is a conical cylinder of dark yellow liquid .  medium bodied and high carbonation .
nice coffee aroma with faint vanilla . overall : thankfully , i bought a single .  pours light yellow with no head .  mouthfeel is astringent and tingly , with good body and a dry finish .
very nice . taste : malt , but with a strong taste of fish oil .  when you could find a glass , this pours a light golden color with no head .  feel is well carbonated with a firm body .
has a flowery alcoholy aroma , strong , with some fruit .  apperance : straw yellow with a minimal head .  nice clean mouthfeel , with just the right amount of carbonation .

appearance : pours a hazy pale golden color with a very nice head that leaves plenty of lacing - unfortunately , its all downhill from there smell : apricot fruity aromas with a clear dollop of alcohol taste : starts out aggressively in the mouth with a piney , resinous hop flavor overwhelming the fruitiness i was expecting from the aroma ; after the swallow , the bitter and metallic piney hops literally explode in your mouth and challenge you to a duel - i give up !  pours red/copper/brown with a small off-white head that dissipates quickly to a light ring . very little lacing .  m : nice and smooth , very mellow .

smell is a pleasant heavy bready smell with some tea in the background .  yellow with almost no cloudiness ( despite the claims of not being filtered ) . thin skin of white foam for a head .  mouthfeel is nice had good body and goes down smooth .

smell is good . rich deep roasted malt .  a : the beer is a pale gold color with a very thin white head that fades very quickly and leaves almost no lace on the glass .  m - asahi super dry is dry but i would n't call it super dry . quite a surprise with how carbonated this one is .

this is the first lagunitas beer i 've had , and after hearing a lot of good things about this brewery , i have to say i 'm pretty disappointed . as a lover of both good beer and good coffee , i really like coffee stouts if they are done well , which they are usually not . this one was far to bright and acidic tasting for a stout ; not a lot of roasty or creamy flavors , just a lot of acidity from the columbian coffee , probably in conjunction with citrusy american hops . the choice of coffee might be the problem here ; a darker roast like a french or espresso roast usually translate better to stouts .  found this rare belgian in my girlfriends dad 's fridge . poured from bottle into pint glass pours 2 finger fluffy white head . unnattractive pale bmc straw color . i prefer this lime flavor over the non flavor of regular bud light mouthfeel is light with sharp prickly carbonation drinkability is high i guess if you actually liked it .  nice and round . good soft carbonation .

s : very fruity aromas . the orange essence dominates this beer and really sets the tone the entire time you drink it t : the citrus is by far the leading character with this one .  can , this poured a very pale gold , the head disappeared quickly .  mouthfeel : crisp on the tongue throughout . light in body . clean aftertaste .

the aroma is sweet figgy caramel malts , candy sugar , sweet grape juice and wood . it 's a bit watery and i did n't care for the flavors much - it just was n't too interesting .  pours clear and fizzy from the can , no head to speak of after a few sips . the color is essentially yellow-gold and light . smells like your typical adjunct lager , maybe with a little more rice than average . just do n't expect much from this japanese macro and you 'll be fine .  very little carbonation .

nice aroma , strong hints of caramel .  pours dark brown like nasty motor oil , and probably equally as thick ( hyperbole ) . no head . no lacing . anyways , it really suffered from the extremely low carbonation .  smooth body is a bit under medium . super crisp , snappy , a bit drying .

s- smells of alcohol for sure and a mixture of raspberries . d- the search continues for a fruit beer i like .  does n't look quite right . a little clear and no real head .  mouthfeel is rather smooth , viscous maybe .

s : got the aroma of dark fruits and alcohol .  it has a brown/apple orange color , and a white head that dissipates fast . is this ruined with no lacing ?  mouthfeel on the other hand is pretty good . medium to full bodied with a nice level of carbonation .

i 'll knock this down from a 5 , due to the excess yeast left behind . aroma wise this is on par for the style : light honey , metallic hops , some earthiness , and a hint of lemony hops too .  poor retention for the style no lace .  i like the body and mouthfeel , but the distinct alcohol burn and slight metallic aftertaste distract from the nice simcoe hop flavor .

nose was an interesting mix of pine hops , banana , black pepper and a general mustiness . hmmm . i was less than enthralled by all of this . finish was dry and spicy , but i could not get that metallic taste out of the way .  what the fuck is this ? ! i do n't appreciate it when beers are given names that make them sound like a different style than they actually are . i bought this thinking it was an oktoberfest and it came out looking like someone bottled a bad day at the hospital .  hops pretty much out of the equation until hints of them at the finish . other notes- the tastes are complex and appropriate for the style . you really can see what the brewers were going for . this beer tastes like christmas in a bottle . unfortunately , for me the various spices and other flavors were a bit much and did n't combine as well as they could have . i would have liked to see a more malt dominant profile with the spices and whatnot more in the background .

aromas of caramelized woods and sweet brown spices .  it is crisp and refreshing something i need after working in this summer heat .  m : at least the mouthfeel is nice . this is a full bodied beer with low to moderate carbonation .

indeeed , the plentifull of ginger in the nose is a good thing , probably the best of this beer .  a . clear yellow with a head that dissipates quickly .  it had a lite to medium body what was smooth and refreshing .

artificial cherry with chocolate as well t- like a very watered down way that it smells . more like a soda than a beer .  pours a sparkling gold that grows hazy when the yeast is swirled and added , hints of orange . the head was only two fingers tall , and quickly crackled away leaving no lacing , very disappointing for a hefe , when it was there it was white in color .  thick in the mouth , it might be nice to have a few ounces of this on a cold night .

the nose is full of fresh raspberries and a hint of twangy wheat . very inviting and fruity . i get barely a hint of berries here .  poured chilled in a glass tea cup . a : clear orange yellow ; inert ; head dissipates quickly ; no lacing s : very malty , but nothing special t : dry , earthy , lightly hopped ( ibus are admittedly low ) ; very little character or complexity m : the low carbonation leaves this feeling dead in the mouth d : you could go through several of these in a row , but there may be better beers for that  md body and strong carbonation .

a - very clear like a highly clarified lager s- sweet whitebread and adjunt malts t - spicy peppered roasted corn . if you watch the average ratings of wychwood it seems like the are going farther and farther down .  not a bad beer at all if your looking for an inexpensive , refreshing , macro . the color and head retension leave something to be desired .  m : just fine - refreshing with a mild carbonation .

smells of sweet caramel malt , orange zest , cinnamon , clove and some other mulling spices . you can really taste the sweetness of the malt .  a - pours a rather limp , clear amber . i know this is a strong beer , but come on , this looks flat .  mouthfeel was solid .

smell is a turn-on , big piney hop notes , makes me want to go roll around in a conifer forest . a disappointing mess .  really irritating looks really great and cloudy gold with some fine particles floating about in the glass s ~ citrus !  mouthfeel is smooth and medium bodied carbonation .

smell : the aromas are mixed fruit with grapes at the front , tremendous oatmeal , and a bit winey .  modelo especial pours a typical lager yellow with very little head from a clear twelve ounce bottle .  mouthfeel is creamy and full , very satisfying , but a little slick upfront and a little warming in the finish .

aroma : flowery and perfume like hop aroma . light presence of pale malts , slight fruity ester aroma .  pours a very pale-clear , almost scary color .  the beer was recently purchase from belmont station so i know it 's not too old mouthfeel : medium body and medium to low carbonation overall : just and ok beer .

aroma : complex nose . fruity with grapes , raisins and plums . it might be a little old or something , because it is certainly more like a wild ale than an imp . stout . no best buy date on bottle .  labatt canadian ale pours a urine yellow color with a hint of gold .  creamy feel . drying . nice . for some reason , this tastes like cheap mac and cheese .

it smells of honeyed malts with a faint snuff of hops possibly .  the raspberry flavor was no where to be found . it did have a nice smell but the taste did n't match it . a friend recommended it to me and needless to say i was not impressed and will not be trying it again ,  mouthfeel : refreshing .

smells sweet and hoppy , hints of caramel and some spices . it 's a subtle but enjoyable medley .  pours a dirty , muddy brown with zero head . ugly as hell but the pungent aroma invites you closer .  and this is with some decent aging on it so the hops have had some time to calm down.. medium light bodied with lightish carbonation , this has a good mouthfeel .

says on the bottle that it 's unfiltered but it looks pretty darned filtered to me as it 's not very cloudy and i do n't see much yeasty goodness in my pint glass . smell has the typical yeasty aroma that a witbier has , slight aroma of orange . had higher hopes for this one as i like witbier , the smell was encouraging but the taste was quite a letdown , very watery .  the inconvienient placement of a label band around the neck of the bottle made it almost impossible to avoid pouring in a few bits of yeast . there is nothing on the label about bottle conditioning either which makes it equally difficult to avoid flakes of yeast sediment . it poured an amber beer with a thin white head that subsided to a thin film .  good carbonation .

s - strong chocolate smell .  looks like a euro lager . very light bubbling and hardly any head to speak of .  quite sweet with a fairly agreeable flavor until the finish which has a phenolic , chemical edge to it . the body has a nice fullness to it as well as a nice soft , chocolate tasting , roast grain flavor to it . this is newly arrived in arizona , so i do n't understand why this is so bad ; and to be honest the flavors of this beer seem pretty fresh , it is just that there are also some significantly off components to this beer as well .

nose is pleasant ; sweet , with rich cocoa kind of aroma and a nicely roasted fragrance as well , hints of a meaty character in there and some woody notes , maybe a hint of some fortified wine as well . smells enticing , and interesting . taste is predominantly sour , with the gritty , ashy bitterness not quite reaching the highs i would expect , and instead the roasted character feels a bit under-saturated to the point that it 's insipidly sour .  appearance : poured a sick yellow with minimal head .  mouthfeel : the beer does have a pleasant body that is thick and chewy without making it a sipper beer . there is a definitely slick feeling to the beer which i would guess is from copious amounts of oat in the grist .

thick sticky and dark , no carbonation or headsmells candish and heavy alcohol like a port or sherry , sweet almost prunish tastesyrupy heavy feelfingers get sticky just from touching it.if you like a brandy and cigar after your meal you might like this .  a : pours a golden yellow colour with a lot of fizz that dissipates rather too quickly for my liking . overall , a decent macro from australia 's 'oldest brewery ' ( as the bottle claims ) . i have had better but for a macro , this is pretty darn good .  m : tingly on the top and smooth and light going down .

s : coffee and cream mixed with a lot of chocolate and coco powder . mmmm . t : much different from the nose ; it 's not really sweet at all .  2 finger head that fades incredibly quickly to leave no trace of lacing or head .  medium mouthfeel .

picked this up because i had heard nothing but good things about this brewery ... i must say i was rather unimpressed . giving the beautiful color i assumed this was going to be a rather hoppy ipa.. unfortunately this wasnt the case ... mouthfeel was very nice.. very smooth and creamy ... but the taste was lacking in the hoppiness ipas usually have .  color is average , taste is average at all . as far as a lager it is avarage , i prefer this one than a molson .  a friend of mine here in greensboro thinks this beer is the one all be all and shared a bottle with me sunday night.poured into a standard pint glass a deep clear amber/bronze with a half finger slight off white head atop , great clarity and hue to the beer.whoo man the aromas are borderline harsh , just wicked resin with a bit of caramel base but the hop onslaught is wicked in not such a good way.the 168 ibu 's is just overkill on the palate , its dry as all get out and bitter to the hilt , wicked pine resin and alcohol make you wan na grab a glass of water and chug it.iam a full on hophead but this is overkill to the umteenth degree , sorry brian i told ya i liked it but man that stuff is harsh .

aroma : terrificic for sytle . very floral . low malt .  serving type : 1 pint 6 fl oz appearance : pours a brightly coloured yellow w/ no real head to speak of and no lacing .  smooth and light bodied .

aromatics lead off with raw sugar , honey , cloves , and booze-soaked apricot . tacky and slick . sugar-dusted apricots , boozy fusels , and crushed cloves start the palate . a decent bitterness tries to balance but fails . finishes with lingering sugar syrup , spicy yeast , booze , and a hint of menthol .  green glass bottle ( .33cl ) with a classic pressure cap served into a la chouffe tulip in gouda , holland . a : one finger head of poor thickness , no cream , and poor retention .  medium carbonation . smooth mouthfeel .

the aroma was pretty sweet with raspberry juice and some chocolate malts .  had this straight from the bottle ( no sense pretending it 's worth a pour ) . maybe it 's because i had been smoking , but i really did n't mind the natty light ( first time i had any since college ) . it 'll go fine with pizza or what not , and whom do you really need to impress ?  mouthfeel is very creamy , almost like drinking foam . very pleasant .

immediate aroma of malty pumpkin pie , nutmeg , cinnamon and allspice . ca n't detect any hoppiness through the spices .  '' normally i 'd apply that kind of criticism to shitty american macro 's but hey , at least they do n't paint themselves as totally superior light beers .  mouthfeel is nice . medium-bodied , but not mouth coating .

corn and light pale malt with some nicely floral scent for a lager , i 'm pleasantly surprised by the heft of the nose on this particular adjunct lager . however , the flavor does n't back up the floral notes that the aroma promised , and i 'm thrust back into the world of a standard , watery , adjunct lager .  it 's not really a `` bad '' beer , but it 's not really a good beer . if you have to drink a light lager , you can find much better .  m - medium body with a nice hearty chew . light carbonation .

smell is pretty nice ... some apple , juicy pear , sugary-sweetness .  the beer pours golden clear , no head . the taste is like sparkling water , apple juice , touch of lemon , and malt .  nicely balanced carbonation .

aroma : some plum and raisin aromatics along with some sweet caramel presence . there are some toasty malts there along with what smells like melanoidins .  tonight i picked up a 12 pack of pbr 12oz cans for $ 5.99 , and i must say it tasted a hell of a lot better this go around then the last time i had it a year or so ago . if you are trying to get drunk on the cheap , this shit is far better then the alternatives in my town ( milwaukees best , miller high life , etc ) .  the feel is light , sharp and very crispy , especially to start out .

s : sweet , with lots of creme brulee and rosewood .  12 oz tap pour into an american tumbler pint @ skippy's a - clear yellow straw with minimal head and bad retention with absolutely no lacing .  the spicing is nice on the medium body .

lacing is minimal s - malty in the nose with some toasted bread . the aroma overall is pleasing , but i dig malt a lot .  tapped into a pint glass at the flying saucer in austin . appearance - clear brown body .  i did not enjoy this beer . purchased in bomber form , the beer poured nicely , but my hopes began to wane when i sniffed it . too much chocolate . the chocolate nose reminded me of chocolate syrup for lattes , which is never as good as hershey 's syrup -- which is n't very good . the taste was more offensive -- like someone dumped a bunch of flavoring into what could have been a good beer . well , someone did . although i did not like the strength of the chocolate , it was the synthetic characteristic that i could n't get past .

smell : the beer smells like chocolate dipped cherries combined with coffee .  started to pour and got zero head , so i aggressively finish the pour to help it along .  full bodied with admirable carbonation .

smells of lemon and orange peel .  pale gold topped by a fast-disappearing finger of fizzy white head .  the mouthfeel is really smooth but it reminds me too much of a banana beer i had a couple weeks ago .

smell : sweet , biscuity malt with perhaps a touch of hops . a rather complex scent for a simple beer .  smell is a weak malty lead with a smaller hop background , similiar to the other thousand average lagers that share the euro ale ancestory . taste is flat , watery with a lemony lingering . mouthfull is initially high zingy carbonation on the tongue that dissipates rapidly , a mild frothy to creamy occurance , which not surprisingly leaves no gassy feel in the gut . very easy beer to drink , its clean and friendly . its like water  it 's crisp and sharp , not bold and complex . it looks good and feels good in your mouth .

s : chocolate brownie with a slight hint of malt .  appearance- after holding a clumpy head for about a minute in my tripel karmeliet goblet , it quickly vanishes to nothing . the carbonation is awkward and sporadic , not at all attractive , and the color is a dirty yellow-gold . the vapid , watery consistency is very detracting , and the beer went completely flat in the ten minutes i was reviewing this .  mouthfeel is solid ; ample carbonation , slightly dry on the finish , not overly resinous .

a-clear yellow-gold color , small head that disappears quickly , zero lacing s-citrus , lemon/orange/tangerine , nice aroma t-little flavor , very bland , almost felt like a was drinking water m-okay carbonation , very light , lacking somewhat although smooth d-i could probably drink a ton of these , but not sure i would want to due to lack of flavor my expectations for this brew were squashed , as played this one up in my head due to reviews in magazines i 'd read on this award-winning beer .  pours a very murky amber with surprisingly weak head .  a very minimal white head is apparent with smile delicate lacing along the side of the glass . i 'm going to forgo my normal formulaic review to say very little else other than this beer is liquid pepper with a hint of ipa . it is very peppery and very smokey . i fear i may need to drink another beer to just put out the fire from this beer ! i ca n't say i like the taste of this beer . there is very little to taste other than just the pepper . i taste very little of my beloved ipa . i ca n't really find a reason or a purpose for this beer other than maybe a pepper or texas themed party . i 've had many other beers with hints of pepper and that 's all beer needs .

s - a very sharp pine dominants over caramel and chocolate malts . as it warms it is easy to notice some alcohol on the nose .  a-dark yellow in color with a white that that dissipates very quickly . not impressed with the appearance of this beer .  palate was medium bodied , creamy , soft and lively carbonation , with light astringency . neither a beer nor a lambic really , just a monster of its own .

a sweet malt-citrus aroma with a hint of banana . taste is far outdone by the aroma and i ca n't beleive the two have the same origin .  a : brownish opaque color . no head ... boo . very hard to get anything else ... t : again more sugar and i get the alcohol at the end .  had very fine carbonation . thick creamy mouthfeel , which was good .

i am testing various chocolate stouts and was not impressed with this one . i was expecting more aroma and taste from the chocolate and coffee . i prefer to drink coffee black , which can be bitter depending on the brand , but this was extremely bitter .  *did not mind , would not buy* app : orange gold hues , dull no life .  decent body ... it 's a carbonation supported medium body which makes it clean and crisp like crunchy fall leaves . i like the mouthfeel , just not too much else .

this is not a dubbel , sorry . aromas are initially of lemongrass and lime , and as it warmed i picked up dark fruits and spices , with a touch of caramel . lots of lime , mint , and herbal / grassiness , with just a bit of coriander - quite different from the latter-stage aromas . nothing rich or dark fruity about this - it 's all citrus .  sort of a straw color , with very little head , absolutely no lacing .  altogether a full taste though and with good and high carbonisation alltogether good mouthfeel .
s : quite smokey with some roasted malt , burnt coffee , and bacon , which along with the smoke was the most evident aroma .  looks like a golden , sometimes-bubbly beer .  good carbonation .

aroma : wow , it does n't suck . very fruity - not cascade-like fruit notes , but perhaps yeasty esters - caramelly , doughy bread notes , a gummy bear-like quality . dare i say this is almost pleasant ? taste : a disappointment , or perhaps the first place my expectations seemed to match this beer 's performance .  drank straight from 24 oz . looks the same as any other macro . a : light yellow .  the mouthfeel is medium-full and creamy .

s - very malt forward . the aroma is very nice but the flavor just was n't balanced .  the head was one finger and pure white , left no lacing and did not retain at all .  the mouth feel is medium bodied with decent coating and weight .

really a nicely put together aroma . taste is almost sour/bitter coffee , really unpleasant compared to how nice the nose was .  ; ) pours a very light yellow with a half finger of head . looks like piss to be honest .  m : the body is medium with medium to high carbonation .

aromas of pine and citrus , very fresh smelling . carbonation hits the tongue pretty hard , but there 's no flavor on the front of the tongue .  has a carbonated body that is a seethru pale gold w/ a decent head that disappears almost simultaneously when you put the mug to your mouth .  medium bodied , moderate carbonation .

s : pleasant british fruityness ( lacking in plenty of north american versions ) , chocolate , brown sugar , roasted nuts . t : great british fruityness , plenty of chocolate , some nut , warming alcohol , a little fusil .  usual pale , transparent golden with some medium lace .  i bought a bottle of this as part of a mix a 6 from food & friends on 20th & spruce in philadelphia . i must have purchased a bad bottle , it was from batch # 9462 . the smell was there , it had an awesome coffee aroma to it that i was very excited for . until i tasted it . it tasted like a sour . i love sours , but not when i 'm expecting a coffee stout .
smell -- nice fragrance . fruity .  a- very transparent yellow color with about two+ finger width 's of head .  medium mouthfeel .

this smelled so good , but the taste fell flat as the flavors really just did not mesh well .  this beer pours a boring golden color with a moderate head .  m- fairly thick with a good level of carbonation to keep it from getting syrupy . the alcohol is n't too noticeable , but the mouthfeel and overall heaviness of the beer limit its drinkability .

minimal spots of lace left behind . earthy , soily aroma with lots of zesty , peppery spice , dark malt and bready yeast . slightly medicinal and herbal with hints of dark fruit . very unique combination of dark malt , spice and belgian yeast in the nose .  a : very clear gold , with no visible carbonation . a foamy white head does n't stick around . no lace is left behind . the heat is strong , but not so over the top that i found myself reaching for my water . toward the end , i tasted a bit of straw like malt and even a hint of corn breaking through .  m & d - the bottle says snappy and crisp . that 's right .

color was fine , red tinged edges but mostly black , aroma was nice , sweet and a bit smokey .  this beer does not have great color , or head and the smell is of corn , but the beer does have some good qualities .  m : surprisingly pleasing . the citrus character refreshes the mouth and lasts until swallowed .

good smell , a balanced mingling of musty red apples , toffee , cherry pipe tobacco and a pinch of alcohol . autumnal and welcoming . high hopes for the flavor , based on the nice look and smell , but no , this is not a great weizenbock .  this can be alright sometimes . appearance- gold color , clear smell- corn , lemon taste- weak flavor , sweet mouthfeel- light body , watery drinkability- can possibly be drank again , would n't usually do it , maybe on a hot day or something , thin enough where it might be thirst quenching but probably only one  mouthfeel was full bodied with medium carbonation .

nose is vinous , slightly vinegary , roasty and a trace of cocoa comes out towards the back .  pours a turbid , cloudy light brown , topped with a thick tan head . are those things supposed to be floating in my beer ?  notably full mouthfeel as well , but overall pretty bog standard ris offering .

the smell is of sweet , citrusy caramel malts with a touch of breadiness and some grassy hops in the background as well .  appearance - transparent golden yellow with a pure white head that quickly disappearred .  light body and medium carbonation , feels quite nice .

smell : sweet dark sugar , caramel , vanilla . odor of hops is certainly detectable but not overpowering .  ichabod pours a cloudy , very light golden color , with no head ( ha fucking ha ) .  mouthfeel : the mouthfeel was appealing to me in that it was malty but the slightly bitter hops kept your mouth dry and encouraged you to drink more of the beverage . a solid mouthfeel that acted upon the whole mouth interior .

putting a 100 wt bulb behind it showed no light at all ( the sun 's never around when i 'm tasting ) . the nose started right out with black licorice with some moderate phenols . unsweetened bakers chocolate and prunes on toasted whole wheat bread came behind . a pleasurable snort , spent a long time swirling this one before tasting .  pale straw , clear & soapy lacing for a head .  m- the carbonation actually mellows out nicely in this medium bodied beer . it 's creamy on the palate and i actually like the fact that a yeasty aspect develops as it warms up .

after further review , there are lots of white sediments floating around in my beer . s - dark fruits , like plums and rasins dominate the smell .  first impression was that the beer was cloudy pale gold beer and did n't have a hefeweizen smell .  mouthfeel was nice and creamy . goes down smooth .

tastes like lemon pepper , and smells plummy .  pours a clear straw yellow with a pretty small head and no lacing at all . looks like apple juice actually .  mouthfeel is smooth and maybe a little creamy , and i can see drinkability being decent with this beer . appearance : 3.5 smell : 3.0 taste : 3.0 mouthfeel : 4.0 drinkability : 3.0

aroma is full of spices , with clove , nutmeg , cinnamon , and some oak . flavor is neither malty or hoppy ... it is just spices .  reviewed from notes on 07/06/10 poured from bottle to pint a : pours with low/no visible carbonation . no head .  despite the finish , the mouthfeel is excellent . d : avoid .

nose is sweet buttery milk chocolate and roasted malts .  appearance - light yellow colour with no head .  it 's pretty good in the mouth , never really any sense of harshness and the head made every taste a little cremey like , so it was good .

smells of spices , hops and the slightest hint of grains .  very average lager . pours yellow/golden color with white head that dissipated quickly .  the mouthfeel is medium bodied and sharp on the tongue but is a bit creamier and smooth feeling on top , which helps this go down .

smells strongly yeasty and sweet , with an almost citrusy smell .  freshness marked as `` enjoy by aug. '' pours a very pale , straw-ish yellow colored beer , touch of haze , with scattered slow moving carbonation bubbles . quick white foam heads dies to a translucent wispy lacing of almost nothingness . hmm ... i guess if you wanted a beer that you did n't really have to think about and wanted to suck down your neck in the hot summer ... this could be your beer .  mouthfeel : the body is on the thick side of medium with mild , tingly carbonation and a finish that has just a touch of dryness to it .

the aroma was an overwhelming amount of cranberry , which should have been an indication of the impending disaster . the taste was fruity but had a signifigant sourness to it that i found very ofensive .  suprisingly , not a bad beer . very crisp and clean taste , not unlike pbr . it 's worthy of a try if you enjoy straight-forward lagers , or are looking for a budget brew .  the mouthfeel was good balance body and bitterness .

aromas were of nutmeg/malt with a cinnamon hint .  poured from 12 oz bottle into flared pilsner glass a- very pale american macro straw color . loose white head only one finger even with a vigorous pour . head disapated very quick to nothing . d- i guess there is better pumpkin ales for your money but this one is very drinkable , watered down version .  m - medium coating with a tingle over entire tongue .

scents of coffee , bitter chocolate , roasted malts .  cheap and ultra-light , you can get over the watered down taste and general bad beer smell as long as you 're willing to buy and drink a lot of it .  the flavor does have raspberry hints but not what you would get from say an authentic framboise . this seemed like an amber ale with raspberry syrup added to it . the alcohol was noticeable which was strange for a 5.6 % brew . this was not bad but there was also nothing really good about this beer other than the appearance .
s - citrus hops , pine notes , malty .  it reminds me of apple cider . starts off with kind of an apple flavor followed up by a hint of light malt .  medium bodied with a super creamy mouthfeel .

the smell is a big hit of vanilla with a cherry flavor acompanied by what seems to be bourbon ( i have n't had a lot , but it smells like good hard liquor ) .  paperwhite head that waits until you look away to fall flat on its back . there 's just the amber liquor sitting there , looking as if no bubbles had ever graced its surface . even topping up the glass fails to resurrect the head .  m : thick and slightly syrupy . proper for the style .

poured into my rapscallion snifter aggressively which led to a nice head and a abundance of aromas coming up from the table .  pours out dark orange and bubbly , nothing but a wisp of white head to top it off . it does n't look like a beer , looks like a sparkling wine cooler type drink .  m : medium light body . well balanced carbonation . very smooth .

smells nice . has a well-seated raspberry flavor ; a bit sweet , a bit tart .  forms a smallish white head of large sized bubbles . after a minute or so , the head disappears leaving a sticky looking lace on the glass . and not that good type lace either .  m : highly carbonated , crisp , refreshing , finishes the littlest bit dry .

s : banana , vanilla , tart citrus , has a `` creamy/lush '' smell of vanilla citrus . rounded smell . t : tart citrus , some pepper and vanilla . bland in flavor .  pours a light honey color , with active carbonation . i always worry about any non-stout beer where the head completely disappears .  a : pours copper colored with a bit of white head that disappears quickly and leaves just a halo and lacing s : big pumpkin smell , but it has too much of a buttery , biscuity taste , like a pie crust .

the nose is odd . overall , the aroma is good .  a- a very pale piss color is appearent on pour , active carbonation throws a massive foamy head that floats like ice on the brew .  m : good mouthfeel on a reasonably full body .

i thought i would be horrified by this , but it smells alright and it works well for what they were going for . the strongest aroma is by far tomato , with oregano herbalness second .  i just do n't get all the hype surrounding this beer . a : clear yellow with a tootpaste white head that quickly dissipates s : tough to tell .  the body on this one is good , with a nice heft from the unfiltered body .

smell : nutty molasses taste : there 's the slightest hint of alcohol .  pours an effervescent honey color with 3 fingers of sand colored head . zero head retention & lacing s : biscuitty malt & grassy hops t : biscuitty malt dryness & a very dare i say west coast hop slant , grapefruit & lemony hops all over the the throat & tongue .  the beer was way way harsh on the palate . you can taste a slight cherry taste ( from the lindemans kriek blended in ) as well as regular ommegang ale , which is nice , but the alcohol is n't hidden at all and the significant malt and yeast ca n't cover up the boozey flavors . the label says it 's ready for immediate consumption without aging , but i do n't agree . i was disappointed , especially considering how much i love ommegang , hennepin and rare vos .

smells very nice , yeasty with dark fruits and obvious alcohol , fine for the style .  pours with a weak one-finger off-white head that fades quickly to a meager collar that tries but fails to leave lacing .  mouthfeel is pretty light bodied with nice dry , crisp and refreshing qualities . a session beer for sure .

aroma is lightly malty , with a bit of a sour base , along with a subtle salty feel that is dulled by a light spiced character . the aroma is unique and nicely concentrated , along with a taste that falls short of anything special .  a pale yellowish malt liquor golden appearance with a foamy white head that quickly dissipates into a fine lacing . aromas of lemony cooked corn fused with clear alcohol , a light sweet cereal maltiness in the background . if you are already familiar with macro ice lagers there are elements of taste you will recognize right off , sweet sugary cereal malts , the lemony cooked corn , i 'll give this points for not tasting like over boiled corn , the stale , spent , neutral tasting hops , while the body is light , it is a bit heavier than most ice lagers , that malt liquor solvent alcohol flavor , dry and largely clean in the finish .  hey , that happens from time to time ... ; ^ ) it has a good medium mouthfeel and the carbonation is on the light side of medium . bottom line : it 's worth a try but it 's not something that exactly grabs your attention .

s : grape , honey , white wine ( muscat ) and alcohol . t : spicy white wine alcohol front , medium honey and grape middle with a dry finish .  pours an effervescent , semi-hazed straw/gold with 3 fingers of pearl colored head . zero head retention & lacing s : grassyness & phenols t : green melon , grassy hops , slight dryness & hints of strawberries up front .  light carbonation .
appealing .  a : pours a one finger head of soft cream , decent thickness , and poor retention . solid brown-black colour .  m : a lot of co2 ( trippel ) pretty creamy

drinkability : its sweet but gassy , crisp but watery , strong nose but flavorless .  a : pours a crystal clear light yellow with a soapy white head that dissipates rather quickly . a fair amount of carbonation floats up toward the top of the glass .  m- the mouthfeel is medium bodied with a good amount of carbonation .

the smell is lightly fruity with notes of apricots ands pears .  '' overall this beer is very thin . there is n't any body , and even less foam . the color is a very light brown .  m/d - medium bodied and very smooth/creamy . great feel to the beer , just not a great taste .

piney - resiny hop flavor . malt was very much in the background . two friends and myself did a blind tasting of 4 imperial pale ales , and this one surprisingly scored the lowest on all our scorecards .  a - poured out a golden/yellow color . it was highly carbonated with a small , white head that left no lace . d - not really something i 'd get for myself , no matter how cheap it is .  big citric show . t & m- medium body , creamy smooth . maltiness rolls out a light maltiness middle to end . d- just for shits and giggles i tried this brew again ... sorry , game over . i love stone brewing but they went too far with the god damn hops ... and you know what hops i am talking about .

smell : like a typical canadian , some malts & lightly hopped aroma covering up a corny adjunct smell , but theres also caramel , white grape , and a hint of nut in there . for the style , this is rather good .  a - looks gold , clear , light , no head , not much bubbles being made , not appealing .  mouthfeel is light bodied , with quite possibly a finish that is crisper than any other brew this ba had experienced . very intriguing .

smell is rather fruity , with none of the coffee and roasted smells that are normally a hallmark of a ris . actually welcome for me , it 's a nice change of pace .  pours amber/caramel with 1 finger of offwhite head that drops off quickly . zero lacing or head retention s : vanilla & caramel in copious quantities t : starts out with a lot of vanilla , then caramel up front .  as the malt bill is substantial , this beer has a nice heavy body . the carbonation is moderate , and overall it has a nice feel .

the aroma is pretty good , if one dimensional . i seem to recall this smelling even better in the past ... but i 'm picking up a ton of buttery graham cracker .  has a very pale yellow color with a 1/2 inch head .  taste : smooth with a crisp malt and fullish mouth feel , herbal and almost tobacco like hop bitterness and flavour erupt in the mouth with a light juniper berry flavour . notes : not a bad brew at all though hops seem to over take the brew with an earthened hop flavour that may not be agreeable with some beer drinkers .

additional fullness is contributed by cloves , stewed apples , and formaldehyde , resulting in a smell that is multi-faceted if a little busy . t : begins off-dry , with mild vinous fruit alongside building lactic and acetic tartness that is interrupted by harsh bitterness and scorched malt .  pours a clear pale amber with a thin white head , and not much lacing .  the mouthfeel is good , almost crisp , but slightly heavy even for an imperial ipa the drikability is decent , but not great .

smell : apples . i 'm sort of blown away by the almost cider-like scent , with a light yeasty component . i 'm a fan of barleywines but this seemed more like a strong , sweet cider on the initial attack with an unusual , fibrous , rotten-apple , yeasty finish that did n't quite jive .  ( bottle poured into pint glass ) this was much darker than i would expect from a hefeweizen ... almost amber it was such a dark yellow . there was absolutely no head to speak of and the same goes for any lacing on the glass .  m - smooth , thick and a little refreshing .

the aroma is very sweet and hoppy with big clementine aromas and even a touch of grapefruit zest .  poured from the bottle into a pint glass , beer is a hazy , straw-yellow color with a thick , viscous white head ; there are floaty chunks in the beer that are not apetizing .  m : thin-bodied and well carbonated ; crisp and dry .

aroma of medium caramel , grassy hops , some rye spice , and a belgium sweetness .  its pale yellow appearance does not bode well , but ... its lack of a real beer smell does not bode well , but ... its lack of a malty or hoppy taste does not bode well , but ... its mouth feel is that of a pale ale whuich is acceptable.. but it is definitely more than the sum of its parts .  first sip has the strong body you 'd expect from an english stout , but the positive impressions begin to dissolve when the taste coalesces into a bland , mild muddiness that lasts throughout the pint . unless you look for a beer on the basis of mouthfeel and consistency alone , there is little to be found in this blandsville brew .

i actually liked the smell of it but was unpleasantly surprised by the taste .  thanks to the person in my spirit tasting group who left this behind . poured into a tulip , this beer has virtually no head at all .  the mouthfeel is full bodied with moderate carbonation , and a smooth texture . overall , this is an average beer at best .

source/serving : draft smell : intense pine , grapefruit . notes : did not enjoy even though i often like very hoppy beers .  pale , clear , and yellow . basically pale apple juice . it 's fine for an eve on the deck , or with a meal on a patio .  tastes too spicy which throws this brew out of balance the mouth feel was great prickly carbonation lifting the sweetness , but not the spice , while creating a light mouth feel .

s : very floral & hoppy with earthy tones and some malts in the backgound . hints of fruit too .  this has the typical appearance you 'd find in most macro lagers . yellow body with oversized carbonation .  bobbb has a nice smoothness to it , courtesy of the wheat , and surprisingly has a decent amount of carbonation given the appearance .

it was also a pretty watery stout .  drank from my cigar city snifter . a-pours golden orange in color . little head , maybe 3/4 '' , but that fades quickly . no lacing left . t- at first i thought i was gon na really enjoy this brew , , , ,then the banana disappeared on me after the second that it touched my lips . m- under carbonaed and very water like .  full bodied , it is incredibly sweet and unidimensional ; it is candy sweetness , then candy sweetness , and more sugar .

the nose is fruity , a blend of strawberry and peach , with some light spicing .  not much lacing to brag about . light brown in color .  m - good , full body that goes down smoothly d - interesting beer for me .

grainy , corn-like aroma with minimal hops and some low levels of yeast character like green apples .  this beer pours a very light straw color , with no head to speak of .  m : creamy , smooth , a little syrupy maybe .

s- the malty aroma is pleasant enough with bready notes on the side .  the beer itself is a moderately pale yellow colour , and before even tasting it , the high carbonation is obvious from the bubbles streaming to the top of the glass .  m : one of the thickest and most syrupy barleywines i 've tried .

it smells grand . a nice fall day ( somewhere that the trees lose their leaves - it 's about 50 degrees out and clear . i 'm glad i gave it good points for smell before tasting it .  appearance : color was very pale light yellow and reminded me of something ... what could it be ?  pretty good on the mouthfeel .

i knew nothing about this beer going into it , so i guess its off to a good start , smells good . t : heres where it throws me for a curveball .  serving : bottle ( batch # 70 ) a - the beer was a pale cloudy yellow with a bright white , big bubbled head that dissipated quickly and left absolutely zero lacing . unfortunately , the quickly dissipating head took away some of the more interesting apple notes while drinking .  there is a really creamy feel and very small amount of carbonation .

s- a good sweet fruit smell with a burnt malt hint .  expecting a gusher but thankfully it was n't ... this does n't start off great with a really ugly pour . a very weak off white head without much retention or lacing at all ... the aroma is very vinous at first , white wine , grape skin , oak , butter , interesting and new .  m - medium to full body beer . pretty thick .
looks and smells crazy , but tastes entirely too tart .  a : very boring , clear pale yellow with hardly any head at all . looks like a bad adjunct .  mouthfeel : substantial , good on the tongue .

while the aroma was good but not great , at least it would seem that a genuine weizen yeast was used .  it poured a golden brown color with very little head which was completely gone after about a minute . the carbonation was basically non existant also .  the mouthfeel was good , the body medium/full and the carbonation average .

s - the smell starts off with with some roasted malt and dark chocolate . there is some fruity cherry smells that makes me think of cordial cherries .  natural light abv : 4.2 % a : the appearance is your ordinary light beer .  m - one of the better qualities of this brew . it was crisp and sharp .

appearance : dark amber , good clarity , not much head development aroma : lush malty backbone w/ just a hint of dark malts and roast , very light woodsy hops , strawberry fruitiness , angel 's foodcake , hazelnuts flavor : subdued malt sweetness , predominating flavors are dark malts and a pronounced hop bitterness , hop flavor is definitely `` english '' , wood , finishes dryish with resiny hops and a hint of corn ( weird !  poured into a samuel smith pint glass on 10/19/11 light , faded straw-yellow ; pretty clear save for a bit of chill haze . one and a half finger head of white foam dissipates to a much thinner , soapy layer . hardly any lace . my first impressions are , in this order : watery , carbonation , metallic .  m - medium body , slightly creamy with light carbonation .

aroma has some caramel , a hint of fruit and maybe some jaggery . at first , it has a harsh buttery hop bite , maybe a little metallic note and finally the rich , aromatic sweetness found in the nose . medium bodied with a slick mouthfeel .  this beer also pours a very light straw with a very thin head .  the mouthfeel is this beer 's only saving grace ( if i had to come up with one ) . very creamy and smooth with mild carbonation .

fruity , sweet , and nutty in the nose .  poured into a tulip glass . clear , golden color with a very small head that quickly disappeared . looks flat and lifeless .  feel is actually pretty good , with some pleasant carbonation and texture .

smell : smells deliciously malty with a small trace of coffee .  corona is a beer that is now a victim of it 's own marketing success , as it is shunned by any serious beer drinker while still enjoying popularity among the youngest drinkers , the hip , and people who do n't really appreciate beer . i loved it in my college years and still consider it serviceable , especially in the summer , although i now can see it for what it is..fairly bland and well advertised . thin , pale yellow with little head .  cold 22 oz bottle served in a straight-sided glass . the flavor is as promised by the nose , but the anise flavor is definitely more natural and less artificial/sweet/candyish . there 's also a definite funkiness to the licorice , which between the oak and the belgian yeast is no surprise . maybe if i really loved licorice this could be an ok thing , but sadly i 'm not a big fan .

the nose comprises caramel , light buttery biscuits , figs , red grapes , light maple syrup , and raisins .  a-it was a light beer with not much color , it had an unimpressive head .  not the usual cali ipa hop blast . m- went down smooth , crisp and refreshing . prob . this beer 's strongest asset , highly drinkable .

incredibly sweet on the nose . raspberry puree .  a : not much head and what little there is disappears very quickly to a thin lace . notes : it is better than the macro brewery light beers but it is in that category for sure . no point in trying this again , and even if it were handed to me at a party i think i 'd just save the calories and have a glass of water instead .  i really do enjoy the mouthfeel of guinness nitro . maybe one day my palette will become too sophisticated for nitro smoothness . i drank 8 pints without retching .

smell is skunky like i expected ( and enjoy ) .  a - straw yellow , no head s - faintly decent aroma ; honey-yeasty t - the taste is about as the nose , vaguely decent .  medium-light body ; crisp and more than semi-dry on the finish .

s : toast , caramel , apples , vanilla , espresso . t : vanilla , coffee , chocolate , roasted finish .  pours a light yellow color with quickly diminishing head .  md thick body and moderate slightly creamy carbonation .

the aroma is very strong and sweet from a distance , but there 's a definite malt smell . up close , the smell becomes more fruity , having a definite apricot note atop the malty sweetness .  not even close to be an exciting beer or something i imagine i would recommend to anything but a novice wanting to try `` one of them fancy beers '' ( 312 has enough character to show the drinker of average domestics a bit of zing but still gateway/bland enough not to make them run back to their watery security blanket that comes in can ) and a big let down compared to other goose island things i have tried .  taste is very bland , but the mouthfeel is surprisingly smooth . the best part of the beer actually .

s = smells of hay , fresh grain and caramel .  pours amber with a ridiculous head .  mouthfeel is heavy malt on the tongue . finishes crisp with a lingering hoppy bitterness and sweet malt on the lips .

it 's a deep amber , and my vigorous pour created a nice 1/2 '' head with gorgeous lacing on the very top of my glass after the first sip ! it 's intensely sweet . what a warm , inhalation of relaxation . this beer is a bit harsh , yet mind mellow .  part of a world beer mixer , so far a very mixed bag to include some beers not listed this site.. pours golden with 1 finger of slight white head . no head retention or lacing s : corny with wet dog ( both dissapate quickly ) , ugh .  the mouthfeel is nice and creamy , but still there is that tannic wood in the background cutting against it . not very drinkable at all , like a beautiful cabernet that someone has oaked all to hell .

strong fruity smells , a mix of squished berries .  more or less a typical pils as far as i am concerned . not really bad but nothing really stood out either .  fairly pleasantly full mouthfeel actually with not a great deal of sizzle from the carbonation .

the smell was hoppy and sweet with hints of fruit .  pours a cloudy burgundy-brown with no head and no lacing .  this was not a bad beer at all , merely average . it did have a good mouth feel but i was only able to drink one of them .

what a good stout should be . has the same as the smell qualities . has a dark fruit/ sourness when it 's colder .  a : half finger tan-colour head of very poor retention ( especially considering the low abv ) .  m - thick with a slight carbonation tingle , goes down fairly smooth .

smell - interesting . herbs and grass , some fresh leaves and citrus punctuate some obvious hoppiness .  lots of yeast sediment was left behind in the bottle . appearance : hazy/translucent golden yellow beer . no lacing either .  mouthfeel is nice - thick and creamy .

yeast with spice aroma , sour dry , with sugar texture . does n't all work out .  $ 4.13 / ea . wheat also abundant . a : no head , no lacing , no cover . cloudy stray body .  low to medium carbonation with a medium mouthfeel helps make this beer sort of drinkable for the style , i guess .

very strong , wine-like aroma . dark amber color .  the foam is a little scarce , and quickly falling to zero .  my 1st flanders oud bruin that is obviously meant to be a sour beer . i love belgian brews and ommegang is my all time favorite brewery , but i guess i am just not cut out for ouds .

a - very dark ( little to no light passes through it ) , almost no head at all ( what is there is tan and dissipates quickly ) s - smells promising with notes of dark chocolate and malt t - initial notes of coffee and dark chocolate resolving into a bit of smoke ... and then nothing ! disappointing because initially it shows a lot of promise with a good nose and some enticing darker notes .  woo hoo.. i was promised that factory fresh bud was amazing and well.. nope.. poured the same weak colour that it always is.. a bit of fluffy white head .  mouthfeel- medium body . good carbonation level .

) , citrusy , clean smell . sweetness comes out more as beer warmed .  upon pouring with no head , i checked the bottle for freshness date and none was present . as previously stated there was no head upon pouring , and no lacing whatsoever .  the mouthfeel is decent , as the carbonation and spice tingles your tongue . pretty average witbier .

light lacing ... interesting aroma that really captures the essence of pumpkin , has some spice and chocolate notes as well . too much pumpkin for me , but its good ... taste is pumpkin pie on steroids , just terrible .  the body is pale yellow , essentially clear but with a few stray flocs swimming about . the taste is blas and nondescript with no lace and no real character .  dark malts had a stronger presence and the hops have only partially faded enough to be in perfect balance . carbonation is lively , i could tell immediately from the loud hiss as i opened the bottle .

the aroma was similar to the delirium noel but with not as much spice . bartender tapped it into a really cool delirium tremens goblet that had the pink elephants on it .  a : clear hold colour . thin head without cream .  mouthfeel was creamy and light , with very high carbonation and very light feel .

nice aroma of spicy hops , mellow malt , and classic ale yeast , with a hint of citrus and pine .  pours a fizzy head that does n't last too long . color is a clear straw yellow . it is definitely a light beer that does n't pour much of a head . it does n't cost that much which is nice and you can drink a few without filling up .  not what i 'd expect from an ipa m : feels crisp , not slimy .

has the aroma of a big , ripe peach .  no stickiness in the lace that is left . not much in the smell , but it is a bit maltier and bit more noticeable than , say , a typical michelob . taste is a bit sweeter and maltier than the 'typical ' macro . the rice is fairly prominent . a baby step up from the 'typical ' macro like bud .  exciting . o : i think i prefer this slightly to duchesse du bourgogne , but only slightly - both are unnecessarily sweet and lacking in genuine complexity .

s : caramel , maple , hazelnut t : not as rich and sweet as it smells - cooked veggie ?  weak looking color with only a hint of hops in the smell and taste .  mouthfeel : the body is on the thicker side with tingly carbonation and a dry finish .

sweet and cinnamon . pumkin is quite present . taste .  nouvelle srie l'exprience de schoune bire de couleur vieil or ou ambre , elle n'a pas de mousse , elle a aussi un nez lger et pic , elle possde une bouche herbeuse , avec un peu dpice , tout de mme elle a une belle longueur . agrable sans plus .  buttery aftertaste and mouthfeel is a big plus , but the way the alcohol overwhelms the flavor is mildly disappointing .

nice , pleasant nose here . i 'm torn on the taste .  this beer is to get you drunk for as little money as possible . it smells pretty bad , tastes pretty bad , and looks like warm piss .  m = thick and malty d = glad to be sharing it .

smell is of sweet chocolate .  a : murky brownish apricot , really not the most appetizing color in the world . no head , low carbonation evident .  m - creamy , full , minimal carbonation , which would make sense as this is naturally carbonated .

additionally this is definitely a filtered wheat beer so this one does not have any of that hazy characteristc associated with most wheat beers . the beer smells mostly of strong wheat with some distinct spicy undertones that come through with the wheat aromas .  this beer pours into the glass with a very pale golden body topped by little head with no lacing to speak of .  the smooth feel of the liquid and its medium-hevay mouthfeel bring hope , as does a dark chocolate aftertaste .

upon smelling this beer i got a lot of coffee on the nose and could smell the sour ( interesting ) .  has a very pale yellow color with a 1/2 inch head .  mouthfeel is light with a good amount of carbonation .

aroma is inviting with all the standard trappings of an oatmeal stout .  a : it poured an odd green tinted yellow colored body with a minimal white hed that receded fast to a ring around the collar that supported a nominal almost non-existent lacing . it was surprisingly , especially considering its uninspiring appearance and smell .  m - good carb , medium body d - for this style i feel it 's a little on the weak side , that being said it still is a pretty tasty brew .

clean , saazy czech pilsner nose .  butterscotch yellow cloudy body with absolutely no head or lacing . this beer should be very clear and have at least a minimal head , but it looks very flat and unattractive in the glass .  m - good mouthfeel . again , the abv content is well hidden in the mouthfeel .

nice . t - the alcohol in this is way too overpowering .  completely flat , pours with no foam whatsoever , let alone head .  a cheap porter is like a bad shortcut : seems like a good idea at first , until suddenly you find yourself in a swamp of murky flavors and wish youd taken the trouble of keeping to a more sure-footed path . the mouthfeel is plump and has good roll , and lace makes a solid appearance . the best thing i can think of to do with this beer is take the label off and tell your friends you brewed it yourself .

aroma of buttery toffee , super malty , and that 's about it . not much going on with the taste . there are some very interesting notes on the finish , but they seem to disappear so quickly i ca n't define or enjoy them . i do n't think it 's very smokey as others have suggested , and alcohol lingers in my throat and breath .  appearance - pours a very dark brown with almost no head and no lacing .  medium/light mouthfeel .
aroma : largely of toffee and caramel .  crap , dead flat no head or bubbles to speak of .  mouthfeel is very thick and chewy , like drinking syrup .

i 'll probably be coming back and re-rating this beer since i tried it after a having about 4 pints of stouts and porters and a full meal . i was a bit full and the spices were just two much . i tried to get it down , but after about four sips , it went to my friend .  500ml bottle poured into my zirndorfer seidel a - golden lager body , 3 finger head that dissapate quickly to leave a crown . rubbish lacing .  mouthfeel : light in bodied . clean aftertaste .

smell was nice , mild hops , but i felt the body was lacking as was flavor compared to the aroma .  pours a golden , clear glass that is incredibly fizzy and carbonated . there is an incredibly thin white head that dissipates immediately .  mouthfeel is thickish and syrupy with decent carb .

pleasantly hoppy aroma .  granted it pours a boring yellow , has not head , and smells like grains .  surprisingly , mouthfeel is quite lush and the carbonation pretty on for a beer that probably co2 injected .

the smell was very complex . it had elements of citrus , alcohol , and other things . the taste was similar , except for the overbearing taste of an old musty house with moth balls .  color was a orangy gold . very weak head ( and i poured aggressivly ) . what head was there was sudsy , not frothy , and it did n't stay long . overall this comes across like a first draft of that belgian style we all know and love .  the carbonation is low and there is a somewhat smooth mouthfeel to the beer .

smells very citussy and even a touch grapelike . sweet like a sparkling wine . also a very orangey scent . still very sweet but with a fairly significant bitter bite .  a : pours a one and a half finger head of slight cream , light thickness , and bad retention .  the feel of this beer is very pleasant and should be applauded .

s -- as advertised , smells like a dubbel/dopplebock mix . candi sugar , raisin , a bit of rum , caramel and grape . t -- similar to smell . for me , the grape presence seems out of place .  a- dirty yellow , white head .  mouthfeel : smooth , medium-bodied mouthfeel . also a little zing from the carbonation .

quite the interesting hop aroma . buttery background , but overall , nice . bitter and alcoholic . nice aroma , but overall , a terrible beer .  poured this selection into a frosted pint glas and was surprised at how quickly the almost non existint head vanished .  the mouthfeel is creamy and slick , the drinkability is just not there .

nose has a sweet fruit aroma ( imagine that ) , with the malt backing , citrus like crispness also noted .  uh , this is not that great . looks bad , yellowish .  milkshake-like texture . it was smooth . so smooth that it lacked character .

the smell was another story . it was a nice mix of aromas , with banana , citrus , apple , pepper , and the yeasts typical of the style . its drinkable and not offensive , but it is a very mediocre beer .  a : slightly hazy , pale green . head like champagne that faded fast and left nothing behind .  mouthfeel is nice , full , creamy , and not too carbonated . its pretty good .

smells like summer ; flowers and spices dominate .  this pours a reddish chestnut color with a scummy off white head that dissappears with laughable speed .  classic winter warmer m - medium body with medium carbonation d - ok. easy to drink but only kind of enjoyable

smells yeasty with fruit mixed in ( zesty citrus - lemon , orange , and some muted berry flavors ) . tastes yeasty , with sweet orange-lemon tang .  pours a pale , straw color with 1 fingers worth of head that fades with minimal lacing . now , i 'm not claiming bud light is some god-send of a beer , but for the style of american macro light lager , its one of the better ones .  mouthfeel , on the other hand , i would actually say is good .

there 's a big fluffy one inch head despite a conservative pour and giving it time to settle . it smells of apricots and honey . light and tropical . i do pick up a faint woody tone ... apparently we 're oaked here .  a : pours a 1.5 finger head of slight cream , fair thickness , and bad retention .  the mouthfeel was also really quite nice , a moderate body that is not at all cloying like the imperials can often be .

holiday spices and candied yams on the nose . allspice , nutmeg , cinnamon , and clove all present . some malty sweetness similar to caramel and toffee poking their head through as well , with a minimal hop presence . thin medium with a hint at drying , and a tickle of carbonation good nose , with a lacking flavor .  bottles may 2007 expiration pint glass a : poured a clear golden color with a sudsy head that quickly frittered away . little lacing .  m : medium-full and well carbonated d : this beer nicely fits the characteristics appropriate for abbey beers , but is lacking in intensity ( as compared with other classic examples ) .

the smell is roast caramel & nuts with a hint of floral aroma .  it litterally took about 5 minutes to pour this bottle into a 19-ounce glass , so that counts for a big deduction in appearance . so all in all this was , for me , a disappointing beer due to highly excessive carbonation and what i felt were overly sour tones in the smell and flavor .  mouthfeel is medium with good carbonation .

a nice zippy spiciness here that 's enjoyable . first sip brings an upfront pale , wheaty maltiness that is a bit astringent . no real detectable hops here .  a : pale golden body . 1/2 '' white head that did n't last long & left little lacing .  `` sampled '' this beer at the saratoga brewery ... .they have an odd practice of selling you the glass and then pouring you 2 `` sample beers '' - clever ! the flavour is more of the same - very light on the palette , and extremely refreshing for a 6 % beer .

appearance 3 nose 4 this brings back memories of sipping my dad 's beer . it 's a nostalgia 4 , not really a ratings 4 .  the way macro brews used to taste . albeit just a `` kiss of the hops '' , schlitz is still a satisfying beer with a decent but not particularly flavorful lager .  the body is full . the taste is truly well balanced , to the point of being bland . it does have some hop like aftertaste which is very surprizing and adds a small bit of character to which this brew is in need of .

aroma is rich toffee , chocolate , and dark fruit infused with alcohol warmth . woody oak notes come through cleanly , but then a stale alcohol quality spoils the mood . damn shame .  this beer pours like a pilsner with litte head . and looks like another lawn mowing beer .  mouthfeel was fine .

although the first time i had it i was quite impressed with the aroma of strawberries . it was very musky .  the beer is a very pale yellow with a light white head that dissipated very quickly .  the feel is good . slightly heavy but not too bad . has some carbonation present .

the appearance and smell win you over . its terrible . you think since its got elderberry in the name you would taste it ... but you dont .  looks like processed apple juice with fizz and has a strong head .  mouthfeel is good and creamy . very oily and probably lots of dry hopping on this one .

it smells very pilsener-esque . very earthy and snappy , slightly watery like a pilsener does . it smells like your sniffing hops ( homebrewers know ... ) .  orangish yellow lager and mostly opaque . huge chunks of yeast floating around make it look like a dirty fish bowl . do n't get me wrong , i 'm ok with a little yeast floating around in my beer but this is too much and is not inviting . thin and bubbly white head forms and vanishes before your eyes leaving little to no lacing .  again , mouthfeel is smooth and rich , a real revelation , actually , but i would n't want to drink more than a thimbleful of this in a sitting .

i recieved a bottle of this ale from my husband for my birthday . i did not like this ale.i liked the aroma and the frst hit on the palate , but then it left a medicinal taste in my mouth .  if 'wee heavy ' is the flagship , this is the ocean . a body of water that got tossed a few blueberries ; only temporarily churned up by the wind .  m - full-bodied and refreshingly crisp in carbonation d - i 'll drink the 6-pack over a few nights , but i 'm rather disappointed in the brew .

on tap at moeder lambic . low lacing throughout which again makes me think it 's not a witbier or even a pale ale . s : nose is of nothing in reality . smells like it wants to be a wit , but ca n't . t : pleasant , light , sessionable beer ... but seems like someone took a lager and `` dry orange peeled/coriandered '' it very very lightly .  in my opinion it 's better than the big macros on the market and a hell of a lot cheaper . a : light pale yellow with a head that dissipated in seconds s : smells of grain and corn t : what the style should be .  a-light brown body with an off white head s-citrusy , grapefruit t-firm malt front , hoppy but not overwhelming m-light-medium mouthfeel d-not very assertive for this style but all styles have a range and this is on the weak end of the assertive flavor scale

smells of sour strawberries and sweet heaven .  pours an absolutely flat copper color .  mouth feel is smooth and clean , with a low carbonation level . overall , poor appearance , but good aroma , feel , and body .

herbal and soft white pepper aroma first , mild strawberries , sweet pineapple , green grapes , rhubarb pie . classic fruity hoppy nose from stone . a mild earthy bite , dry wheat , watery , thin in the middle with mellow fruity hoppy overall with very little else happening .  i found this tiger lager a disappointment ... ..very little head , and what there was quickly disapaited ... there is no sparkle to this product and certainly no fizz ... .nice colour , full bodied ... but flat , as if it had been poured the night before..how sad !  cereal . this is an old school ipa , so i was not expecting a hop bomb . some hop bitterness . smooth and refreshing .

s : bready , yeasty , very much in line with the smell of new belguim 's `` fat tire '' . a toasty smell with some subtle hints of alcohol at the end of the smell .  appearance : pale yellow carbonation with no head at all .  the mouthfeel works for me . it has a nice thickness to it with a fairly substantial amount of felt carbonation .

a very sophisticated and refined looking beer , and just exactly what you want in a berliner weisse . loads of funk and acidity on the nose , tart citrus rind , grapefruit , composting greenery and crushed vegetation . maybe this is a berliner weisse which really requires syrup to give it any character ( or rather , to cover the weak , but unpleasant characters it has ) . it was promising on the nose , and it looked the part , but it could n't hold its end up when it counted .  it 's roughly the color and transparency of the bottle it used to be in , making it too light for a stout , and the pour recalls urination in that it makes plenty of noise but every bubble produced is full of air , not co2 . what little froth ever existed evaporates with the precipitance of a bullet . it does n't help matters that , in order to produce any head and thereby a more vivid aroma , i 'd have to agitate my glass with enough fervor that if it were a baby 's throat i 'd be sentenced to death . watery in heft but sticky and persistent on the palate .  the taste unfortunately got skewed right away as the butteriness of this brew superceded any and all other flavors . the feel was medium/full and creamy .

aroma : coffee and dark chocolate , that 's a nice combo flavor : pretty straight forward coffee and roast grains . bit too burnt for me but coffee is not overdone as in many examples . a nice beer though .  an equally watery white head rises and is gone right away ... a gag me aroma that reminds me of budweiser with corn and grain and slightly less skunk than the king ... the taste surprises as its not a watery skunk , its actually bursting with strong in your faces hops , the hops are strong and bitter but in a rote metallic way .  body is right , but finish is somewhat boozy .
the aroma is mostly citrusy hops , especially grapefruit , with a hint of pine .  pours absolutely nooo carbonation whatsoever .  m : feels refreshing , average carbonation .

first sip confirms jagermeister smell , but with a burnt aftertaste . most of the reviews here have hit the flavor right on the nose . jager / ale / menthol cigarette is an accurate description .  pours a golden yellow that is clear . develops a thin white head that dissipates quickly into a narrow collar .  the feel was very creamy .

aromas of roasted , toasty rolled oats dance alongside hunks of bakers chocolate and hints of dark fruit . sweet and roasty with a smattering of alcohol and hops sitting in the background . puckering ... this one seems to be infected ... and how i was looking forward to it ... damn . there 's a slight hint of hops on the finish but the overbearing sourness ruins the overall character of the brew .  as with my other experiences with berghoff , not much of a head , and very light carbonation .  consumed 12/03/07 at crown city brewing , pasadena . creamy nitro texture . then , unexpected black coffee bitterness appears on tongue long after beer is gone .

appearance is of tannic swamp water . aroma is of toffee and molasses , with a strong suggestion of vinous alcohol , and some oak barrel woodiness . or , i just do n't like ales that look and taste like wine .  a- labelling is alright ... pours a watered down apple juice color and no head whatsoever is detectable ... there was n't really even any foam when i poured this beer .  mouthfeel - nice round feel , good carbonation .

i say about this beer what i 'll say about all of dundee 's beers : if you want to teach someone about beer , by some dundee styles and train them on what are simple examples of the various styles . i think they empty the brewery 's spice rack with this one as the flavor profile is all over the place . it is an interesting treat for those long winter nights .  deep murky dark brown color . no lacing at all .  mouth feel : the mouthfeel is quite smooth and full for the style .

aroma was of malt and a nice vanilla/chocolate .  beer poured clear light yellow with minimal head . looked almost like an adjunct lager , but the yellow was a little more intense .  mouthfeel is light body and there is lots of nice carbonation .

very different aroma . possibly some toffee there too .  served from a 500ml brown twist off bottle into a pilsner glass . a- pale straw color , fizzy head fades in seconds . the appearance screams macro .  m - kind of a lingering bitter finish . fairly full bodied with moderate carbonation .

smell is plum , spice , and bready .  listed at an even 7 % abv instead of 7.5 , and served ice cold . pours a relatively deep golden colour , comparable to apple juice in hue . there is one half-finger of soapy white head on top , which soon dies down to a thin , filmy cap . malty , sweetish aftertaste lingers for a bit along with just a bit of boozy heat - maybe i 'm just getting used to higher abv beers after all the belgian stuff i 've had lately , but the extra alcohol seems reasonably well-hidden . not something i 'm likely to get again when i can think of 2 other strong polish lagers i 'd prefer , but at least this stuff is cheap .  mouthfeel : lower than average carbonation , good for a stout . body is very good .

color is a lovely , clear cherry , copper amber . aroma is malt , toffee , caramel , a bit of fruit and roast .  yuengling premium pours a pale straw color with a decent but somewhat fizzy white head that disappears quickly , leaving some thin whispy lace down the side of the glass .  m- there is a creamy medium-full mouthfeel with a mellow alcohol heat and soft fizz in the finish .

a nose of wheat , amost bready in character.very pleasing in smell . taste is pretty good .  pours a clear mix of straw and amber with a dismal to eventualy no head .  in the mouth , it was rather solid , having a nice creamy feel with lively carbonation .

smell - smells like it is going to be a slightly sweeter version of the belgian white blue moon taste - was not happy with it . it was very sweet and then all of a sudden kinda sour and bitter .  a=pours a very thin looking golden color , thin head , completely transparent .  the mouthfeel is pretty solid . medium bodied , decent carbonation , moderately sticky .

smells is completely dominated by the odor of fresh ground ginger and an every so slight maltiness . taste is very mild maltiness with a subtle layer of ginger followed by a touch of hops , very underwhelming .  bottled 3rd week of september , pours caramel with 3+ fingers of tan head . no lacing or head retention s : toasty malt & leafy hops & coffee t : toasty malt , dryness & coffee up front .  the body is light and it goes down with an easy dryness .

this beer smelled better than tasted .  pours a clear yellow gold with a small white head that quickly goes to a thin film that leaves a little lacing .  m - lightly carbonated . creamy all in the mouth , and finishes wet .

low head , clear golden colour , pleasant hoppy aroma .  castel is a lager that is light in color like a pot of gold . this euro pale lager , is the best deal in town at $ 1 for a large can that will make the silver bullet run for it 's money .  m - medium-full body , lower carbonation , a slightly grainy texture , with light residual stickiness .
